summary: Bitten by a radioactive spider in the subway, Brooklyn teenager Miles Morales suddenly develops mysterious powers that transform him into the one and only Spider-Man. When he meets Peter Parker, he soon realizes that there are many others who share his special, high-flying talents. Miles must now use his newfound skills to battle the evil Kingpin, a hulking madman who can open portals to other universes and pull different versions of Spider-Man into our world.

Amazing. Spectacular. Sensational. Superior. These words have all been used to describe the character of Spider-Man. They can all ALSO be used to describe ‘Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse'. The film follows young Miles Morales who, after being bitten by a radioactive spider (sound familiar?), starts on his thrilling journey to becoming the new Spider-Man! Along the way he encounters several alternate, dimension-displaced versions of Spidey. These Spider-People include an older, jaded Peter Parker, Spider-Gwen, Spider-Man Noir, Spider-Ham (Yes, he's a pig), and Peni Parker (along with her biomechanical suit called SP//dr). The story is uplifting, inspiring, and hilarious, with the message that "Anyone can wear the mask". The animation style is unlike anything I've ever seen before. The film looks like a comic book come to life, and it was captivating and mesmerizing to watch. It really is a "comic book movie"! I left the theater feeling like I had just witnessed something truly special. The cast and characters were all FANTASTIC, but my favorites were Spider-Ham and Spider-Gwen. The villains were all menacing and intimidating, which I feel is rare in an animated film. The music was also incredible and complimented the film PERFECTLY. In conclusion, ‘Into the Spider-Verse' is an emotional story about believing in yourself and becoming who you were meant to be, regardless of any obstacles that may be in your way. It doesn't matter who you are or where you come from...you can be a hero. YOU could wear the mask. It is not only the best Spider-Man movie thus far, it's my new favorite animated film and one of the greatest comic book movies of all-time.

Into the Spider-Verse" is an outstanding animated film that breaks new ground in the superhero genre. Its animation style is a unique blend of 2D and computer-generated animation with a comic book aesthetic that makes the visuals dynamic and vibrant. 

The story is both emotional and action-packed, following the journey of Miles Morales, a young boy who gains spider-like abilities and becomes Spider-Man. When a group of villains threatens the fabric of reality, Miles teams up with other versions of Spider-Man from different dimensions to save the day. 

The characters are well-developed and have their own distinct personalities and backstories that make the story even more compelling. 

Overall, "Into the Spider-Verse" is a must-see movie for superhero fans and anyone who appreciates exceptional animation and storytelling.
Beautiful animation and an amazing story. I loved it

Visualmente asombrosa y surrealista, esta película es una obra de arte por su combinación de animación tradicional y CGI. Aunque esta película fue realizada por Sony, no hay duda de que esta es la que da inicio al concepto del multiverso en la filmografía de Marvel, que luego comenzaría a ser aplicado en el MCU relacionándola con la trilogía de Spiderman de Sam Raimi, la saga de The Amazing Spiderman, la saga de X-Men y el SSU. Claro que el multiverso empezó a usarse en los cómics y ahora se usa en las películas, expandiendo la filmografía de Marvel de una manera alocada y excitante. Además esta película aclara una incógnita sobre que pasaría si Peter Parker en algún momento se iría y quien lo reemplazaría. La respuesta aquí es Miles Morales, quien también recibe los poderes de casualidad. Incluso también nos presenta otro Peter cuya historia sirve para responder que sucedió después de la saga de The Amazing Spider-Man luego de que Gwen muere, y también una historia alterna sobre si, en vez de Peter, hubiese sido Gwen quien recibiera los poderes, al igual que Peggy Carter en What If?. Otros puntos más a mencionar son la escena post créditos que conecta con la serie animada de los años 60 y la enemistad entre Wilson Fisk y Spider-Man que recuerda a la serie animada de los 90. Esta película y su secuela dejan abierta la puerta de que todo es posible en el multiverso sin excepción alguna, tal como se ve en el MCU lo cual tiene una enorme importancia en la filmografía de Marvel. Spider-Man: Into The Spiderverse es sin duda la película ideal para comenzar a conocer el multiverso una vez ya visto las películas y series que Marvel hizo anteriormente y comenzar este viaje multiversal que para alguien que le gusta Marvel es un hermoso sueño húmedo. Mi calificación para esta película es un 9/10.

This might be better than "No Way Home" and definitely served as a prototype for that live action movie.  Who knew an action sci-fi cartoon could be better than it's live action counter-part?!  But the script here is so strong.  It takes you by surprise with it's inventiveness.  Plot wise this mixes together as aspects of the standard Superhero origin story; which is expected.  But then it brings in It's a Wonderful Life and Christmas Carol; where the ghosts of Christmas past so to speak; (in this case other versions of the hero himself; from different dimensions) coach the hero and train him, a la Obi Wan Kenobi, to rise to the occasion of his super hero calling.  It's a wonderful plot; building on the whole idea of past franchise cast members joining the movie as characters from a different universe; or dimension; a conceit cleverly started by Jeremy Abrahams' Star Trek years ago.  A wonderful story and a wonderful cast; wonderfully inventive; great chemistry between the actors; the story consistently surprises you; and you leave the theater definitely hungry for a second course!  I can't wait to see the next installment in June!  Highly recommend!

What a way to end 2022! I watched this film when it came out in 2018 and hadn't revisited it. Let me tell you that my opinion has changed a lot since then. I truly believe that "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" is the best Spider-Man movie ever released.

There is emotional complexity to this movie and an incredible depth to each character (especially Miles). The "all is lost" moment is masterclass storytelling and creates a near-perfect finale.

"Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" showcases why film is my favorite medium for storytelling. 

Best Character: Miles (honorable mention to Peter B. Parker)
Best Scene: Leap of Faith (Top 10 all time)
Best Quote: "Anyone can wear the mask. You could wear the mask."
Best Song: "What's up Danger"

Note: Stan Lee's cameo is this movie is an all-timer.

Spiderverse is a triumph in animation. It manages to be an un-selfserious adventure romp with smirky dialogue and absurdist silliness, while deploying some of the most creative cinematography I've seen in any film - superhero or no. It seemlessly blends trendy modern styles and music with a vividly 'on the page' comic-book aesthetic. It is just as contrived as the next comic book movie, and even more lighthearted. Yet somehow it feels so much more grounded in the lives and emotions of actual people. The now souless and repetitive comic book movie landscape is here completely disrupted with something altogether more ambitious, artistic and - genuinely - funny.

All in all, this film does everything that animation should give you the freedom to do. Go big, go crazy,  go creative.

I particularly liked the times when speech from the comic book that the film seems to be set in, appears on screen - this doesn't happen all the time but from time to time and its quite amusing and visually appealing. I suppose its a little bit like the old Batman live action show, with one or two times where noises made appear on screen, like 'bonk' etc.

This film should appeal to action film fans - although it is CGI, its very fast paced and engrossing and I wouldn't say its entirely meant for young children - it can be enjoyed by an older audience too but would certainly entertain youngish people as well, so its a bit of an all rounder.I very much enjoyed this - I think it's a film that's probably worth a re-watch or two because there's so much going on that it'd be easy to miss little clues and details while watching the main action on your first view. I'll watch it again at some point and see if I'm right about that or not but otherwise, yes, I'd certainly recommend this film as a decent, solid bit of action packed entertainment. I wouldn't necessarily say it's a film with a lot of thought provoking aspects as such but for what it is, it's a very good film regardless.

But the charm and memorable design make this a mute point overall. Easily not just a classic super hero or animated movie but this is A All Time Classic in General.

Warning: Spoilers
"Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" is a fantastic film but might be a bit overwhelming for some viewers. It's filled with blaring hip-hop music and the animation is beyond splashy...it's competely intense! Now these are NOT criticisms...more a warning if you hate these sorts of things or if you or someone you loves has challenges, such as Autism....as the film might really be overwhelming. Still, I'm nearly 55 and loved the picture...and I think most will if they have an open mind and want something different. That DOES strongly apply to me, as I've gotten sick of superhero movies because there have been so many recently and there's a certain sameness about them...but not this Spider-Man film!

The story is told with breathtaking CGI--with a look that is nothing like any other film I've ever seen. In this world is a young man who sees Spider-Man killed and is also bitten by a spider and becomes the next incarnation of Spider-Man. But instead of taking the time to enjoy and learn about his new powers, this young man finds himself in the middle of a weird apocalyptic occurance---and all the various incarnations from the various universes come together to save the day.

Overall, amazingly creative...there's nothing else like it. This is more than reason enough to see it. Sadly, however, the film loses a bit on home TVs...even big ones as the scale and size of the film needs the big screen.

The best Spider-Man movie ever after the first two Sam Raimi movies and No Way Home and the best animated movie after WALL-E and Batman: Mask of the Phantasm. The ground-breaking 3D-2D comic book CGI animation is so unique it looks like the evolution of visual art and it reminds me of the art style from the Ultimate Spider-Man and Spider-Man Shattered Dimensions game. This movie is about representation, inspiration, interacting in your revolutionary-looking world, and becoming your own icon. Miles Morales is the second best coming-of-age character to be Spider-Man.

Being Spiderman in movies isn't easy. We always have high expectations for this iconic hero. And you know what? This movie reaches and passes them easily. Everything here is perfect. You can just be watching a well-done action scene, enjoying a beautiful and accurate soundtrack, having fun with perfectly timed jokes (it's serious or fun when it has to be) or maybe crying because something heartbreaking happened. Also, there are spidermen for everyone. Are you a young teenager? No problem, you will identify with Miles leading with all the changes he's going through. If you are a late teenager, you will understand the reason for all Spidergwen's actions. Besides, for old people, there will be Peter B. Parker being everything you expected from someone who's in his 30's or 40's and has to face the world.

This movie has no flaws. It gets everything right and has an evident care for our beloved web head. This movie is a testament to Spiderman and all the fans who have stuck with him for the past sixty years, young and old. The animation is beyond perfect and the tiny details, the creativity, and the genius of this movie never fail to amaze me. The voice actors are perfect for their respected roles and every line is delivered with such wit. The story is flawless and neatly paced with witty humor, drama, and creative action scenes all in one. But what I love most about this movie is it's unique understanding of our friendly neighborhood Spiderman. It understands what it's like to be the underdog, fighting a battle when you don't know how to fight, constantly failing yet refusing to fall. Into the Spider-verse has such a clear comprehension on what it means to be Spiderman. Anyone can wear the mask because all it takes is the courage to get back up after getting beat down, which I find is Spider-man's most important trait. Spider-man always gets the worst luck and yet continues to fight on because it's his responsibility. No matter what happens, he finds a way to perservere because it's the right thing to do. It was an interesting choice using Miles Morales as the protagonist and I think it made the movie all the more special, telling the story of Spiderman from a different, refreshing perspective while maintaining the heart of its origins with Peter Parker. There is so much right with this movie.

Excelente película, una de las mejores películas de superhéroes y del personaje. Lo que mas se destaca a simple vista es la animación, es increíble lo bien hecha que esta toda la película, con esta animación llena de luces, colores y detalles muy bien cuidados. La banda sonora es perfecta y queda muy bien con el personaje de Miles. La trama es super entretenida y divertida, y aunque parezca que es la misma historia de siempre, tiene algunos giros y sorpresas muy interesantes. El personaje de Miles cae muy bien, ya que siendo un personaje "nuevo" para la mayoría del publico, logra que cuando termina el film te den ganas de ver mas de la historia de él. El villano principal también es muy bueno, con una historia y una motivación muy bien contada. Los otros tipos de Spider-man llegan a ser muy carismáticos todos y con un estilo diferente cada uno, pero sin dudas se destaca el Spider-man de Peter B. Parker, quien tiene una gran historia detrás. La cinta además tiene escenas icónicas, como por ejemplo la del salto de fe de Miles, la cual por su significado se vuelve muy memorable. En conclusión, una de las mejores películas de Spider-man, logrando un mejor desarrollo de personajes que las dos primeras películas del UCM de Spider-man y contando con una animación brutal, que la llevo a ganar el Oscar. Muy recomendada.

Why did it take me so long to see this? A wonderfully imaginative and creative blast that harnasses the unique possibilities of animation and the best of the superhero genre with wit and intelligence to produce something new and different. Unlike many new and different pieces of art, however, it's also warm and inviting. Brilliantly animated, acted, and directed, it has uplifting ideas about diversity and inspiration without being too sentimental or 'life lesson' of the worse type. Possibly a shade too long - or that may be a tired, Covid recovering viewer speaking - but all in all it's a brilliant acheivement.

It's refreshing to see an animated Spider-Man sequel for  a change. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is groundbreaking in many ways. Its unique style of animation would make you feel like you're watching a comic book come to life. It's almost like a full-length motion comic movie. The sound editing and musical score also helped create the different moods. Although there were times when it was too loud and a bit overdone. The addition of comics-style narration and comic book sound effects was a great idea. The story itself was alright. The movie is full of action, chases, twist & turns and character interaction. A little bit fast-paced, but it's a very entertaining audio-visual treat!

One of the best things to come from Spiderman and one of my favourite movies. There's very little I can complain about. Parts of this movie look like they would've simply been better looking if they weren't animated on two's. And I wasn't the biggest fan of Spider-ham or Penni Parker. Aside from that, everything was fantastic.

Visually this movie looks great, especially with its creative use of camera angles. The action was great to look at, a lot of the comedy landed perfectly, and when it got serious it did that very well. This was the first time I had ever seen Miles Morales and he was a joy to watch, he's written excellently. I had previously seen Gwen and of course Peter, and they were great in this movie as secondary main characters. The other three members of the team didn't get much time to shine, but I think it was better to focus on the main three rather than sacrifice some of the time they got or make the movie much longer to flesh out six different protagonists.

This is, in my opinion, the best movie adaptation of a superhero comic that has ever been produced. All the characters are interesting and memorable, and, while there are many characters in the film, it doesn't lose sight of the fact that it is a Miles Morales origin story. The animation is outstanding, and mixed with the superb voice talents, great soundtrack, and interesting story, it makes for a great time! On a side note that is more opinion than fact, if you have never read a Miles Morales or Spiderverse comic, I recommend NOT reading any before watching this film, to prevent any surprises from being ruined! I hadn't read any before watching Into the Spiderverse, and I wouldn't change that even if I could.

Incredible movie. A bit late for this review, as the movie came out 3 years ago, but to this day it remains my favourite movie. The animation is so smooth, and there are so many details going on. The rewatchability of this movie is incredible. The soundtracks really compliment to the mood, and are incredible on their own. The messages and ending keeps you on the edge of your seat, with the gripping last fight scene keeping you extremely invested in the movie. You can feel yourself relate and root for Miles, and you can really see his emotions alongside him. Absolute hands down an incredible movie, and my favourite ever. It doesn't delve into the typical gore genre of superhero movies to keep the viewers invested, and can be watched by all ages. Best to watch at home though for a few people, as the effects in the theaters may be a bit too much (especially older citizens). The movie also has some very funny moments that are perfect for each situation, unlike other movies that use jokes halfway through the climax. Would definitely recommend to anyone who enjoys films in general. 10/10. The animation is smoother than water, the acting is just perfect, the jokes land right on target, and the movie in general keeps you glued to the story. Hyped up for the sequel coming out next year. Definitely recommend, 10/10.

The perfect Spiderman movie and one of the most perfect animated movies to debut. "Spiderman: Into the Spider-Verse" tells an incredibly moving story that has powerful messages throughout. The animation is phenomenal, and is done in a way to make it seem like an actual comic book is coming to life in front of your eyes. This is easily the most comical of the Spiderman films, even bringing in several references to the comic books themselves. The humor is handled very well, and the banter between Miles and Peter, Miles and Gwen, and Miles and his dad, Jefferson, is extremely entertaining to watch. The villain is also one of the best to ever hit the screen, being a villain that you feel sorry for and even begin understanding his motivations for what he does and why he does it. However, I think where this film really shines is in its action, which is done so well and is so fun to watch. The cast is absolutely perfect, and the ending will leave fans dying to see the sequel.

This movie is just amazing: 
1. The animation is insanely unique and the perfect style for this world: so vibrant and colorful with striking and memorable imagery in almost any scene.
2. The story balances multiple characters but gives each of them great moments and development. Miles is a perfect protagonist for this story, the slight subversion on the older Spider-Man fits, Kingpin is given enough backstory to understand, and the Prowler twist is handled so well. Amazing voice acting for each of these characters as well.
3. The plot should be all over the place, but the writing and directing smoothly moves you through this movie like you're turning the pages of a comic book.
4. I really felt the weight of this world and the characters: when Spider-Man is killed, I am reacting in the same way as Miles- watching a seemingly invincible icon and personal hero get beaten by the bad guy. I felt Miles struggles with his dad and the expectations on him. When Miles finally gets in touch with his abilities and accepts that this is who he is, I truly felt for him. Hell, the Stan Lee cameo is even one of the most emotional scenes in the movie: my sister and I were both crying when we watched this in theaters the first time after his death. 
Ultimately, this movie is just a Spider-Man fans perfect movie, and this movie is an experience that I will always enjoy and remember fondly, and I regard it as one of if not the best animated/superhero movies of all time.

A must watch before you leave this planet film where it test the possibilities of what animation can advance to and maybe one day be in the rankings to aim for Best Picture with the right script and direction with the likes of the minds of three directors - Peter Ramsey, Rodney Rothman and Bob Persichetti, and the duo of Phil Lord and Chris Miller. Absolutely mind-blowing stylized animation that viewers will never have expected from the trailers. Sony really found its mark and style in the animation sector and hopes to bring the same quality in future installments and original IPs. A very diverse cast and who knew an African-American Hispanic Spider-man could be the new inspiration for the next generation of animators and story-tellers. Can't wait for the follow up sequel to this universe.

I've never seen a bad Spider-Man movie, you'd be pretty hard pressed to do so. No disrespect intended to Peter Parker (The OG) but I've come to like Miles Morales' origin story better. Also add the other alternate universes of Spider-Men (and Spider-Women when you add Gwen Stacy and Peni Parker to the equation) and you're in one heck of a ride. You also get to see a various amount of villains such as Green Goblin, a lady Doc Oct, Scorpion, Tombstone, Kingpin and my new favorite, the Prowler (I REALLY loved his design in this movie). Small negative would be the omission of Venom & Carnage to add into this already crazy melee of characters but the movie still did it's thing without them. There is but so much you can pack in a 2 hour movie but I expect none less from Marvel. I'm also grateful Sony had their hands on this one letting the story and narrative of the plot be great, while this probably still would be decent under Disney's supervision, it would've been watered down to make this movie a 4 Star at best.

Normally whenever there is an introduction to a new alter-ego for a superhero we all know and love, it is often met with backlash. No one can accept Dick Grayson as Batman, Calvin Ellis as Superman,  Carol Danvers as Captain Marvel, Wally West as The Flash - the list goes on. And Spider-Man is one of, if not the most popular and likeable superheroes out there. So in such a condition replacing our beloved Peter Parker with some new random guy could have been a disastrous idea. But not only did this movie take the risk, we're glad it did.
Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is the kind of a superhero animated movie I wanted to see - one with traditional animation done in the style of stereoscopic 3D, with continuous symbols of glitches. Personally I consider watching two superhero movies to be the most connected with watching a comic - Zack Snyder's Justice League and this. And out of the two ZSJL feels more like some painting more than an actual comic, so this one takes the cake for it. The speech bubbles, the panel swipes, the colour splashes; everything make this movie look like watching a Spider-Man comic come to life.
Personally I'm all in for the diversity in the characters. Normally I am annoyed when diversity is their only trait. When such a character is added just for the sake of existing, it just makes it look like a wasted effort, and what makes worse is that we can't even point it out without upsetting some people. Miles Morales, however, absolutely does not feel the same. The kind of a person he is, the way he turns into Spider-Man and meets the other heroes to learn more about who and what he is, everything seems to come out naturally.
The story is very well thought out, which is also another reason why it feels so natural. If I were given to introduce a character and bid farewell to the renowned one, I could have never done it as well as this did. It introduced many different types of Spideys, made us feel emotions for all of them, had us sympathise with the bad guys all the while making us laugh and cheer at the fights. See this is exactly what I'd want from a comic book movie, especially a superhero one. It should not just be, but actually feel like we are immersed into the environment, even though it is an animated movie.
My favourite character in this movie was Spider-Noir. He was hilarious as a detective, always talking about everything like it is supposed to be a mystery. He also looked cool, so there's also a plus to that. Then I also liked Miles Morales himself. Whatever the movie was wanting me to feel for him, I did so. As he builds his character development from being a clumsy teenager to the most powerful Spidey, it was a spectacle to watch.
I really wish to see more of these. Miles Morales is already one of my favourite characters now, so even if in future he slowly replaces Peter Parker as the face of Spider-Man, I won't feel bad about it. The recent PS5 game, if I hadn't watched the movie, wouldn't have received my interest no matter however good it was, since I would never accept anyone else as my Spider-Man. It really seems to be a great time to be a Spidey-fan. I hope it lasts long.

I'm not generally one for rap , and there was a whole lot in this movie, but it fit in with the tone of the movie, both rythmiclly and lyriclly. The plot was kinda generic, but the movie isn't plot driven, its character driven, and the characters are incredible, so I have no complaints. The only issue I had with the movie was how Miles' storyline with his dad was kinda left hanging. His dad tried to confront him through the door, and that led Miles to hug his dad at the end of the movie, but he didn't know it was Miles, so that didn't really give Jeff the closure he needed for his arc with Miles, but maybe thats me digging to far into the movie. Over all, 9.5/10.

I would go as far as to say 'Spider-Man: Into the Spiderverse' is the most visually stunning film I've seen; with a truly unique and revolutionary comic-book-esque animation style, every frame is poster worthy. Its achievements are far from lying only in the aesthetic department, another standout feature for me being the the soundtrack. 'What's Up Danger' couldn't have been a more fitting superhero theme to match its urban hip-hop context, and other tracks such as Daniel Pemberton's 'The Prowler' will surely give you goose bumps.
Thankfully this film doesn't suffer from the ailment of previous Spidey films, either. We're introduced to an intricate web of wacky characters (looking at you, Peter Porker) without the plot being over muddled.
Congratulations to everyone involved in this clever modern classic that exploits the medium of animation to a new potential and shows us just how much more there is to discover in this realm of filmmaking.

I was torn between 3.5* and 4* for this but the higher won out due to just how spectacular it looks. However, this movie isn't as good as everyone makes it out to be. While it is a good movie, it is not nearly 'the best superhero movie ever' as I have seen some tout. There are some glaring plot issues (understandable with a multi-dimensional plotline) and a lot of the characters don't have anywhere near enough screentime or interaction with Myles to get the emotional sendoff the movie tries to shove down our throats. However, it is still a damn entertaining movie that got some genuine chuckles out of me at times. And Myles himself is a good character, as is fake Peter. It was just everyone else around them that felt a little flat, which again is understandable when introducing so many new characters into one movie. It was overall good, but not excellent like some suggest.

The story centers around a young man by the name of Miles Morales and he like any other teenager is struggling to find his place and where exactly he belongs in this life. Due to the curious nature of the boy, he stumbles upon an abandoned NYC subway tunnel which will prove to change Miles forever. Miles was bitten by a radioactive spider not unlike the same spider whose given Spider-Man his power. Naturally Miles turns to the only person he knows could help, the actual Spider-Man. Now caught in a fight against Wilson Fisk turns into this inter-dimensional clash, one the proved to be too much to handle for only two super-powered Spider-Men. Once messing with dimensions, Miles meets and recruits 5 other super-powered Spider-Men and women from their respective dimensions in this battle over time and space. Will Miles be able to take a leap of faith and finally let go for the sake of the universes?

Decent... I'd recommend watching it... but it's definitely not the best they could have done. First, the things I absolutely love: the animation and music is some of the best I've ever seen. I love the comic book feel the movie creates. But, alas... the lesser great things in this movie: the characters are, for the most part, underdeveloped and most of the characters are shallow; some of the spider-person characters were just there to make a joke or two. Kingpin's backstory could have been fleshed out more to create a deeper antagonist, but we're just given one bit of backstory and that's that. And that's more I can say for the rest of the villains, or, Kingpin's villainous henchmen. But the biggest mistake in this movie is the main protagonist's father. Miles forges a kind of bond with his father by the end, through both himself (being the son) and on the other hand, Spiderman , and some character development took place, but I would have loved to see a lot more. Their relationship is still not where it should be, and the characters have a lot more development to undertake before I can picture their father-son relationship realistically.

If I had to describe this movie in one word, it would be unique. Everything about this movie just felt fresh and new to a genre that has been very saturated over the past few years. The entire film felt like it was told through this ADHD style lens that made each scene feel like you were right along side Miles. The action was fast paced and exciting, and it never failed to put a smile on my face. The movie also showed how well it is at balancing tones. One scene would make you cry, while the next made you laugh out loud, and the next would give you a sense of empowerment. The animation style was also pretty remarkable. It truly felt like a comic book brought to life. Every frame felt vibrant and lively, and you could really tell that the animators poured their heart and soul into. Overall, this movie was pretty damn amazing.

Spider-Man Into the Spiderverse provides a great coming of age story and a new spin on the story of the character of Spider-Man. It features the same aspects of the character such as family, friends, and responsibility in a new and bold way. The use of Miles Morales instead of Peter Parker as the main protagonist provides new angles and story telling devices. The use of the Kingpin as the main antagonist instead of other Spidey villains also helps to tie in the plot with the character, as the motives of Kingpin's plans look and seem justified while also reminding us about the true antagonist of the story. Overall, the plot, characters, and graphics all serve to create a dynamic movie never before seen in the big screen

I've watched this film around when it came out but decided to rewatch it again recently just because of the new Spider-Man: Miles Morales game. The premise of the movie is simply "Bitten by a radioactive spider in the subway, Brooklyn teenager Miles Morales suddenly develops mysterious powers that transform him into the one and only Spider-Man. When he meets Peter Parker, he soon realizes that many others share his special, high-flying talents. Miles must now use his newfound skills to battle the evil Kingpin, a hulking madman who can open portals to other universes and pull different versions of Spider-Man into our world". I absolutely adored it when it came out but do I still feel that way after rewatching it?

Firstly, the animation style and 3D models are absolutely amazing! While I do love the Pixar style of animation, this comic book style of animation was such a breath of fresh air in the animated film department. I also appreciate a lot of the aesthetic choices such as having this shaky movement instead of fluid which further makes it feel like a comic book come to life. The action scenes are also animated really well and are an absolute blast to watch as well. Clearly, a lot of thought went into this and it clearly shows in the movie. 

Miles Morales (Shameik Moore) is a great main lead. He isn't perfect and is actually very flawed with them making a fair amount of what would be frustrating mistakes. However, the directors succeed in still making us root for him as we can see how much he really wants to pull through for the team. Peter B. Parker (Jake Johnson) is another great Spiderman in this movie who is a mentor figure for Miles. He is a person who has been doing this spiderman business for over 20 years and has a lot of problems with his Peter Parker life such as his divorce with Mary Jane. Due to this, he is quite neglectful of Miles but he goes through his own character arc that is done very well. His chemistry with Miles is one of the things that really shine in this movie. Gwen Stacy/Spider-Woman (Hailee Steinfeld) is the third Spider character that appears in the movie and is mostly there to be the competent and supportive one in the group for Miles. The other three Spider characters Spider-Man Noir (Nicolas Cage),  Peni Parker (Kimiko Glenn) and Peter Porker (John Mulaney) are also all very distinct and different in personality which is perfectly converted despite small screentime. 

The cast is also phenomenal, everyone does a great job, especially Shameik Moore and Jake Johnson. There is also some other stellar casting like Brian Tyree Henry as Mile's dad, Mahershala Ali as Mile's Uncle Aaron, Chris Pine as Peter Parker of Mile's universe, Zoë Kravitz as Mary Jane, Kathryn Hahn as Doc Octopus, Liev Schreiber as Kingpin and even Oscar Issac for a mysterious role that I won't spoil. It's an all-star cast and even though some have small roles, Sony still went through with casting big known actors. They all do a great job. The excellent soundtrack further elevates this movie. Every time the Prowler is in the movie there is this horn in the soundtrack that makes him seem more threatening. Additionally, there are some pop, R&B, rap songs within the movie that all fit really well and gives more identity to the movie and characters. 

The story is simple yet intriguing enough to keep the audience engaged. It introduced the complex multiverse idea but doesn't overcomplicate it to make it distracting. There are multiple villains but the director makes sure the main focus of villains is Kingpin which is a good idea as multiple focus villains will make the plot feel convoluted. There is also excellent dialogue which is thanks to Phil Lord and Rodney Rothman. The jokes all land and the serious moments are heart-warming and the banter enjoyable. It's good dialogue and none feel wasted. 

If I have to give the movie a flaw then I would say it is kind of the Spiderman group dynamic. Spider-Man Noir, Peni Parker and Peter Porker don't interact much with Miles apart from being extremely harsh on him. It makes the last moments with these Spider characters not as strong. Miles also just become an extremely adept Spiderman because the plot needs him to be. It doesn't completely feel justified since it doesn't feel like he was provided with enough training to be that good. However, it doesn't break the movie and the sacrifices are understandable to keep this origin story in just under 2 hours.

Overall, Spider-Man into the Spider-verse is still one of the best-animated movies to come out in a long time. I still loved it after rewatching it. It's a fresh take on Spider-Man that we haven't seen before in a movie. If you haven't watched this movie yet then you must absolutely watch this movie. I can't wait for the sequel!

Before I explain what I think of this movie, i want to explain what I think of superhero movies as a whole;

Superhero movies typically get around 3-4 stars.  They're solid, they are entertaining, but they lack rewatchability and most of the visual effects look the same.  I even think some of the plots mesh together.  The only real reason people come to watch those films is for, let's face it, the action.  That's what a superhero film is about.  There are some exceptions, like the Dark Knight, but for the most part, superhero movies take themselves a little too seriously. 

The reason I bring that up is because SpiderVerse separates itself from the pack.  It does have action, but it also has some very likeable characters and some great dialogue.  There are even some emotional moments; depending on who you are, there are some scenes in the film that will make you cry.  Everything about this story works perfectly.

Of course, the biggest thing that separates this movie from animated films and superhero movies is the style.  Every frame of this movie is a comic book panel.  It's obvious that this was the intent, there are even onomatopoeia bubbles and dialogue boxes in some frames, but the aesthetic and framing of the movie also capture that.  This part stuck out to me because I LOVE comic books and graphic novels.

But, let's say you're not a fan of comic books or superhero movies [yes, those people exist].  If you are indifferent to that kind of thing, there is still an engaging, unique story, with engaging and unique characters.  The movie also has a great sense of humor, the type of humor that makes anybody laugh and smile.  

In short, the movie separates itself from the pack with clever writing, but what ultimately makes it a must-see is the stylistic presentation.  This movie is as beautiful on the outside as it is on the inside.

Spiderman Into the Spiderverse Review 
	Spiderman Into the Spiderverse is an animated film adaptation of the iconic superhero Spiderman. In into the Spiderverse a gifted teenager named Miles Morales becomes the one and, only Spiderman or so he thinks in his universe, and ends up teaming up with other Spiderpeople from other universes to stop a threat to all of their realities. Spider into the Spiderverse is a brilliant animated masterpiece, not only with mixing in traditional animation with computer animation, but with having many other typical elements that go along with animation such as humor and colorful characters. 
	Spiderman Into the Spiderverse pays tribute, not only to Spiderman, but to the animation genre in general. It pays tribute to traditional animation by showing traditional animation in the form of a comic book when one of the spidermen in the film whose name is Peter B Parker explains a plan he has to hack a computer. It also gives acknowledgment to classic animation simply by having a classical animated Spiderman in the form of a pig. It shows respect to anime by having an anime spiderwoman and to more modern animation by being mainly in the form of CGI. It gives nods to the original Tobey Maguire Spiderman films by showing some of the scenes from them over again in animation. It also plays the original main Spiderman theme song and features the old Spiderman cartoon that came out in the 60s. 
	The film has a fair amount of humor which is also admiring since animation traditionally and perhaps usually is associated with humor. If you notice during the opening scenes of the film when Mary Jane is kissing Spiderman it's Mary Jane hilariously hanging upside down instead of Spiderman. Peter B Parker sees a different version of himself which is not only a blond version of himself but a much nicer looking version of himself if you notice which is also amusing. There's also an inside joke when one of the spiderpeople asks if the spiderpig known as spiderham is legally allowed to say "that's all folks" after spiderham says, "that's all folks."
	Spiderman Into the Spiderverse creates plenty of diversity with its gaudy characters not only by having spiderpeople that are completely different from each other, but also by having a biracial person play Spiderman, and diversity adds tons of color. Spiderman into the Spiderverse is very different from the previous Spiderman films by being animated and this alone is very gaudy. I would love to see each spiderperson in the film of their own.   Particularly, Spidermannoir because seeing a film of his would be an authentically different Spiderman film. It would not only be animated but also in black and white, and I just may get my wish with there being talk and planning of a spinoff film. 
	Spiderman Into the Spiderverse is an animated masterpiece that is not only worth seeing, but also worth seeing more than once. I give Spiderman into the Spiderverse a 10 out of 10.

Spider-Man is a character who's story has been told many times, whether that is in live action movies, animated tv shows and even in video games, however Spider-Man: Into the Spiderverse (2018) manages to take the character(s) and create such a unique environment for it to tell its story. Not only does it take a new approach with Miles Morales being the lead, rather than Peter Parker, but it is displayed in such a beautiful way with the animation provoking a comic book style which seems plucked straight off the pages.

As directly quoted in the film, ‘you got a problem with cartoons?', Spider-Man: Into the Spiderverse (2018) proves that you don't have to be a live action movie with huge action scenes and CGI to be amongst the best super hero movies out there, as not only does this film visually stun and attract, but it also allows for some deep themes and messages. The process of becoming a hero is truly felt in this film, with some great perspectives and foreshadowing.

Spider-Man: Into the Spiderverse (2018) tells a fantastic and unique Spider-Man story which surprised many, and proved that you don't need to be a part of a huge franchise to be a success in the genre.

I think that it's impossible to not like something in Into the Spider-Verse.
Despite being touted as a Lord/Miller return project, with what seems to be little of their actual involvement, the real star is the incredible editing and overload of visual styles and the completely relatable and believable (but not forced) characterisation of mixed-race star of Miles Morales.
Into the Spider-Verse is (obviously) a hilarious, creative, exciting, surprising and engaging elseworld fusion and re-invention of Spider-Man, and while they had to go animated to give a mixed-race Spider-Man his due (and some strong, feminine, and different female characters as well), it may have completely done Morales justice. Free of the shackles of Raimi's live-action post-9/11 America-pandering version of Spider-Man, Spider-Verse is allowed to make something clever out of the whole time-paradox-rebootquel trend popularised by 2009's Star Trek - except here it's deftly handled, gentle and most of all, fun; rife for easter eggs and appropriate fan-service; I for one, actually cheered, when I saw the videogame costume in the lair, and the bubbles and comic styles all just gel.
The voice cast is superb, for this reason: they are all great actors but the characters felt entirely like characters, and unlike something from Dreamworks where the characterisations hinge entirely on you recognising the actor's star power, in Spider-Verse I never felt the need to IMDB it half way through, I just felt how real these people were. My girlfriend, at the tease of the other Spider-People, said, with a real surprise and light in her eyes: "There's a female Spider-Man??!!" and I realised that I took for granted that I already knew who Spider-Gwen was, and also how powerful it was to see her, and how little I cared whether the Spider-Person was in fact a man or not. In-fact I'd kill to see a live-action Spider-Woman film.
So this film is truly one for fans and one for noobs, and that's rare, I think my partner would have loved it even without me pointing out that I owned the Spider-Noir comic book and without pointing out that, yes, Wilson Fisk is that big in the comics (sometimes), or a myriad of little things that I don't know how I know.
More impactful than anything for me though was that the final fight, when he's all 'alone', was the most tense end fight in the usually predictable, numbing and inevitable superhero final fights. Whereas by the end of most superhero films, the hero has built himself up to win, in Verse, Miles has only just got himself ready to start, in a film that starts with the actual killing of a universe's Spider-Man, you really don't know what it can do, and with a Miles Morales who has only just found himself, and who's an actual kid instead of a thirty-something-year old actor playing a kid, it's nail-biting stuff.
I read an article about how the Spider-Man from the start is the idealised version of Spider-Man, the brand version; perfect, the whole of everything, unrealistic, unreachable. And where that Spider-Man could do it all, it takes the team of Spider-People from different universes, each with their different skills to come together and support each other. More pointedly, The Peter B Parker (B for Ben?) is the hero we can be, he's flawed, he has the same problems as we do, he's neither immaculate, nor immune to the trappings of life, he's the flawed hero, and he's from the main Marvel universe. 'Our' universe. I think that's quite powerful, and certainly a bold decision and one we may never see in a Spider-Man film ever again.

'Spiderman Into The Spiderverse' (2018)
Like the majority of movie viewers, I too thought 'Spiderman Into The Spiderverse was great. I recall when first seeing the trailer, I really didn't know what to expect, nor did I expect it to be as good as it was. With the absurdity of the plot and eccentricity of the animation-style, akin to classic comics as if they were jumping right out of the book at you, this was a risky film for Sony to put out in my opinion, and they lucked out big-time. It only seemed like the logical conclusion to come to in terms of the over saturation of the genre and abundance of Spiderman films we've seen the industry pump out to this day, so why not throw a multitude of different Spider-men and women on the screen at once for a surprisingly good time and embrace the nature of what superhero films have become? Not only is it a great superhero film, but it's a fantastic comedy, with even hints of drama woven into the plot. Also, all of the voice-acting in the film is perfect, (however I did find Kingpin's voice to be a bit too exaggerated and over-the-top) and the fact that they got Nicholas Cage, arguably one of my favorite actors (for reasons better or worse), that really leans the movie in my favor... Overall it's a great family film and action/comedy which I'm glad to own on blu-ray. I think it will easily go down as one of the best Spiderman iterations we've seen thus far.

My Rating - 8/10

One of my new favorite movies! 

I really appreciated how the creators of this movie worked to make it approachable for wide audiences- I'm pretty unfamiliar with the Spider-Man universe, and this movie welcomed me in. And watching this movie, even if you're not a "comic-book person," is an experience. Watching this whole movie feels as though you've stepped into a comic book. The text (in thought boxes and in the backgrounds), the half-tone shading, motion lines, bright colors and lighting, foreshortening and action poses- it's all done so purposefully. The whole thing feels like a piece of art. It's done in such a smooth and natural way that I didn't question it after maybe 10 minutes, but I was still aware enough of it that it would catch my eye with some really stunning details- glass shards sticking to Miles' fingertips, the afterimage within bright flashes, the color contrasts in the super collider. This movie is an absolute visual DELIGHT.

In terms of the story, there's some really strong character building and relationships, even with a line of humor running throughout. Miles starts as an awkward teenager who acts as though he's got everything together around his old friends, but feels he doesn't fit in- a struggle that follows him through the movie. At the end, he's settled into his new identity much more, but realizes he's still new and has a lot to keep learning. He and his father and his uncle all have shifting relationships of misunderstandings and support and forgiveness, which eventually (mostly) resolves. Gwen and Peter B. don't open up entirely with Miles, but are able to take the next step in their lives after meeting him. And that's another thing I appreciated: all of the "Spider-sonas" are human (well, except for Spider-Ham, of course!). Miles is awkward, Gwen and Peter B. are closed off and insecure, and the others have their own quirks and unfamiliarity with Miles' world. It really feels as though "anyone can wear the mask."

A few hesitations:
Kingpin as a villain didn't sell his painful backstory quite so much as other villains I've seen in superhero-style movies—take Disney's Big Hero 6, for instance, where the villain's agenda is similar. (BH6 spoiler ahead) Both Kingpin and the villain of Big Hero 6 are trying to bring back family members they've lost. This might be because of the Disney movie's plot- they show them as a more sympathetic character, and get the audience to like them before making the villain reveal. Still, Kingpin is a (brutally!) powerful villain who poses a very real threat, and his larger-than-life design and acting set him solidly in the comic-book world of Miles' Brooklyn. And after watching a few times, his backstory is a clever parallel to Miles' devotion to his family and his greater sense of "home" …and this goes farther in humanizing Kingpin. 

I could also see how the soundtrack might be off-putting to some audiences, and it's not music that I typically listen to. Still, I didn't mind it, as it just suits Miles' character so well. And the little touches of him singing along or of Peni Parker working determinedly to the beat of the background music physically place the soundtrack in the movie's world. There's also plenty of instrumental heroic music blended in to add that inspirational tone that we love in superhero movies. 

Overall, it's a wild kaleidoscopic ride through gleefully gorgeous visuals, strong characters, a twist on superhero music, exciting action, and a new and exciting Spider-Verse. Stop reading this long review, and go watch it!

Practically no flaws. The story feels genuine and the situations are relatable. The unique animation style also keeps it interesting for those who don't like this kind of movie. Everyone except Miles' mom gets impeccable character development and a fleshed out personality. The Kingpin is also a great villain, and he's made very intimidating by the fact that he has so many powerful sidekicks not even as strong as him. He feels justified in his actions in some ways. The loss he felt has crippled him, this makes him feel genuine and relatable. The comedy is well done and keeps it constantly interesting. The emotional feats this movie pulled off are absolutely stunning.  The ending is epic and feels earned. 10/10, one of the five best animated movies ever until this point.

As it stands, Spider-man: Into the Spider-Verse is arguably the best Spider-man film of all time. An original story that made a compelling case for the protagonist, who might not have been as well-received in the comics.

The film has made incredible technical achievements that fit in with the "comic" appearance, at times messing with the frames in order to give it the "comic coming to life" type of feel. It even implements frames into storytelling!

The soundtrack sets the tone from the get-go allowing the viewer to know the characters on screen and even feel what they feel in moments of high emotion.

Combining technical achievement and a fresh take on Spiderman, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse was one of the best films of 2018.

Where do i start, Spider-Man: Into the Spiderverse is a animated action, thriller staring Shameik Moore which follows the story of miles morales, a boy who is destine to be one of the many spidermen. This movie has everything, a solid soundtrack, a talented cast, Incredible animation (well get back to that later), and an inspirational storyline. The film is based on brooklyn new york were are main character miles is trying to get out of his new school, were he has trouble fitting in, when he sneaks out one night to see his uncle eric he is bit by a radioactive spider and gains powers, shortly after finding out he has powers, he gets to meet peter parker who shortly after, is killed by the main protagonist king pin who brings in different spider men from different dimensions which leads to a peter parker from a different dimension teaching him to be spiderman. This movies storyline is inspirational at its core, and will genuinely make you feel like you are spiderman. in addition this movies soundtrack is insanely incredible, each song fits a different vibe, and its truly a trip listening to it. Finally watching this movie is like reading a comic, the onomatopoeias pop up, the characters all look hand drawn from start, and the scenes of the city are colorful and a key part of animation history. overall this movie is a banger 10/10 easily, and my favorite movie of 2018

What a fun experience! As a huge fan of Spider-Man, I was floored by the amount of time and dedication that went into making this the ultimate Spider-Man tribute film. It had plenty of fan service, humor, emotion, and action to go around. The animation style was stunning and a refreshing change of pace from the typical Disney/Pixar formula. The Easter Eggs are practically limitless and leave room for an infinite number of re-watches. However... I felt the movie lacked a truly compelling villain, as we had all become accustomed to in Spider-Man films of the past. Kingpin's motivations were present but his charisma lacked in a big way. It's understandable given the sheer amount of characters introduced in the film, but was a bit of a letdown. I may be biased, but Kingpin is not a great Spider-Man villain and is better left duking it out with Daredevil in Hell's Kitchen. Overall, it was a great movie that deserves its Oscar and the heaps of praise it received.

I finally got around to seeing this and can now confirm that all the positive buzz about this movie is totally justified. It's kind of a bizarre story, but this movie is relevant in a way that nearly all animated movies are not. From the characterizations to the music to the animation style, this movie is fun and youthful and incredibly creative. Everything about it feels fresh and new. If this is the new wave of animation, I'm all in. The premise is that there are multiple parallel universes and a Spider-entity exists in all of them. Plot happens and the universes collide, bringing 6 versions of Spider-Man (some female, one not even human) into the same universe… or "Spider-Verse", if you will. It's a modern concept for a modern movie. Add to that the innovative animation style, and you have a real winner on your hands…literally - this movie actually beat Pixar for Best Animated Film at the Oscars this year, and I say Hallelujah to that. The movie honors and stays true to its comic-book roots, it's a literal translation of a comic into a live-action film, complete with thought bubbles, narration boxes and on-screen sound effects (blam!). I can see why comic fans were creaming their jeans over this movie… and though it's a comic-book movie for comic-book fans, you don't have to be a fan of comics or even know any of the story or characters to enjoy it. At its heart, this is a coming-of-age story for new character and Spider-Person to be Miles Morales, and his story is told with an authenticity that makes you really believe the character. The writing is intelligent and funny, and peppered with just enough clever meta references to throw fans a bone without being overkill. Then there is the fantastic voice-work! I was especially impressed with Jake Johnson as the older, busted version of Spider-Man, his dry wit is absolutely perfect for the character. My only complaint is that it is a bit too long; two full hours is a bit much for an animated film and it tends to drag, and I got a little bored at times. But that's a small price to pay for such a pioneering piece of work, the raw ingenuity of the film more than makes up for its erratic pacing. This is the kind of movie that a bunch of super nerdy and creative college kids would make in their spare time if they had unlimited funds (and at least a few of them were high). Which, in a way, I guess that's exactly what it is. The film was created by Phil Lord and Chris Miller, the geniui behind "The LEGO Movie", and these two dudes have their finger on the pulse of the cultural zeitgeist more than any other filmmakers working today… which I think is why this film feels more significant than your standard animated kids' flick. If you like animated films, comics, or just enjoy watching something different than you've seen before, definitely make this one a priority to see. And don't forget to watch the post credits scene! It's awesome.

If you'd have told me Into the Spider-Verse would end up being one of my favourite Spider-Man movies there's a good chance I'd have peed my pants from laughing so hard. The trailers did nothing to spark my interest, and even after the great word-of-mouth I still expected something average. Well, not only is this one of the best Spider-Man movies ever, it's one of the best superhero movies ever. It gets so much right and completely understands the character of Spider-Man better than any of the other films. It's original, surprising, funny, and delivers some genuine heart and emotion. The fact they were able to pull this off within a story that's more than a little unorthodox, and just downright weird at times, is an impressive accomplishment. It turns the relatively unknown Miles Morales into one of the most exciting new heroes in the Marvel universe, and also happens to be one of the most visually stunning, and unique, animated films I've ever seen. I don't think anyone expected Into the Spider-Verse to be quite this good, but it's nice to still be surprised by a genre that gets extremely repetitive and predictable at times. If you've been avoiding the movie because it's animated or you think it's for kids, big mistake. Into the Spider-Verse is all-around terrific filmmaking, and deserves everyones attention.

The Movie, "Spider-man Into the Spider-Verse", was released in December 2018. Directed by Peter Ramsey, Bob Persichetti, and Rodney Rothman. The movie went on to receive 7 awards for Academy Award for Best Animated Feature Film, Hugo Award for Best Dramatic Presentation, Golden Globe Award for Best Animated Feature Film, BAFTA Award for Best Animated Film, Critics' Choice Movie Award for Best Animated Feature, PGA Producer of the Year Award in Animated Theatrical Motion Pictures, and the New York Film Critics Circle Award for Best Animated Film.

Spider-man Into the Spider-Verse was a very good eye opener from its art style itself. They way they fit this cartoon comic book type of feel into the basic movie is phenomenal. The main characters help give it a more child friendly vibe, but adults should still enjoy the movie through its compelling back story. From the multiple characters this movie won't have a problem keeping anyone's attention. The action never stops but still leaves enough time for story. 

The movie starts off with a slow story, but as the movie progresses it hits you with the main plot. The movie has very little slow moments, but when it does its mainly for suspense moments. The movie doesn't have many moments you can describe without giving away the movie. Even though the movie has a lot of important moments there are still a few moments kids and adults can relate to.  

I think this would be a great movie to watch no matter what age you are. The movie shouldn't be limited to kids as it still has adult-ish humor. The action plus the intriguing story should keep anyone's attention. People who don't like or enjoy super hero movies will definingly not like this movie. It leans more towards the super-hero persona then anything else, but the occasional comedy will help. So, if you are into super heroes this movie is for you.

I had high expectations for "Spider-Man:  Into the Spiderverse" when I started watching it mainly due to its high Tomatometer rating.  When it was over, I can't say the movie was terrible, but I was not impressed.  The movie is very well made.  The animation is quite good.  However I felt the main story line was old and tired.  One positive thing you can say is the movie does a good job showing the dark side of being a superhero when Peter Parker is killed.  However that is nothing we have not seen before.  The movies "Kick Ass" and "Hancock" have covered this territory.  Also the character of Kingpin is very poorly drawn.  All the time I was on screen I kept asking myself why his head was in the middle of his chest.  Also multiverses and time travel are also two plot devices that have been stretched to the limit an infinite number of times.  While "Spider-Man:  Into the Spiderverse" is not terrible by any means, it is in my opinion highly overrated.

I love this movie so much, in fact, it is my favorite movie of 2018. It is jam packed full of amazing art and music, and the story is perfect for Miles Morales' origin. First off, the animation style is incredible, it really blew me away and made it look like an actual comic book. The Sunflower song is very enjoyable and catchy, but it is just a bit underutilized in the film. Shameik Moore killed it in this movie with some great voice work, he was a very convincing teenager who was trying to deal with his new found powers. Jake Johnson was my personal favorite, he brought the veteran presence and leadership that Miles needed, he has a really good voice that fits perfectly with a middle aged man. Everybody else including Mahershala Ali, Hailee Steinfeld, Brian Tyree Henry, Kathryn Hahn, Liev Schreiber, Chris Pine, and Nicholas Cage all were really good as well. The only things that I didn't really like were just a couple of the characters, Aunt May and Spider-Ham. May was in the film for maybe 10 minutes, but she was bland and cliche, she didn't have any depth in this movie at all, and Spider-Ham was just silly, I get that he's a cartoon, but he doesn't contribute really anything to the story accept for a few jokes which all fell flat. Kingpin was done well, and I liked the female Dock Ock. All in all, this is a very fun and entertaining movie with great voice work and a revolutionary new art style that I hope to see utilized more in the future, great story, great characters, go watch it. This is a must see for spider-man fans, comic book fans, and for anyone who likes to watch good movies.

Spider-Man: Into the Spiderverse RATING: 4.4/5 This movie puts the last 10 years of Disney animated features to absolute shame. It's crazy how overly stylized this movie is, it really just oozes creativity. The offbeat frame rate is a stylistic choice that really helps sell the fact that you're watching a comic book movie, and it doesn't take long to get used to it either IMO. I saw it in IMAX 3D and at first I thought there was something wrong with the film quality but it turns out it's actually all colored like a classic comic, dots and everything. The movie does move kinda fast but it does take the time to explain all the different Spider-Man characters you're seeing. Interestingly enough, it brings up how long each different Spider-Man character has been doing the superhero thing too. By doing that, you get to see the difference between a character who just got their powers and doesn't know how to use them, versus one who's been doing it for years, or decades, and is a veteran who's seen it all. It's a great contrast, with my favorite being the older, very jaded, Peter Parker that they show in the trailers. He's been around the block so many times that he knows villain plots by heart, so he's very nonchalant about everything. It's a pretty fresh, and funny, take on the character. The star here is Miles Morales, of course, and I have to say he's handled quite well, even his family. If I had to say anything negative about the film, it's that not every character gets used to their full potential. There came a point where I just noticed there were a lot of spider people fighting villains that hadn't really been fleshed out at all. The film could have probably used another 10 to 15 minutes just to doll out some basic characterization to some of the villains, and even some of the spider characters. The spiders all have their own personal issues, but the only one that really gets addressed is the older Peter Parker. Something even happens late in the film that is presented in such a way that it implies something significant just happened. However, the ground work is never properly laid for it to mean anything to the audience, so the moment just kind of awkwardly lingers. Outside those minor complaints, this is definitely a good, you could even argue great, movie that deserves to be seen on the big screen. There's a level of craftsmanship and creativity here that you just don't see in movies in general anymore. The film has a lot of heart, you can tell the creators really cared about what they were making here, and it wasn't just a cash grab. Be warned, you may get hit with some emotional moments in this film, even Stan Lee's cameo was sad, despite it being funny as well. The film has a very positive message about being good and doing good that I think the world needs to hear more of these days. Definitely one of the best films of the year. Oh yeah, and stay until after the credits. There's a pretty clever Spider-Man joke at the very end.

The opening started  "glitching" and I knew I would love this movie. I was proven right from beginning to end. The use of music and color was magical. Being a comic book brought to life, Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse (ITSV) is a unique experience, consisting of a variety of unique and relatable Spider People, multiple villains, great pacing, great dialogue, great character arcs, and spectacular visual effects. Unlike previous Spider-Man films, ITSV is able to handle multiple villains well, especially the Kingpin. The unique animation style is bold, in your face, and an incredible risk on Sony's part, but it pays off, as it resulted in one of the most memorable and amazing films (animated and in general) of the past decade. After seeing this film, I'm left wanting even more. This is the perfect Spider-Man film.

The interactions between Miles and his dad are insightful, and there's unexpected depth to the interactions between the ‘Spider-People'. Funny, fun, and visually amazing, it doesn't get much better than this.

Closest comparison: It's like Spider-Man: Homecoming meets The Lego Movie.

I've found that most of the reviews here have been absolutes, so let me give you an actual review:
-The animation style may be incredible and groundbreaking, but it gets in the way of many scenes (typically action ones) and makes everything very blurry and hard to follow.
-The plot is incredible, however all the Spidermen were generic stereotypes except Gwen, Miles, and Peter. Although Peter is just barely anything more than the washed-up celebrity stereotype and mostly just made fat jokes. Gwen seemed very Mary Sue-esque.
-The invisibility power Miles has closely resembles a McGuffin due to how no other Spiderman has ever had anything but web-slinging and suddenly the new one just HAS invisibility.
A good movie, however not without flaws.

Spider-Man into the spider-verse may be the best superhero movie ever made and is undoubtedly the best Spider-Man movie. From the captivating story and the outstanding performance from the voice cast to the stunning details and unique aesthetic that words cannot give justice too, Following Miles morales (Shameik Moore) as his journey to become the new Spider-Man, Wilson Fisk as the kingpin (Liev schreiber) collides the universes of Gwen Stacy's spider-woman, (Hailee Steinfeld) Peter B Parker, (Jake Johnson) Spider-Man noire, (Nicolas cage) Peni Parker (Kimiko Glenn) and last but not least Peter porker (John Mulaney) unite forces to stop the destruction of their respected universes. Spider-Man into the spider-verse is an awe-inspiring movie that swings the viewer into the action with a modern soundtrack and surprisingly funny scenes throughout. All in all this movie is a must see and is a standout example of how risk taking can pay off when those working have faith in their movie, show this movie to your kids, your friends, anyone considered a fan of animation or film as Spider-Man into the spider-verse is a must see.

I am a huge superhero fan, but this.....this was awful.  I'm just at a loss at the reviews that this movie has gotten, from both critics and audience.  I can often read reviews and side with the audience.....but not in this case.  All I could think during the entire movie (that I watched with my son that likes this movie) was "this is so dumb".  Maybe I can blame it on the headache I had from watching this extremely poor choice of animation styles.  No....that's not it.....it was just dumb.  The plot wasn't good, the choices for the "other" spider-men were just horrible, and don't get me started on the animation.  I know they probably thought they were being very clever with the animation, but in my opinion.....it did not work and was just an absolute, horrid mess.  Such a mess that at the climactic ending, you couldn't even make sense of what was happening.  It was an assault on the senses.  I have never before been so baffled by reading some of the rave reviews.  "The best movie ever".....Really??????  "A work of art"......Really????  What kind of movies have you all been watching??  Everyone is entitled to their opinion, and I'm obviously in the minority on mine....but I will proudly tell you that this movie was terrible.  It's on you if you want to waste 2 hours of your life and some ibuprofen.

I watched the Alternate Universe Cut & boy was I delighted to have spent the extra 40 minutes on such an amazing piece of art.

	This is my first time watching the movie so this version to me is indeed very complete. Most of the added scenes are undone, either in comic-looking sketches or basic animation.

	Seeing so many different versions of "Spidermen" working so well together in this brilliant animation made me really wish for a live-action multi-verse Spidermen featuring Tobey Maguire, Andrew Garfield & Tom Holland to become a reality!

	In the credits, I spotted some VO cast that I know, namely Hailee Steinfeld, Mahershala Ali, Zoe Kravitz, Nicolas Cage, Chris Pine, Oscar Isaac & Greta Lee.

	Also, there's the Stan Lee quote, "That person who helps others simply because it should or must be done, & because it is the right thing to do, is indeed without a doubt, a real superhero."

	Lastly, to quote Lord Tih Liang, "the theatrical version was superb too...everything about the film screams passion and creativity". I truly agree to his words.

The film was a unique take on the Spider-Man universe and was refreshing in a world where we have Spider-Man 1-3 and the two Amazing Spider-Man's. This outshines all 5 of those movies and is just as good as the new Tom Holland Spider-Man films. The animation style was great and unusual, taking elements from comic books and implementing them into a movie. They use chromatic aberration to show focus rather than blurring which looks really good and the change the frame rate depending on a character's confidence and skill. These techniques and some others create a really cool effect that may now be visible to the eye, but does influence what is perceived subconsciously. The art choice is breath of fresh air from the usual 3D animation styles. Having multiple Spider-People is also great and shows a bunch of different personalities. Each one is unique and likable. My only complaint is that after 3 viewings, it does get a bit repetitive. There are movies that can be watched 10+ times and I'm not sure this is one of them. It is still enjoyable after watching three times, it just isn't as great as the first few times

This is truly something spectacular. What especially struck out for me was the animation, which was truly beautiful and unique. I was never that fond of Spider-man but after Tom Holland's MCU-Spider-man films and Spider-verse it has become absolutely my favourite superhero and maybe even my favourite franchise.

Unfortunately, I'm not a fan of superhero movies, and thus the story never really felt like my kind of thing. I thought it was exciting that we went on a journey with a kid who doesn't magically master his powers at first, but I thought how he did end up realizing his capabilities felt very cliched, ending with the magical must-win battle for Mr Spiderman so that Spiderman films will continue to be made and studios will continue to make money off them. I also thought the father-son dynamic had potential, but for me could have been explored further. There's no arguing, however, with how mesmerizingly good the animation is, providing the film with an explosive fast-paced style that is fresh and engaging, ensuring I got to the end, even if the story was dipping a little.

Visually stunning with a pretty good plot. The visuals set a precedent for what animated superhero movies can and should be. The writing is solid, though corny at times (though this is to be expected for a kids movie). The humor is very Marvel-esque-- it does a good job of ironically downplaying the stakes. And like the live action Marvel movies, it uses dialogue that tries very hard to make characters seem 'regular' and 'likable.' It is formulaic and takes very little creative power, but it has worked for Disney's Marvel Universe, and this movie has a lot of plot points to get through, so it is understandable that the writers established character likability as easily as possible. There are emotional interactions at points in the movie, particularly with Miles's father, which don't make much sense. They seem like they are shoved in for dramatic effect rather than the natural progression of character arch. But that's enough complaining. After all, this movie seriously exceeded my expectations. All of the Spider-Man variations, particularly Peter B. Parker and Nic Cage's Spider Man, are engaging and provide some very funny moments. Overall, kids and parents alike will be entertained by the story and dazzled by the animation.

What's impressive about Spiderman: Into the Spiderverse is that it pulls together so many things and makes most of, if not all of them work to an impossibly good degree. This is a boundary-pushing animation masterpiece with bold ideas, great music, and a mature script.
I knew it was going to be good and it still managed to exceed expectations.

This is by far the best Spider-Man movie of all of them. The art style is so incredibly unique in how it utilizes aspects from comic books. Not only that but the entire film is dotted in most scenes or textured in other ways akin to the tv show Chowder. The next thing you notice in this movie is the sound, more specifically, the music. The music is amazing and perfectly fits every scene throughout. Not only that but the fact that so much of the music is Post Malone fits perfectly with Miles Morales' life and character within the film. It also creates a very modern feeling that other movies lack. The level of absurdity is great and totally works with the animation and plot. This even allows for some great humor moments. Even throughout the absurdity and fast-paced animation style, the movie still manages to hold onto a meaningful and well thought out spiderman origin story with amazing characters that are incredibly well developed. Even the villain has a good motive with an extreme plan fueled by emotion, a good trope in any movie really. Lastly I will address the thing that most people talk about, a black Spider-Man. I will say that unlike other movies, this movie does diversity right. Miles' culture and heritage does play a role in the movie and is clearly visible to the audience, however, nothing about the plot revolves around his race and culture. He's not ‘black Spider-Man' but he is Miles Morales, a character that proves to the world that anyone can be a hero with enough determination.

Add to that the superb directing, great voice-acting and a banging soundtrack that fits perfectly with everything else that's going on, and it's so very easy to see why this blew everyone away. I don't think it's an exaggeration to say that this film just single-handedly raised the bar for the animated superhero genre. Check it, you won't regret it.

Miles Morales, a teenager from Brooklyn is bitten by a spider while out showing off his graffiti skills with his uncle.  He soon develops powers similar to those of iconic superhero Spiderman but surely there can't be more than one Spiderman? We soon discover Wilson Fisk / Kingpin has been fiddling with an inter-dimensional weapon that has brought various incarnations of Spiderman from past, present, future and the bizarre all together in one space to fight the big bad and help Miles realise his destiny. 
I don't usually follow the animated films from the comic books but this one received so much positive attention, including an Oscar that I had to see it for myself.  I have to say I thought it was brilliant.  There is a fun, action packed story with an animated style that I have never really seen before, visually it looked amazing. The story pays tribute to the comics, there is a cameo from the legendary Stan Lee and there are little in jokes that reference Spiderman's previous onscreen adventures. Overall it was a very fun movie to see, the kind of Spiderman story I have been waiting for.
