Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is bright, bold, and full of heart. The film shows how rich the world of Marvel is in source material. The animation at times looks revolutionary, and at other points, it looks spazzy and straining. Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse is a rollicking watch but it does have a few flaws.

The Good:

+ The film ties neatly with both the earlier Spider-Man movies and the world of comic books – it has fun with its roots in ways most superhero films do not have. 
+ Quirky and colourful animation; both a tribute to comic books and refreshingly different.
+ The core of the story is exactly what you would expect from a Spidey story: a teenage drama and a story about growing up and finding yourself.
+ The entire world feels realistic and the characters are highly relatable. In many ways, Into the Spiderverse is more down to earth than previous Spidey films. 
+ Its visual style, storytelling techniques and flow bear close resemblance to comic books.
+ You will fall in love with the tried and tested Spidey origin story all over again.
+ Into the Spiderverse plays around with layers and angles in ways that are surprising for an animated feature.
+ The animation is so slick at times, that it feels almost photorealistic.
+ The actions scenes are huge, bold and inventive.
+ Miles' road to becoming Spider-Man is wonderful to watch – the problems, challenges and stakes feel realistic.
+ Nice to see the film populated by alternative versions of the character.
+ The script teaches its viewers many important things and has real depth.

The Bad:

- The livid action scenes are also a major weakness, since they tend to turn into a mesh of colour more akin of a messy LSD trip than enjoyable action.
- Unfortunately, the movie often falls into the category of childish goofiness that is so common with animated films. The goofiness in most of its physical comedy might not suit all adult audiences. 
- The trippy visuals and over the top action turn the movie into a hectic and childish affair.
- Mostly boring villains (apart from the reimagined Doc Oc): Kingpin just hangs around for the duration of the film and the Scorpion is just a mindless beast.
- The alternative versions of Spidey really have no real place in the story, except for Hobo Spidey, and feel more like unnecessary fan service.

Verdict:
It does a lot of things right and reinvigorates a character who has been through most on the big screen already – but it is just too much of the good thing to truly be enjoyable.

Spider-Verse has proven that there is more to tell, with a refreshed slider man featuring miles morales. 
The movie was made to feel like out of a comic book, but what it actually does it makes feel immersed into the story, planting a subtle awe of interest never seen in such a movie.
Another problem the movie fixes is its use of underrated supporting characters like tombstone and prowler. A common problem in movies is that a poor use of its characters to make it feel tied in with the main story or making them feel like an afterthought. Every character however is used correctly, from the various spider- men to the kingpin's goons,
But what stands out is Kingpin's renewed humanity where driven to evil only so restore his family.
Miles's leap of faith is the greatest spinexhiller as he embraces his power to become the true spider man of his universe and ultimately suck it up to face his challenges: helping the Spider-Man and defeating kingpin.

My 9-year-old brother has always been a fan of Spider-Man and superheroes in general. So when he was dying to see this movie, I was initially really skeptical about watching it. Animated superhero movies always seemed super cheesy to me. I will choose live action heroes and the MCU every time. 
But this movie caught me completely off guard. Because I'm only 14, I know that I didn't get every Spider-Man joke that was in there; those are the older references my dad would get. Despite that, I absolutely loved this movie. It made you, laugh, cheer, and cry at the same time. The characters were well written, and you felt like you understood them and the trials they were going through. There were some dark themes, and the writers were willing to make bold choices about the story. At the same time, the movie had the tone and feel of a kid's superhero movie. On paper, that shouldn't work, but Sony did something right, something that all studios should strive for in their movies.
I had some minor nitpicks about the plot, but that's about all I can complain about. This is a must-watch for kids and adults of all ages.

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-verse is an amalgam of good animation, comedy and emotions beautifully delivered with the power of friendship and togetherness being superior to everything else.
The movie has a simple story line where multiple, parallel universes collide and the writers take good use of this by writing enthralling character arcs which give out a simple message, ‘That person who helps others simply because it should or must be done, and because it is the right thing to do, is indeed without a doubt, a real superhero.'
The great aspect of this film is how it builds an emotional relationship with very less screen time. For example, the protagonist Miles and his Uncle Aaron hardly share a few scenes together yet one can understand the emotions they share for each other with just a single scene. So is the relationship of Peni Parker and her father, they don't even talk to each other but still, the emotions are justified.
The actions scenes were amazingly well done. The finale was great and a sequel is undeniable.

Spider-man Into the Spider-verse is a film for everyone.  Or, rather, those who don't get epilepsy.   It has a fantastic equilibrium between being a blockbuster film & staying true to the comics.  Featuring prodigious voice-acting & comedy, it also makes fun of the Tobey Maguire films!  The hand-drawn 2D animation is breathtaking. The artist animated different characters on different frame rates.  This is what gives it the fast-movie slideshow look (Kind of like a stop motion movie).  The only downside was Stan Lee wasn't here to see it.  Spider-Man Into the Spiderverse is one of the best superhero films ever made & easily the best spider-man film.  A must see for any spider-man fan or moviegoers in general.  Fantastic!  Amazing! Incredible!  Invincible!

I, like most people, made many mistakes throughout the year of 2018. One of the biggest ones was not watching Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse, because as I recently found out, this movie is not only the best animated movie of its year, but also one of it's best movies period.
Let's start with the animation, because it was groundbreaking. Watching this movie was like opening a comic book, and being pulled into it. The text boxes and action words popping out were great homages, but the feeling of a comic extends pass that. The Prowler chase down scene, first on foot then on a bike, Peter Parker's plant to break into Alchemax, and the introduction of the other Spidermans feel ripped straight out the pages, but imbued with the pacing, delivery, and animation of a well-executed movie. All of this would be enough to insure the movie was very good, but it gets even better, the fight-scenes are incredible, doing justice to each of it's fighters, without losing sight of the conflict's scope.
Finally, we couldn't talk about the animation without mentioning the color palate of the movie. The warm of Mile's home and family, the dull greys of his school, the terrifying contrast of the Prowler's dark purple and energy blasts, and the pulsating awesomeness of the fights at the collide, colors in this film seem to perfectly fit the scene, and the characters in them.
On top of that the pacing of the story is near perfect, as it balances jokes, exposition, the aforementioned action sequences, and character growth with effortless grace. The numerous plot twists and character reveals (The Prowler, Doc Oc, the Other Spider-men) in this story were really set up well. Kingpin is a great villain, stuck in the relatable rut of trying to turn back time to avoid the horrible consequences of his past, but at the same time, his introduction, in which he kills the original Peter Parker, shows he is a man past redemption. All of the side characters bring the quirky humor, (Spider-Man Noir and the Rubix Cube, Spider-Ham with his Looney Tunes) antics and emotional depth (The destruction of Peni Parker's father's machine and Gwen's backstory) that has made Spider-Man stories so universally beloved.
Obviously, the most important part of this movie, is the character it centers around, Miles Morales, a teenager who is teenager trying to figure out his identity and his place in the world. When Miles first came onto the comic book scene as a half-black, half-latinx Spider-Man, there was the usual outrage of forced diversity, and while all of that has faded away to be replaced with near universal acclimation, one of the best things this movie does is avoid shoving diversity down our throat, while at the same time making it clear that Miles is a character informed by his race and heritage. From the obvious, shallow features, such as his graffiti and the Biggie song that plays in the background as he runs through the city, to the more subtler, deeper elements, such as his confusion as to why his parents choose to stay in Brooklyn, his discomfort in the elite, preppy boarding school he tested into, and his preference of his cool uncle, Aaron Davis who encourages him to pursue his art, to his father, Jefferson Davis, who pushes him to focus on his grades. It's also fitting that first one turns out to be the Prowler, while the latter is a cop. Ultimately, Miles steps up when he needs to, and learns to control his power and be a hero, while finding a way to balance the two conflicting parts of his life.
This story, at the end of the day is about growth, and where Kingpin is unable to move forward emotionally, or where Aaron learns the consequences of his life of crime in time to safe his nephew, but not in time to save his own life, Miles Morales, and the new Peter Parker, show how to learn from past mistakes, and confront their problems head on. Jefferson eases up his pressure on his son, and learns to support him in other ways. The only gripe I might have with this movie, is that while Gwen Stacy gets similar screen time as the two main Spider-Mans, she often feel relegated to third fiddle, and as such her character isn't developed out as much, but even with that, she is interesting, complex character.
In conclusion, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is a comic book brought to life, with a touching story and jaw-dropping animation. Its damn near perfect.

So when I heard Sony was doing an animated Spider-Man, good lord this is about a million miles from where I thought they would be.  By that I mean good, like, really good.  Like, maybe the best Spider-Man movie ever good?  Is that even possible?  It's weird because it even does things that were terrible mistakes in other movies and does them here in a way that works out with artistic brilliance.  For example, when Ang Lee did stylized comic panels in Hulk, it was confusing and weird.  When this movie does it, it adds to the energy and atmosphere of the film without ever interrupting the flow of the action.  How?  How did they do that?  Maybe because this whole movie is basically a comic book.  The characters look more like comic books than ever, and even the different Spider-Men have different art styles to them, and did I mention the "bing" and "pow" and "bagel" text sound effects and even thought bubbles that will appear over their heads?  This movie just oozes so much style.  And we get so many cool Spider-Men, and so many cool villains, and somehow it never feels crowded like it did in Spider-Man 3 or X3.  Again, mistakes in the past but here it works.  What the hell!  And it does all of this without missing it's emotional core.  Actually my favorite moment in the movie isn't a big action sequence, it's a small moment of all the Spider-Men sharing their experiences of loss, and experience they can all only share with each other.  It's surprisingly powerful considering one of the characters involved is a talking pig.  Really if I had a critique, it would be wanting a few more moments like this.  Also probably more of other Spider-Men, because really this story is Miles, Peter, and Gwen's story and the other three are more or less background.  I would have liked it to be more even, but that might have pushed the magic formula.  Honestly I shouldn't be complaining because that this works at all is amazing  That it's this damn good is a godamn miracle.

Into the Spider-verse is a beautifully crafted movie, which perfectly represents the sometimes surreal but always beautiful Marvel comics' style, with a great multi-media art direction. 

Into The Spider-verse mixes a great coming-of-age story with the classical, beloved superhero action of a typical Marvel movie, in a new and beautifully colored enviroment, with charismatic characters and an interesting story to unfold. 

The movie is not devoid of criticism: some characters and relationships are not developed enough (mainly the father-daughter relationship between Noir and Peni) and the movie comes a little short on pacing in certain scenes.

Overall, it's a great movie which truly deserve the title of Best Animated Feature of 2018.

This has got to be the biggest comeback for a movie studio in the history of cinema!!! Just think about the fact that a little over a year before this masterpiece was released, Sony had just put out one of the worst movies of all time, The Emoji Movie. But, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is not only Sony Animation's best movie, but it's one of, if not the best, animated films ever made. First off, let's talk about how beautiful the animation is; when I saw the teaser back in 2017, I was not a fan of the animation at first because it looked too chopped up. That was before I realized what they were going for: an animation style as that of a comic book. When I realized that, then my opinion went a full 180 and I thought that was an awesome idea, and after seeing the movie it really looks fantastic. From the text showing the characters' thoughts to the big letters popping up, whenever something exaggerated happened, was awesome. The voice talent in this movie is remarkable, especially from Shameik Moore and Jake Johnson. Everyone was great, but they were the real standouts in this movie; they were extremely funny and worked well together as Miles Morales and Peter B. Parker. And this movie, has the pure definition of storytelling; you see a full character arch for Miles, as he goes from a fish-out-of-water high schooler to the confident webslinger we know he is. Also the soundtrack for this movie is amazing (as far as I'm concerned better than the black panther soundtrack, which I also love). My only real issues with this movie are tiny nitpicks and they don't affect anything in the movie, so I can overlook them, but I'll mention them anyway. First off, I do think it was a bit on-the-nose that Sony animated their products into the movie (especially with Miles' headphones), but like I said, I can overlook that. Also, Kingpin was kinda cliched and underdeveloped, but it's ok because if they gave him a clearer backstory, this movie would've gotten bogged down in too much exposition, so I'm fine with it. To sum it all up, if Spider-Verse is Sony apologizing for making the Shit Emoji Movie, then all is forgiven.

Overly long, overly complex and stuffed to the gills with more 'special effects' than a transformer movie - rendering the whole thing a chore to sit through as an adult.  Animations were top-notch, but the color shift to simulate comic book printing was more distracting than effective.

Seemed more a 'coming of age' movie than a spider man movie (I say 'man', but the on-going cynical approach of making spider man a near pre-teen to appeal to kids is as prevalent here as in all the live action movies).  

Far too much time was spend getting to know this kid and not enough time spent on editing the main action so it was actually meaningful.  And the ridiculous idea that this kid (who has been 'spidy' for all of TWO DAYS, can defeat a villain all the other 'spidys' from all the other dimensions couldn't - and of course has more wisdom than any adult in the movie, was just a weak ploy to appeal to the children watching.

Probably great for young teens, but tougher to sit through for an adult.

Where do I begin? 
Spider-man has been my favorite superhero for as long as I can remember. I, like many others, have seen every one of his films in theaters. Some wowed me, some were ok, and then there's Spider-man 3... But this movie.... This movie blows them all out of the water. 

The voice acting was incredible, especially from our lead character, Miles Morales. It would have been easy to slack with the supporting cast, but they brought their A game as well, making for a fun batch of chemistry with all of the characters throughout the film.

The main supporting character is Peter Parker, who is my favorite web slinger (I mean, I grew up with him, what can I say?). His portrayal in this movie was different than the Parker we're all used to, but I loved what the writers did with him. It added an extra layer of humanity to him, and made his connection to Miles all the more meaningful. Spider-Gwen was, as I hoped she would be, incredible. The voice actress perfectly captured her unique personality and edge that makes her so interesting. The other characters don't get quite as much development but we get just what we need, and they're so much fun to follow. Especially Spider-Ham, who I worried would be too silly and turned out to be a perfect fit.  

The soundtrack was similar to Black Panther in that it gracefully blended hip hop, electronic, and orchestral sounds. This created a score that perfectly fit the theme of the movie, and is fun to listen to on its own. 

The action was great and exciting to watch and I loved how it all looked, which brings me to the final point. 

THE ANIMATION WAS INCREDIBLE
It was beautiful to look at, it didn't distract you from the movie, and it was a fitting theme for Miles' story. That's an important note too. This film features several web heads, but Miles always feels like the star of the show, and I feel like that could have easily failed. 

I don't know what else to say, it's fun for kids and adults, and it's easily my favorite movie of 2018 (sorry, Infinity War). 

10/10

My favorite film! I was a little nervous going into the theatre because we can all agree that they haven't done great with their Spider-Man movies and their animated movies. Come on, they somehow decided to make the Emoji Movie! And now they have squished those together. Also, I would have thought that bringing the multiverse, a very complicated and huge part of comics, to the big screen. The executed it brilliantly. Stan Lee has an actual big part of the film. He inspires Miles to buy the Spider-Man costume and says it will fit anyone. Which is an enormous nod to how Stan Lee likes his superheroes to be any diversity, sexuality, beliefs. He believed that anybody could be a hero. And I liked the memorial of not only Stan Lee but Steve Ditko as well in the credits. By the way, there is an end credit scene which left me so excited for the sequel. The animation was incredible. They used many styles of animation anime, looney tunes, noir. But the main animation they used was a comic book style animation. It was like watching a moving comic book.

Everything that Phil Lord and Christopher Miller produce is gold. They both produced the two Cloudy with a Chance Of Meatballs movies and recently The LEGO Movie 2: The Second Part. I would've preferred characters from the comics that appeared in the series like Superior Spider-Man or UK Spider-Man. But learning about these characters from the movies and in my own time, they are way more interesting. A radioactive pig who bit a spider to a girl with a telepathic connection to a spider. They had the basic characters they needed for the story like Spider-Gwen and Miles Morales. Miles and Gwen were played by Shamik Moore and Hailee Steinfeld. They had great scenes together. I fought it was brave killing off Peter. Well from Miles universe anyway. I really felt something. And they barely gave us anything about him. Everyone else's reaction I guess made the moment sympathetic. Kingpin was the main villain. Liev Schreiber isn't a brut sounding person, well in this case anyway. That's what made Kingpins like Vincent D'onofrio fantastic. And I don't recall Kingpins head being in between his nipples. But they did get his strength and size right.

I crapped myself when those jumpscares came. There weren't many. The flow of the film felt really passive and came making it super unexpected. Mahershala Ali is a fantastic actor. He was great and I am glad he played Miles Uncle also known as from the comics, the Prowler. I thought Spider-Ham was going to be over the top because he was quite silly in the trailer as well as Peni Parker. But he didn't go as over the top as I thought. I loved how they incorporated the Spidey gadgets. The soundtrack is more than incredible as well as the comedy. I feel like this film was very underrated. Watch this film now! And if this doesn't win an Oscar for best animation - Edit, they did win. Proving that this is truly a masterpiece and also destroyed Disney's big streak.

I normally could careless about a movies soundtrack, but blasting rap and hip hop ever 60 seconds doesnt interest me. In this case, yeah, im going to harp the soundtrack because youve shoved it in my face five times in ten minutes. It needs to be varied. It needs rock, it needs classical, it needs blues, it needs variety in any form. Btw, most movies go between five and ten minutes between songs, as a minimum, if youre playing the same genre every two minutes its obvious your story is weak. There again, it is weak, because you have no hook to draw the audience in beyond - once again - your annoying soundtrack. I say annoying, again, because theres no variety whatsoever and, again, its alk your listening to. Want to hear a conversation between miles and his classmate? If you can over Notorious Big. Look man, the best movies have variety, no when to keep the music down, and when to blast it. This one doesnt. Juice, with tupac, was full of rap and hip hop, but it knew when to play, and when yo let the story tell itself, so no variety, but at least it didnt shove it in your face every sixty seconds. This movie? A great score, amazing character design, and a fresh style of animation all make this one of the best animated movies I've seen in a while. And if you see the interviews or listen to the commentaries from the creators, it's clear they had a great time making this film. I think if most creators had that attitude, animated movies would be much better and a lot more creative then they have been recently. All-in-all, Spider-verse is amazing, I would recommend it to anyone who enjoys action, animation, or just good storytelling, and I think some big animation studios should learn from this wonderful example: Animation was not made to replicate real life, it was meant to create things you CAN'T make in real life! Be creative, and take some risks!

I've always been a purist. I enjoy the classic comics and their stories the most. Just how I was raised and what I grew up with. I know of the Morales storyline, just never gave it much credence. So, I was a little hesitant heading into this movie to say the least. That all aside, this little flick was a lot of fun. A fun, though not original, story leads all the various Spider characters together in a fun ride through Marvel lore. Was also very pleased with the adult overtones to the story while keeping it an animation movie for kids, which so many new cartoon movies do so well these days. In the end, while I may still believe that Peter Parker is the Spiderman, I now have a better understanding and appreciation of Morales and the other variations of Spiderman and their place in the Marvel Universe. Well done, Sony. And, of course, RIP Stan Lee. You will be missed.
A fun, entertaining movie but completely overrated and overhyped.

Animated films often have a hard time reaching the adult audience. The two best techniques to get that older audience are fast-paced references that go over younger heads and nostalgia. Spider-Verse happily hits both of those techniques in a way that really captures the comic-book sensibility.

This movie packs a lot into a small box. Honestly, the first twenty minutes are spent establishing the characters and the world. Even when the plot gets more complex, we never lose a sense of who these characters are and what their motivations are. The cast brings each and every character to life, and the story has real emotional meaning.

It definitely feels like a comic book, replete with action words and striking animation. While it captures a lot, I canâ(TM)t help but feel that this was overhyped. It sits in the same space Guardians of the Galaxy does; I think itâ(TM)s fine, but not transcendentally exquisite. Your mileage may vary.

Alternate Spider-Men from various dimensions are brought together by a selfish scheme, confusedly interact, share a few puns, trade tips and race to beat the bad guy before their respective home worlds are annihilated.

Given the steamroll of positive word-of-mouth, I had concerns about this one living up to my expectations. Instead, it smashed them to pieces. It surprises, delights, amuses and entertains right from the opening gun. A sharp, witty script manages to nail the goofy essence of the character (seen through a kaleidoscope of different lenses) without feeling forced, hokey or dated. It's effortlessly hip and tuned-in, a tale that understands what's fresh and spotlights that without exploiting it. The plot remains light-hearted and smooth, but not without trials or consequences.

And I don't think I can say nearly enough about the dynamic, electrifying visuals. They're a shot of adrenaline, consistently vibrant and dazzling, a vivid showpiece that leaps straight from page to screen without sacrificing any of the clever little quirks and format-conscious tricks that always seemed so inseparable from the printed medium. Into the Spider-Verse is the first time a big comic book adaptation has really worn those funnybook roots as a badge of honor, something to be respected and embraced, rather than an embarrassing blemish. It understands what makes a good comic tick, values those singular traits and uses them to improve the entire production. I didn't realize how much I needed something like this.
THE best, most inspirational, well-written, all-around most perfect animated movie of this year if not in well over a decade.

I just finished watching this on DVD. Maybe I should take a little time to think on it, but I'm firmly of the belief that it's the perfect comic book movie, or at least the perfect Spider-Man Comic book movie, in a more literal sense than usual. Though the story beats aren't quite as emotional as in Spider-Man 2, the action, color palette, designs, and story all serve as a love letter to the many comic book versions of the spider as well as the cinema version. Miles is a terrific protagonist, much better than the comics version, and the other spider-folks all pull their weight. If you love Spider-man, or have ever loved him, you have no excuse not to see this movie. It's fantastic in all the ways it should be and doesn't try to be more than it has ever been great at, good clean fun and action and inspiration. Maybe we all can't be Spider-man, but with a leap of faith, I don't see why we can't make the world a little better.

There is one scene in "Spiderman: Into the Spiderverse" that is one of the greatest summaries in cinematic history, one shot that takes the entire movie and shows it front to back, start to finish. It encapsulates all the emotion, all the drama, all the humanity, and tells you nothing about the film that you do not already know. It shows Spiderman 'seated' on the side of a glass skyscraper, edging his way carefully to the very top, facing downwards toward the street far below. He hesitates a long moment, then leaps out into a daring, graceful dive. In that moment, the moment he pushes away from the comparative safety of the sheer glass surface of the tower, the animators captured the entire film, if not the entire genre, because the glass breaks.

Glass is surprisingly tough stuff. Even regular glass would be difficult to break if you were pulling on it, and skyscraper glass is much stronger than regular glass. Anyone up with superhero mythology knows Spiderman can stick to walls. What this scene is telling us so brilliantly is that this new hero is resisting his new life so hard that when he finally pushes himself into it, accepting the risk and danger, that he breaks the glass, and not even in the easy way. And it tells us that even though he is so afraid of this adventure that his fear can shatter even skyscraper glass, his will and courage is stronger still, strong enough to break that glass and propel him into this fearsome future. Massively good story telling, amazing art, and a lot of heart to boot.

This indeed is one of the greatest scenes in film, and why not? The whole theme of the movie is that this man is one of the greatest, which means he is great, and there are many others who are also great. In other words, anyone can wear the mask. Anyone - a child, a stranger, a person of color, a woman - can wear the mask. You can wear the mask. And isn't that interesting?

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse (5 out of 5 stars). Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse proves that after a few times rebooting a Spider man origin story into a movie can never get old. You would think there is plenty of different Spider Man movies done so quickly within the last 15 years. Into the Spider Verse takes a different approach. Approaching the material and adapting the comic book into a movie. With colorful animation and visuals with the word effects or comic book action violence. The movie is spectacular and one of the best Spider Man movies ever. From the help of Phil Lord and Christopher Miller (the people who did the 21 Jump Street movies and Lego Movies) takes the comic book material and they bring a kinetic energy with the story. The plot follows Miles (Shameik Moore) a teenager who is forced into private school with his father being a police officer and a mother that is busy as a nurse. He gets bit by a radioactive spider. And he notices changes such as having sticky fingers and being toned out. When the Kingpin tries to turn on a particle accelerator which Peter Parker/Spider-Man fails to stop him. He asks Miles to learn to take the responsibility and stop Kingpin. Miles meets other Spider-Mans from other alternate universes such as a burnt out Peter Parker (who is out of shape, careless, and depressed looking), Spider-Ham (a talking pig), Peni Parker (a young girl with a spider robot), and Gwen Stacy (Spider girl). The film does have a lot of throwback references that brings in some easter eggs from Sam Raimi Spider man movies. The film is a lot of fun. The most fun you will ever have watching a superhero movie on the big screen. Director Bob Persichetti, Peter Ramsey, and Rodney Rothman did a fantastic job in adapting the comic book into an animated film. The animation is slick, stylized, and colorful. If you are sensitive to flashy lights and fast paced changing colors it may be a difficult film to see. The characters are a lot of fun. Miles is that type of likable character were you can try to relate too. The villain Kingpin did look a bit cheesy with having a gigantic body that seems very inhuman. But it was a lot of fun. The story and direction runs at a kinetic fast pace energy. And the action sequences are stylized and exciting. Overall, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is a great film. Definitely a recommended film if you are into comic books or superhero movies. This Spider Man is a lot of fun. It has a fast paced story, it has action, and the animation/ visuals are entertaining with a comic book brought to the big screen. The soundtrack in the film which brings in a hip hop tone works great with the movie.
simply amazing. storyline for the most part was on point! I would say 98% of the movie was great. didnt need spiderpig.

Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse is one of the most overrated comic book movies of all time. Fans have waited for a great Spider-Man film since Rami's Spider-Man 2; back in 2004. Spider-Man 3 was a massive disappointment compared to a the sequel, The Amazing Spider-Man in 2012 was pretty good, but it wasn't anything that we hadn't seen before from the beloved character, and Amazing Spider-Man 2 was god awful. Spider-Man: Homecoming was really fun and enjoyable, but that film is a mix between two companies; Columbia Pictures and Marvel Studios. Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse is the latest Spider-Man film from Sony pictures that is in association with Marvel. Into The Spider-Verse was also one of the most skeptical movies of 2018, due to the fact that every Spidey movie after Spider-Man 2 was either mediocre or just plain bad. One the film hit theaters, it recieved a huge amount of praise from both critics and audiences. People loved the directing, the writing, the animation, the emotionally relatable storylines, and the fact that this was the first Spider-Man film directly from Sony pictures that didn't suck. However, I am one out of the very few that did not care for this film. One of the few positives I have with it is that the animation is spectacular and is filled with such a creative amount of detail that you get sucked into the movie. The performances by most of the cast including Shameik Moore, Jake Johnson, and Hailee Steinfeld are great, Peter B. Parker is a scene stealer, any scenes with him and Miles together were the best. Miles Morales is an interesting character. 

Now lets get on the negatives. This movie has the potential to be outstanding and one of the best, but the aspects to Spider-Verse that destroy the potential are the subplots including plots having to do with Miles's Dad and Uncle's relationship. Those parts take you right out of the movie, and could've been handled much better. The filmmakers decision during the first act with Spider-Man was terrible and they should've treated the character with much more respect. Other Spider-people including Peni Parker, Spider-Man Noir, and Spider-Ham have no purpose to appear in this movie. Wilson Fisk is also a really bad character; which most people can agree on. I wish the film focused more on Mile's character instead of allowing screen time for five different Spider-people. If this movie were more focused on Miles, Peter Parker, Peter B. Parker, and Gwen Stacey than I would've really enjoyed it a lot.

Overall, I feel that Into The Spider-Verse could've been much, much better and hopefully the sequel will be an improvement.

What can't we say about In the Spiderverse. The characterization of all the spier-people is great, the writing is excellent, and most of all the animation is mind-blowingly impressive.

Even though they don't get a lot of time to pull everything off, the writers manage to deliver a fairly complex story within a short runtime. Miles and his family feel fleshed out, and resonated emotionally. Even Kingpin, in his small time on screen as a villain, has his actions and motivations justified in an understandable way. 

The voice actors all do superb work here, and the casting director really needs more kudos for a job well done. Even a spectacular script will fall flat is the lines are not delivered convincingly. 

The animation and art direction are some of the best, if not the best, I have ever seen. While it takes some time to get used to (I think they are shooting on 3s due to the complexity of each frame) the visual feast more than makes up for it in my opinion. You just have to see it to understand how impressive it is, and it is made all the more so if you are an artist yourself.

If you haven't seen this film yet, get out of your seat immediately and go.

Every single trailer that was released for this movie stunned me, largely due to the staggering comics-inspired visuals. But I was trying as hard as I could to lower my expectations for the movie, as I was quite possibly sure that a movie with many "spider people" in it like this would be a total mess. The reviews came out calling the movie one of, if not the greatest Spider-Man movie ever made! I was still has my same worries; but I was so glad it gained such awesome reviews, for I really had thought the movie would be a critical failure. (I mean, It's produced by Sony Pictures Animation after all!)

First things first, the eye-popping visuals I've seen a glimpse of from the trailers didn't disappoint. As a matter of fact, the animation looks even better than I expected it to be. The insanely inventive visual style of this movie is unlike any other film ever made; It's simply groundbreaking! Plus, the movie could have easily felt more self-indulgent than clever due to the eye-poppingly opulent visual style that embraces the aesthetics of its comic-book roots; but the movie's substance is as much as it's style. The action set-pieces are quite staggering and innovatively designed; those of Incredibles 2 really pale in comparison to what I found in this movie! But the quick-frame animation also does something spectacular for the action sequences. It made the action looks pretty fast and uniquely slick.

While the movie's unique aesthetic was the thing that made me interested in watching the movie in the first place; the thing that amazed me is the unorthodox and unprecedented way the movie captured the anxiety and panic of gaining superpowers and becoming a superhero. I know it seems weird and quite silly when I say that I felt that I was feeling what Miles Morales felt when he discovered that he became a superhero for the first time! The movie shows us how "With great power comes great responsibility" instead of making us hear it over and over. Of course, the visuals added a lot to this point in particular; but it's Phil Lord and Rodney Rothman's astute and extremely clever script that made Morales a fully-fledged, and quite relatable character by putting him in both internal and external conflict. Nothing feels exceptional or new in the character's arc, and you could easily sense the familiarity of the phases our protagonist go through; but the innovative storytelling that enriches the plot as well as the main character made up for that. Although they are not fully-developed and fleshed-out as much as I hoped; The other "spider people", are utilized quite well, they fit perfectly in the story, and every single one of them has their own personality, its own character, and that made each one of them adds something different to the humor of the movie, which is, by the way, quite brilliant! That's more than enough for me, especially since the overabundant storylines and characters were my biggest concerns about this movie before watching it. They could have hampered the narrative and made the movie a complete mess like I had expected; but they didn't, and everything was surprisingly cohesive.

There is no doubt that the subtle humor played an important in making the storylines feel coherent; but the unparalleled realization of the idea of... well, the parallel worlds and the multiverse is really the thing that glued all the different sub-plots and storylines together, and made what seems implausible on paper quite compelling and cogent.

The villain, Kingpin is, sadly, the worst thing in this movie. His character is underutilized, underdeveloped, and kinda dumb and stupid! It's really disappointing, as Netflix's Daredevil's Kingpin is one of my favorite comic-book villains I've ever seen being depicted on screen. Besides that I already knew his background very well, the movie did nothing but giving us every once in a while a glimpse or a peak of Kingpin's back-story, and hence his motivations, and this was very perfunctory, especially for those who introduced to this character for the first time. Adding insult to injury, the short scenes that concern Kingpin are scattered and annoyingly intrusive. The fact that Kingpin is quite brainless is totally out-of-place. I mean, the movie is way too smart and clever to have a villain like this that kept giving the protagonist enough time to defeat him until the very end!

Overall, Miles Morales has an unforgettable big-screen debut thanks to a compelling adventure story with innovative and clever storytelling, ground-breaking (and hopefully revolutionary) striking visuals and risk-taking animation style, and strong vocal performances from the entire cast. The well-deserved Oscar winner, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is hands down the best animated movie of 2018!

Well the biggest surprise of the year appears to be that the Sony Animation release where John Mulaney voices a talking pig is one of the best films of 2018!

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is an incredibly unique film showcasing fantastic animation that gives the film a look that will always be associated with this project. Introducing comic book elements into the film only to switch it up further by incorporating different animation techniques on top of each other later in the film.

As a comic book fan it is really cool to see underappreciated characters treated with such respect in a big film like this. Cage and Mulaney both do a fantastic job playing two of the more comic relief characters in the film while still managing to showcase what makes those characters interesting. This film follows the character of Miles Morales (Shameik Moore) a fan favourite but often overlooked character in the Spider-Man cannon. Despite most audiences not being familiar with the character the care and commitment to getting him right is commendable.

Really thatâ(TM)s what this film is all about, care and commitment. Sony Animations doing a Spider-Man film with bankable stars like Hailee Steinfeld and Jake Johnson was always guaranteed to make money but this film goes above and beyond to ensure that it offers a new experience.

I realise that the way Iâ(TM)m talking about this film makes it sound like an âimportantâ? film that is more art project than family fun but that could not be further from the truth. Into the Spider-Verse is hilarious. This film has a writing credit from Phil Lord one half of the team behind the Jump Street films and the Lego Movie and it shows. I canâ(TM)t remember a single joke that didnâ(TM)t land and much like with The Lego Movie even scenes that donâ(TM)t feature as many jokes are still very engaging and entertaining.

In sort: See this movie! (and stay for the end credits!)

9.5 Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse
This movie is fantastic in literally every single way. Awesome graphics. Compelling characters and great development of those characters along the way. The plot was well-done and the pacing was about spot-on. The voice acting by all involved was great, and despite being an animated film I think it gave us the most realistic look at Spider-Man we've ever seen. Miles Morales starts out as a kid trying to understand the universe, by the end he becomes a wonderful hero that is very accessible to the audience and very relatable. It just all was unbelievably great. This won the Academy Award for Best Animated Film; however, I think it should've been nominated and possibly won best Picture too. Please watch this.

I never bought a comic book in my life. That is mainly because my brothers did and got me into Marvel and DC. 

For years now we have been watching live action movies. I have to admit that I am not a huge fan of those. 

However, this one is a totally different ride. The visuals, the pace, the storytelling and the audio design. Everything in it's right place. 

For me, it is a total game changer. I truly hope they carry on with this type of animated movies and create a new Marvel Universe with this style. I would be so happy if that happened. I gotta thank my brothers that got me into this awesome world and the memories + nostalgia made me feel so good.

An animated movie with a cool concept and cool look, exceeds already high expectations. A lot of what Sony has done with Spiderman's character has been mixed reviews, mostly thumbs down. But using Miles Morales was a fresh take. Most superhero movies take forever to build up the backstory which in turn makes the movie drag on. This movie blends a cool story while telling you the story of the main character. There is an awesome mix of multiple Spiderman which gives you an amazing mix of an animation styles. The visuals are spectacular and it's a great piece of cinema that isn't hindered by being a cartoon. In an age where comic book movies are being constantly turned out Sony was able to put a new twist, while keeping true to characters that already have so much context tied into them. The soundtrack, much like the movie, exceeds expectations. It's one that you leave the theater saying you need to own so you can listen to it on repeat.

One of the best, of not the best animated movies I've ever seen because of two reasons. First the plot, the movies' plot turned out better compared to the original Ultimate Comics plot. I loved how Miles' character development wasn't rushed at all. It was more realistic for a teenager with so much in mind to have inadequacies (control of his powers) and hesitations (the leap of faith) before taking on the suit of the friendly neighborhood Spider-Man. The plot pretty much developed Miles to become the Spider-Man in the end. Second, the animation was crisp and was an eye candy throughout the movie. I can't explain more about this, but I wasn't bored in any scene which happens when I watch animated films this is because even the simplest scenes are dazzling to watch because of the innovative animations. Additionally, the movie being centered on Miles Morales as the main hero didn't really hindered on shining some light on the other spiderverses' SpiderMen. SPIDER-MAN: Into The Spider Verse... where do I begin? SERIOUSLY. WHERE DO I BEGIN? This was literally everything I wanted in a Spider-Man film. I wonâ(TM)t give too much detail about the plot, but it all revolves around Miles Morales witnessing an eye-opening change in self, acquaintances, the world and a specific âuniverseâ?. Visually, the film is like a comic book brought to life. I know thatâ(TM)s been said frequently, but thatâ(TM)s what the movie essentially is. The colors and lights really pop out, as well as the action. Every character in this film has a backstory. We understand their purpose of why they do what they do. Even with KINGPIN, the main villain. Heâ(TM)s not the most fleshed out character in the film, but we still understand him. Kingpin was my ONLY issue with the film, and itâ(TM)s very minor. Everything else was just unbelievable. The animation is EXTREMELY innovative. The creators of this film really outdid themselves here. Like I said before, the colors are really VIBRANT and the action set pieces are off the chain. Each one of the Spider-Men are so unique in their own way, and thatâ(TM)s what I think was meant to be. I love every single one of them. When it comes to character development alone, this is what I was looking in the past FANTASTIC FOUR films. Not to mention, the movie is very fast paced. It almost runs at 2 hours, but it felt like 15 minutes. Also, the soundtrack, including the score, is AMAZING. Since itâ(TM)s in NEW YORK, we get a lot great mixtures hip-hop & funk. My head nodding throughout the entire film. The humor is PERFECT. Not a lot of films have humor that land every time, but this movie has that type of humor. It was SO FUNNY. I laughed so hard during certain scenes. Lastly, the film pays very satisfying tribute to the one and only STAN LEE. His cameo that just struck me. May he Rest In Peace. "Spider-Man: Into The Spider Verse" is a progressive, bold, visionary, revisionist, emotionally inspiring, HILARIOUS, stunning, ACCURATE, and precise film that not only shows that theyâ(TM)re still can be fun comic book films, but it also shows us that anything is possible. This is ABSOLUTELY the perfect Spider-Man film & the best since Spider-Man 2.

Spider-Verse is one of the best comic book movies and THE BEST Spider-Man movie ever made. This movie is a masterpiece. Every single frame was glorious. It is the most beautifully animated film I have ever seen. Spider-Verse is so fresh and funny, and feels nothing like any comic book movie has ever done before. It really is something original and entirely new.

Spider-Verse is the closest that anyone will get to nailing the feeling of reading a comic book. Never before has the sensation of reading a comic book be so accurately portrayed in cinema. The film is filled to the brim with style. It oozes it. In terms of depth, scope, stakes and action it feels much like a high budget live action film. Even if you have seen all of the trailers, this film still has so many surprises. The trailers did not give away anything... you guys are in for a treat.

The film is ultimately a Miles Morales story, and it executes it perfectly. All of the many characters are handled and balanced to perfection, and they successfully built a whole universe within one movie while still focusing on Miles.

The references that the film makes to the other Spider-Man movies and the comics are some of the best Iâ(TM)ve seen in a movie. There is a Spider-Man 3 reference at the beginning of the film that almost had me in tears, I was laughing that hard. The Stan Lee cameo is perfect and probably the best, it rivals the Spider-Man 3 cameo, â~Nuff saidâ(TM). And whoever came up with that end credits sceneâ¦ they need a raise.

Everyone please go and see Spider-Man into the Spider-Verse, even if you aren't the biggest comic/superhero fan. There is something here for everyone. If you are a comic fan, then this is a no-brainer, YOU WILL LOVE THIS MOVIE. Please go and support it.

Sony launches another Spider-Man franchise with Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse, a fun, though bizarre, animated film.  When the nefarious crime lord Kingpin opens up a dimensional portal he accidentally transports several spider superheroes from alternative universes who then team-up to defeat him.  Unfortunately the animation style is incredibly poor; having a rotoscope type feel that often seems out of focus with a mesh filter (likely meant to resemble a newspaper comic-strip).  Also, the multiple Spider characters kind of diminish the value and importance of Spider-Man.  Still, it's interesting to see alternate universe versions of Spider-Man, and the action is pretty exciting.  Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is entertaining, but it's also a real mess that's constantly getting in its own way.

A big, sprawling Spidey adventure/origin story that's execution is beyond reproach - it's gigantic! - and that embraces, no, it chokeholds, much of the by now popular Spidey lore...except for one niggling concern: "the proportional strength of a spider". There are several Spider creatures here, all from parallel dimensions by way of explanation, but not one of them could escape a wet paper bag. Oh yeah, they shoot spider webs and they swing around an intoxicatingly beautifully rendered Big Apple landscape, but (for me) one of the most alluring aspects of the wallcrawler was that he was as strong as the most buff of Marvel's coterie of jock straps w/o looking like it, if not stronger. Cut to: the look of surprise on all of his enemies faces. "This skinny runt is kicking my ass?!?" = the charm of SpiderMan. Disappointing for that lack. But in all else this is one heck of a rollercoaster.

Great visuals--it was obviously made in 3D but it kind of "feels" like traditional animation and man I have been missing traditional animation... aside from that, The two main characters (black and red spidey) are nicely handled and likeable. I could have done without the robot and pig, though, I kind of wish it just focused on the three--but I get that this was probably a film "for the fans" and maybe people more acquainted with spiderman lore really loved those side characters?

Now I do have to admit I wasn't as sucked into this as a lot of audience members clearly were. I thought the plot was a fairly typical superhero origin story and without any twists or turns you're largely just waiting for things to come to the conclusion you expect. But even if the film kind of ran out of steam for me near the end the beginning parts were SOLID. I liked the establishment of Black spiderman's character, I liked seeing his interactions with his family and school and stuff--even up to the point where he's stealing the Goober with red spidey is darn solid, the banter and antics in those scenes were great!

...Actually, the more I think about it the film really only started to slow down and get bloated once the pig and robot were added. That may just be coincidence of them arriving during "plot wrapup time," but I supposed it reiterates my point that I found them distracting from the character arcs that had been set up thus far. It really took time away from arcs that I had been invested in.

But even if the stereotypical plot and bloated number of characters was a bit of a letdown I can't let the score lower TOO much for the ingenuity of the visuals alone. I hope we see more films looking like this in the future.
Absolutely loved the style of this movie. Totally enjoyed every minute.

The best spiderman movie ever made, my personal favorite superhero movie to date, and its in my top three animated movies of all time. Im a big fan of spiderman but my opinion on the movies is that majority of them fall somewhere between 1-3 and a half stars, but this movie shattered every assumption I had about it and surprised me at every turn. This movie has something for everyone, its probably the most interesting and beautiful animation style Ive ever seen, every scene pops and rings out with beauty. It has amazing writing and characterization, and not a single joke falls flat. Ive seen it three times in the theaters and I cant recall ever enjoying a movie so much I saw it In theaters more than twice. It really is a movie for everyone, beautiful visuals, amazing writing, an inspirational story, great soundtrack, hilarious jokes, a few sad moments that will stick with you afterwards. You can feel the love for this character in every frame and every line of dialogue. The fact that Sony made this movie shocks me because most other spidey themed movies made by them fell flat, it honestly makes me confused how they can go from the painfully dull venom movie to making this flawless animated spiderman movie. I really hope they do something else with these characters and the universe they established in this movie, itd be 100% more interesting than a few spiderman solo movies based around the venom movie. Cant recommend enough

Following the passing of Stan Lee, the creator of Marvel Comics, the newest Spider-man movie gained an incredible amount of anticipation from eager Marvel fans. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse lives up to its hype and satisfies the needs and wants of any movie goer. The style of the movie engaged the audience with its comic-style animation. This is almost reminiscent of the movie Scott Pilgrim vs. The World, with its visual onomatopoeia. Not only was the style great, but the comical tactics employed were genius. The audience stayed captivated in the movie's serious parts but still managed to get an incredible laugh from the audience when a character said something funny, or whenever there was an (intentionally) awkward moment. Overall, the movie did a fantastic job keeping the audience motivated with its unique styling and comedic tactics. I recommend everyone see this movie, if they haven't already.
Amazing would recommend

Overall the film was solid (mostly because it was a marvel film alone) but also it introduced some new ideas into the marvel universe. The movie starts with a typical background and orgin plot, and eventually leads into the superhero aspect of the film when life of the Miles is changed and paralled to that of the late spideman. What really makes this film intereting is when other characters, and their humors, come into play when the new spidermen come in from different dimensions. Although the antagonists are lacking a little depth, and the ending was a tad too touchy, the plot wad developed well, overall. I think for me personally, and the rest of the marvel community, the Stan Lee store clerk was a great touch to the movie; however, I wish he played a more integrated role in the movie with some character development. The biggest thing that I think fans are most excited for is the idea of a marvel multiverse now in play, and the implications it could have for the future of the Avengers series:  But that is a story for another day.

Absolutely ground-breaking and breathtaking as a visually stunning graphic novel. Unlike other superhero movies, this movie does what has not been done: immerse you in the graphic style of graphic novels and comic books (“Sin City” being an exception, groundbreaking in its time, but paling in comparison to the broad palette of visual art in Spider-Man). Some scenes even the color shift which is seen in comic books when the red, blue, and green don’t quite align properly at the printer. On top of all this, the script is fantastic - truly funny and intelligent. The animation of the characters is superlative in the re-creation of subtle facial expressions during dialogue, something live actors themselves struggle with (and sometimes fail at). The story itself is your typical save the world story, and the script self-referentially pokes fun at itself (the oft-repeated phrase “...you know the story”). On top of all of this is a top-notch soundtrack. The after-movie credits show what an unbelievable assembly of graphic video artists was required to put it all together. I cannot sing enough praise about this movie. It will live permanently in my collection, to be watched many, many times. One of my favorite movies of all time.

The idea for this is not original, because it has been in comics, but it is new for the big screen. The story, though, could have been a tad bit better. I went in thinking there was no way, NO WAY it would live up to all the hype it was getting.   Wrong!   It does.   It's a fresh take on Spider Man with new ideas and characters.  It's a salute to the original Spider Man movies, perhaps even a true sequel in some ways to the Sam Raimi series.   It's a salute to the cartoons you fell in love with as a kid.  It involves everything that is wonderful about Spider Man and more.   I love Peter Parker, and was not thrilled about a Miles Morales.   But the Miles character, his family, and world were more than a welcome addition to the "Spider-Verse."  I was thrilled and surprised to find out it's just as much of a Peter Parker story as well.  Even the plot itself was so clever and full of surprises.  A must see if you love Spider Man, comics, or just solid action and entertainment.   Another nice thing is that it's family friendly and fun - where so many Super heroes are now trending dark and more adult.   In other words, your kids can fall in love with this world for the first time as you fall in love with it all over again.   If it's true this was done by the guys that got fired from the Solo story , then that is a real shame.  This had all of the fun and magic that the Solo story sorely needed.   Kathleen Kennedy and the Lucasfilm world made a huge mistake by not letting them add their talents in the Star Wars universe.   Because what they did in the "Spider Verse" was a blast!

Wonderfully stylized, and I was digging it from the opening credits. Saw this long after the buzz died down about it, and while I can't say the hype was warranted it certainly was a great movie. Things the movie did very well, aside from the great visuals, was making the story fresh all the while juxtaposing it with various renditions. I'll say certain elements, particularly the family (Morales' father and uncle), while serviceable weren't nearly as strong as others. The villain, Kingpin, had a rather weak element as well. There are tropes the movie falls into momentarily, such as the curmugdeonly Peter B. Parker playing the tsundere reluctant-but-then-sweet teacher and the scene where all the spider-whatevers show up and start unnecessarily testing Morales by beating him up before quickly assessing he's not ready (what a bunch of a-holes). These things aren't bad per se, they're just less good than everything else the movie offers. A slightly (SPOILERY) nitpicky thing I have is when Kingpin does his signature double-fisted slam thing onto Morales and he doesn't die despite the same thing killing the original Peter Parker. Then, Morales (presumably) regains consciousness and staggers to his feet, taking several moments in which Kingpin (who is just watching dumbly) could go ahead and hit him again or whatever but doesn't. That scene was just weird to me. Anyways, the last thing that was also great was the soundtrack. It fit so well with the film's style.

Spider-Man: into the spider-verse gives a refreshing take on animation which i feel gives a more visual interpretation of mess and pressure one feels from the teenage experience.  The characters, while already fan favourites are given a completely new lease on life in this film. They stay more true to the relatable essence of the comics while giving us nods and odes to the previous Spider-Man films and shows. Going into the film I was worried about how they would work all the characters into one cohesive story but they managed to do it. The story feels smooth and while it is yet another Spider-Man origin story, it still feels refreshing and new. Given all these positives you would be lead to believe this is a 5 star film, well for me its a four and a half stars. I only have two problems with it, one being while I love the original score and the original soundtrack, at some points the latter just doesnâ(TM)t work. Without giving anything away there is a scene at the start where they somehow fit three/four different songs from the original soundtrack in under three minutes. It just doesnâ(TM)t work and makes the moment a tad overwhelming but the original soundtrack does work in other moments. great example of it working is the âwhats up dangerâ? scene, the scene mixing and blends everything together and the lyrics and tone match the subject amazingly and caused me to have goosebumps for awhile after. The second fault i have is, no epilepsy warning. The film features a lot of flashing lights and colours which could be dangerous for some.

I’ve never seen anything like ”Into The Spider-Verse” – so far beyond any animated work I’ve ever seen! Merging gorgeous animation with comic-style textures and embellishments, this represents a much needed paradigm shift in super hero storytelling. Perhaps, rather than focusing budgets on multi-million-dollar salaries for ‘roided-out film stars, studios should be making animators the stars of comic-based films (seems only fitting given Marvel’s hand-illustrated roots). I really hope this sensibility becomes a more regular offering within Marvel’s portfolio. This is what a superhero movie should have been all along!

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is a 2018 American computer-animated superhero film based on the Marvel Comics character. The film was directed by Bob Persichetti, Peter Ramsey, and Rodney Rothmam.
I was really looking forward to this animated movie, but I ended up being extremely disappointed. It is chaotic and confusing, with very a very basic story-line for the most part. The music and songs are distracting and annoying, and while the visuals are inventive and different, they are also jarring. The film has a dark feel to it overall, and apart from a couple of scenes towards the end which show true comedy and depth, it was mainly un-involving and uninteresting.

This movie is better than any Spider-man movie I had seen. Though it does have its flaws, and perhaps its score is effected by the fact that main character is black. I can understand that, as it is hard to find any good animated black characters in media, and I have to say they blew this out of the park. The animation is fantastic, but the first five minutes of flashing colors made my head ache. Then, there is the small issue of no character development in the final three Spider-mans: Peni Parker, Peter Poker, And noir Spider-man.  They seemed to be just added for different animation styles, which wouldn't be a problem, if they had more character fleshed out. Overall, the film is emotional and is a must see for any marvel fan or any person in general.

When the movie opened with the main character mumbling along to the music, I knew it was going to be a good one. If the movie goes to the length to portray the characters with such genuine personalities, it is going to be better than the competition. The movie feels so accurate in its portrayal of miles being an awkward middle school kid who all the sudden is a superhero. Things just keep happening that he has no control over. When the action starts picking up it turns into everyone tossing him around until they can deal with the problem. When he finally gains control of his power it feels like he earned. 
The whole cast does really well. I love John Mulaney and I'm kind of surprised he did so well in a kids movie considering majority of his humor is mature. I was worried about Nick Cage, but he didn't have too many lines and didn't do anything insane so I was fine with it.
Overall, it was a great movie and I hope more studios pay attention to how this movie approached its characters.

I went into this thinking it was going to be the dumbest thing ever & I walked out with it being my second favorite Spider-Man movie. It's just fantastic. The reason for the animation style is obvious and the beauty of this vision could not have been conveyed without it. I loved the storyline & how it took the same and made it different.  The humor was something I did not expect, I was dying laughing. The Nic Cage Spider-Man is truly a stroke of genius and I want him to have his own movie. And this truly put the heart into what Spider-Man really stands for. Went into this not really knowing who Miles Morales was and came out wondering how I've never really heard any of this before.

âInto the Spider-Verseâ? caught me completely off guard. My woman and I arrived 15 minutes late to the film, and when we sat down Miles was having issues with his body producing natural adhesives, at least the puberty jokes could not get any worse than that.
This film, though aimed at kids, did wonders for someone like myself who still thoroughly enjoys comic books as I wait to finish this review so I can read this weekâ(TM)s latest issues (Itâ(TM)s Thursday NCBD is every Wednesday, I gotta keep up!). So granted, the digital effects were captivating. It looked like a 3D holographic comic book cover for the better part of nearly two hours of my life. I love how the hip-hop covers of âStarBoyâ? and âColoring Bookâ? could be seen on the Times Square ads and how the characters were not sacrificed to be walking stereotypes in lieu of their color, except maybe Milesâ(TM) mom (afro-P.R. and a R.N. who speaks Spanglish, AI dios mios!) .
Spider-ham could have been left out until he pulled the mallet. Spidey Noir was as stoic as I wanted him to be and Spider-Gwen finally gained my respect after years of trying (unsuccessfully) to read any comic with her in it (Iâ(TM)m more of a GwenPool guy anyway), still, Peter Parker that hung up the tights took the cake as my favorite Spider-Man in the pic.
For years, I ran away from Spider-Man thinking that all he does is bitch like a little kid about his problems so he must be a character ONLY for little kids to idolize. He juggles insanely hot playmates with love from his Aunt, a high IQ that gets him throughout college and into the exec chair of his own business, and if that doesnâ(TM)t pay the bills he can make scratch Atna successfull newspaper company, why complain? But to see it all be tore down for this sweat pants Spider-Man, that touched me as much as hearing Uncle Benâ(TM)s quote for the umpteenth time in !y life because that brought Spidey back to an everyman level for me and gave me someone to root for in the red and blue tights which I havenâ(TM)t in a long time.
As for Miles, he perfectly displayed what it is to suffer from an anxiety disorder, I enjoyed the feel-good story of him saving the day and gaining acceptance of himself not through his peers, but I saw him more as a walking PSA of mental illness, an after-school special in regards to puberty, and a Trayvon Martin-esque martyr if he would have lost his life in the movie. To me, Miles was more of a representation of multiple movements for equality than just a singular character. Oh, and that was cold how Gwen put him in the friend zone. And as for the outro with 60â(TM)s Spider-Man ; I smell a sequel.

I swore off animated movies.  Having gone into a sugar coma while viewing the highly-regarded "Paddington 2" (2017), I vowed never again.  In this case, I'm glad I broke the rules.

"Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" breaks plenty of rules on its own.  Along the way, it offers a variety of pleasant surprises.  There's a cameo by Stan Lee (creator of the Marvel Comics franchise) selling Spider-Man costumes and validating that we're all Spider-Man by gruffly confirming that his one-size-fits-all costumes fit everybody - at some point.  There's Mahershala Ali (Uncle Aaron) not lighting up the screen with his presence, primarily because he's not on the screen.  There's Liev Schreiber (Kingpin) showing his dramatic range by shifting from his dour, but excellent, role in "Ray Donovan" to Spider-Man's dour nemesis.  In a total shocker, there's Nicholas Cage (Spider-Man Noir) appearing in an interesting movie.  There's Hailee Steinfeld (Spider-Woman/Gwen Stacy) in another transformative role.  There's Byron Tyree Henry as, wait for it, Jefferson Davis, the father of our Afro-Puerto Rican protagonist.  It's all just weird and wildly wonderful.

The plot is also predictably bizarre.  As part of his plan for world domination, Kingpin has built an atomic collider that inadvertently creates a rip in the space/time continuum.  Our protagonist Miles Morales (Shameik Moore - 2015's "Dope"), a 16-year-old student at Brooklyn Visions Academy, is bitten by a mechanical spider.  Soon enough, he explores his developing super powers and is out to thwart Kingpin.  Because of the disruption in the space/time continuum, other Spider characters are able to come to his aid:  the aforementioned Spider-Woman, Spider-Man (Chris Pine), Older Spider-Man/Peter B. Parker (Jake Johnson), Spider-Noir (Cage as a black-and-white character in a trench coat), and, my personal favorite, Spider-Ham/Peter Porker (John Mulaney) who bears a striking resemblance to Elmer Fudd.  Back to the plot: on the brink of world disaster, they collectively save the day.

Even visually, this film is disorienting.  There is conventional CGI, Ben-Day dots (used regularly in vintage comic books), an anime character (Peni Parker, voiced by Kimiko Glenn), thought balloons, even written sound effects reminiscent of the old "Batman" TV series (1966-1968).  Directors Peter Ramsey, Rodney Rothman and Robert Persichetti, Jr. have pulled out all the stops.  It's all so bizarrely unique that Sony is reportedly trying to patent the processes used to craft these unique visual mash-ups.

If you are looking for a logical/linear story line or deep insight into the human condition, get serious.  You really expected that from comic book characters?!   But if you want a strange but wondrous adventure, in the immortal words of Steppenwolf (1968), "You don't know what/We can find/Why don't you come with me little (gender neutral pronoun)/On a magic carpet ride?"

A colorful and breezy picture (and I do mean picture, it is gorgeous to look at), Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is the knockout that many fans wanted for decades and one of the best animated superhero films ever made. I'd argue it's the best representation of Spider-Man in cinema and the closest one to the manic glee and near-cosmic weirdness of the venerable series it is based on. Spider-Verse uses new fan-favorite Miles Morales (Shameik Moore) as its protagonist and we spend a great deal of time with him. Now while it would be redundant to talk about # representationmatters at this point, it was refreshing to get a Spider-Man who was NOT Peter Parker. Parker (Jake Johnson, Chris Pine) ends up being a secondary character(s) and functions as a mentor to the younger, anxious Morales, which was an interesting dynamic. We also get crazy alternate universes colliding, with several different Spider-People on screen and interacting at once. (Fear not. It does not turn into Crisis on Infinite Earths madness.)

Let's talk about the visuals. HOLY GOD. This movie is beautiful. I'm glad they didn't bother with the typical CGI that abounds in multiplexes these days. And yes, while hand drawn animation is still my favorite, that artform has undergone a slow death outside of Japan this past decade. (Take a look at DC animation now and compare it to 15-20 years ago.) Spider-Verse opts for a cell-shaded look which looks remarkably close to comic panels of today. It allows the filmmakers a lot of freedom with visuals and crafting whatever they need without looking out of place or cheesy. Voice performances were exceptional (Morales, alternate universe Parker, and Spider-Gwen stand out). While we get plenty of laughs, there are plenty of heartbreaking moments to be had, sans the melodrama. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse packs all the entertainment one wants and then some. It will probably become what Mask of the Phantasm is to Batman. I look forward to the sequel and hopefully we can get some other off-beat characters such as Ben Reilly's Scarlet Spider. When Miles Morales gets bit by a radioactive spider he assumes the role of Spider-Man. Except there's more than one Spider-Man from separate dimensions crashing into one. The superheroes have to get to the bottom of what put them together and figure out how to right those wrongs for the sake of the universe.

Acting: 10

Beginning: 8

Characters: 10
Easily one of the shining moments of this movie is learning about each spider character. Their differing personalities make the team-ups and dialogue scenes hilarious. Peter B. Parker shows us what kind of man a hero becomes when his life completely falls apart. He's nonchalant and sloppy, but not because he doesn't care anymore. Meanwhile, Spider-Ham was just perfect in every single way. I won't spoil any of his moments like trailers have already done, but his featured scenes don't disappoint in the least.

Villains are solid as well. Kingpin is a coldhearted badass who intimidates everyone in his path. As the story progresses, you understand what helped to make him who he becomes. This movie did an excellent job of fleshing out each character and giving them purpose.

Cinematography/Visuals: 8

Conflict: 10

Genre: 8
Animated film or not, this movie is as good as it gets. Though not in my upper echelon of superhero films, it still ranks right up there with some of the best. Incredibles 2 gets the nod for best animated superhero film this year, but Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is not too far behind. 

Memorability: 9
The animation style alone is enough to make this movie one that sticks around in your head long after you've watched it. The action sequences are long and satisfying, really popping off the screen. A positive message puts a nice little bow on top of everything.

Pace: 10
Entertaining from beginning to end, Into the Spider-Verse sets a swift pace and doesn't slow down. Even scenes between the action have something important or funny happening that keeps the audience involved in the story. No slow-downs or lulls, the movie remains fresh deep into its runtime.

Plot: 10

Resolution: 5
Ending was meh. Wasn't bad, but it didn't give me that Cherry On Top feel that I typically look for in an ending. It left me feeling a little...empty.

Overall: 88
When I first put Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse on my radar, I had no idea what to expect. I saw it as more of Sony trying to cash in on their one main Marvel character. After seeing it, I'm happy to report that I was dead wrong. I really enjoyed the movie and I can't wait to check it out again at home in 4K!

Gorgeous visuals, addictive soundtrack, fluid and unique animation styles, amazing storyline, funny and creative, Spider-Verse makes a connection with the audience and itâ(TM)s more than just animated film. Itâ(TM)s a gift from such talented human beings who wanted to give out the message that anyone can be Spiderman.

I will foreward this by saying I am not a fan of superheroes. Or at least I thought I wasn't. Then I saw this mesmerising artwork. This is what animation was made to do. It pushes the medium in ways my brain couldn't quite compute and a fast paced rollercoaster of animated abstractness balances perfectly with very sensitive and very real moments. 
The tender scenes seem realer than live action through the filter of the style. There are moments you forget it's even animated and moments you couldn't believe it is anything other. 
Despite it being more 'animated' than any cg movie I have seen, It is also a rich story where the dialogue isn't clunky and maintains a balance of sincerity and meta jokes. 
Here at last is an animated movie from a major studio directed squarely at adults. This is not a movie for young children and is paced to serve the older audiences of super hero films. This is backed up by the loud five year old behind me * mommy I want to leave I dont want this movie!!!*. For an older overstimulated generation to lose themselves in this visually hectic and wonderful feast is great, but I hope the marketing as a PG movie will make parents of younger children think twice.
