(Minor-Plot Spoilers)

I knew "Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse" was going to be great, but I didn't realize it was going to be amazing.

We first have to talk about the animation.  Similar to many Telltale Games products, the animation is inspired by comic books.  The colors are loud, bright, and poppy.  Warning to people with epilepsy, this movie has many flashing colors at times, so be cautious when watching the movie.  This movie embraces its comic book visuals by making all the animation embraces the style.  The action is like one from a comic, the camera angles pop, and the character designs are all unique and distinct.

Our main protagonist is Miles Morales.   This is a film about Miles Morales becoming his own superhero.  While the other Spider People he meets knows he has great potential to be a superhero, the issue lies that he needs to be ready now to help get the other Spider People back to their dimensions.  He just got his powers, and now he must replace the prior Spider-Man and become the new Spider-Man.

Every character has an excellent personality, motivations, flaws, and emotions.  This movie made me tear a few times for how much I identified with multiple characters and their struggles.  Rio Morales, Miles' father, is filled with so much heart and conflict.  He is a great dad, but he and his son are growing apart.  Rio is loving and strict but is still understanding.  Miles wants more freedom but needs more guidance.  Adding in Mile's Uncle, Aaron, and you have a tug-of-war of family conflict.  As the plot continues, the emotional weight of the stakes becomes more teary-eyed, you really get the feels a lot in this movie.  

But family themes also lies in the relationship between Miles and, who I'm going to call, Spider-Man 30 (the Spider-Man I assume to be in his 30s).  Spider-Man 30 and Miles have not just a teacher-student relationship but also a father-son relationship; which makes a perfect scene for Spider-Man 30's character arc.  With each scene, Spider-Man 30 grows, and as a result, he is more interesting.  Because of the course of events that happen in the movie he has to evolve continually throughout the film, and it is paced organically.  He turns from a Spider-Man that is in a depressive state into a Spider-Man that is ready to move on to the next stage of his life.   The three primarily focused Spider-People are Spider-Man 30, Miles Morales, and Gwen Stacy (aka Spider-Gwen).  Spider-Gwen doesn't have a character arc, her role consists of being a foil and support for Miles and the rest of the team (just as an analysis; it does not make her character any less enjoyable).

The other Spider-People are secondary characters who have traits and identities of their own.  Spider-Ham has his own 2Dish animation mix with the 3D animation.  Peni Parker is an anime character with a robot â" they always remind me of the movie "Next Gen" on Netflix (which is a compliment, I love that movie, go watch it).  Spider-Man Noir is voiced by Nicholas Cage, enough said, that is stupid-genius casting.  When these characters start getting their own movies, I will gladly throw my money at them.

One final note I will discuss is that seeing this movie in RealD-3D is worth the extra money.  You get an additional amount of depth with every frame, and the 3D perspective enhances the visual experiences.

4.8/5 Stars

This is a movie that I've been wanting to see for the longest time. I'm a huge Spider-Man fan. I love Spider-Man. I do also like Peter Parker, mostly because when I was growing up, I related to him and I still do. But in the latest Spider-Man movies, Peter Parker has been the main focus of those movies. Now we have a fresh new face in Miles Morales and a different story that we haven't seen before. Now that I was able to see it, I can say for sure that this is most likely my favorite animated movie of the year. I was really surprised on how great this movie actually is.  Not only from a story perspective but it's also visually stunning. The animation is beyond glorious.

There is absolutely so much to praise about this movie. Starting with the characters. To be honest, I didn't know that much about Miles Morales. If anything, I only knew that Miles Morales existed. But this movie showed me how great of a character is Miles. Not only he's a great badass character in those great action sequences, but much like Peter Parker is in the comics and in the movies, Miles Morales is a very relatable character. He's going through a very tough part in his life. He has trouble connecting to his father. He doesn't like the school he's attending. His given smart parts where the viewer can totally identify himself with Miles.

Peter Parker was great in this movie. He definitely shares some screen time alongside with Miles but he's not used in a way where Peter is far more important than Miles. This is definitely the story of Miles and the movie acknowledges that.

Nicolas Cage as Spider-Man Noir was excellent. Loved his character and every moment he had on screen. Even Spider-Ham or Peter Porker was very funny, which leads me to say that this movie is hilarious. The movie had a very unique and funny way of presenting these characters rather than just filling us with the basic info of each of them.

The animation is my favorite aspect. It feels like the entire movie you're reading a comic book movie. Sometimes squares appear saying what the character is thinking. Or even those big "BOOM" after a character punches someone appears. You even get to see one of those stamps that every comic book has.

It really is gorgeous animation. Something that it's a first time for me saying regarding Sony Animation because I don't usually enjoy their movies, and their animation is usually normal. Nothing special about it. This time they went big and it worked for them. Words can't express really how much I loved the animation. It was outstanding. It really was.

The story was also very engaging and interesting. A unique look in the many Spider-Man movies we've seen. And it worked.

My only issue with the film were the villains. Wilson Fisk looked great, he was a badass, and I understood what he was doing yet I never really got the why he was doing it. Then we have several villains that appear throughout the movie. Sure, they looked great, but they were simply villains, which I guess worked out for the movie.

Final Thoughts.
That been said, this film was great. I had a great time. I enjoyed. Hands down, best animated movie of the year, and quite frankly, possibly best Spider-Man movie since Raimi's take. There're also some hilarious references to the previous Spider-Man movies and an awesome end credits scene.

In un'esaltante grafica fumettistica, prende vita uno dei migliori Spiderman cinematografici di sempre. Il personaggio ï¿ 1/2 nuovo e risponde a una necessitï¿ 1/2 di svecchiare quel Peter Parker, di cui, ormai, il pubblico cinematografico ha noia. Oltre ciï¿ 1/2, troviamo, per la prima volta, il Ragnoverso (Spider-verse) e dunque uno dei passaggi piï¿ 1/2 interessanti dell'universo fumettistico del supereroe. Contando su una squadra di eroi ragneschi, provenienti dai vari mondi paralleli, il protagonista, Miles Morales, adolescente in preda alle difficoltï¿ 1/2 della sua etï¿ 1/2 e dell'acquisizione dei nuovi super poteri, dovrï¿ 1/2 destreggiarsi fra nemici enormi (di fattezze e di potenza), la propria crescita e la missione per riportare a casa gli altri "Spiderman". 
Il film, infarcito di citazioni e rimandi all'universo fumettistico e cinematografico, ï¿ 1/2 un'esperienza visiva nuova esaltante. Anche se, all'inizio, possono infastidire alcune scelte visive (come la resa del bordo sdoppiato, per ricreare la messa a fuoco della macchina da presa), con l'avanzare dei minuti si entra nell'ottica di quelle immagini a volte estremamente bidimensionali, altre volte capaci di una mobilitï¿ 1/2 e profonditï¿ 1/2 di campo, che rendono le scene d'azione il punto piï¿ 1/2 luminoso ed esaltante della visione. A tutto ciï¿ 1/2, s'accompagnano escamotage visivi prettamente fumettistici, inseriti con intelligenza e funzionali al racconto della storia e del protagonista. 
A far da cornice a tutto, una colonna sonora moderna ed in grado di raccontare alla perfezione l'ambiente in cui si muove Miles.

As a cinemaphile, as an animation enthusiast, as a comic book geek, and *especially* as a dad, this movie hit every bullseye. I have no complaints. It's wholly unique in animation technique (which is breathtakingly stunning), it nails the score, it nails the writing, it nails the cinematography, it nails the editing. It respects its audience, it celebrates the universe in stands in, it embraces and amplifies and explodes in comic book personality. I could nitpick but it really doesn't deserve that. It's the real deal kind of cinema. And, now, as a dad. Oh jeez. I saw it with my 6-year-old daughter, and... Whew. Was not expecting the emotional impact. This film is has got some piercing profoundness for both young and old generations.

*Spoiler Free*
This movie to me was absolutely perfect. The best of everything media has to offer with the reflection of our inner journeys ("the Hero's Journey" pretty much all movies are based on) in current culture.
It took the best of everything available now and there was nothing "unnecessary" in it in my opinion. Most movies have scenes that ruin the momentum, or aspects. Kind of like if a movie was a puzzle and they added pieces of other puzzles that didn't fit and take you out of the film.
The emotions, story and animation were all perfectly done. The scary moments were scary, the sad moments tugged on my heart and the funny moments made me laugh selflessly. The navigation of emotions are perfectly balanced. Which is brilliant considering how short the scenes are and how fast paced the movie is. The pacing is perfect, giving just enough time to enjoy pieces of the story with absolutely no fluff.
It has a full identity. The animation is absolutely unique among all other animation films to me. Staying true to the comic book origins while also bringing life through gorgeous animation.
I really feel like the culture this movie was based on was also well represented and authentic. The soundtrack is amazing. Bringing the best of big theatric sound and raw hiphop/rap artists. Some movies that are based on African American culture it feels like a white guy tried his best to give his view on it...and it's cringy. Although I am white so I don't even have a great opinion on this hah.
Great casting.The characters and voice acting communicate the story seamlessly and hold the balance of the film's messages. Which almost never happens in movies in my opinion. Shows like True Detective, Avatar, The Wire and others where the world is so full that it's so easy to become immersed I think have a similar quality (immersion) that the creators of this movie also created.
It really felt like the detail of each scene was as "full" as a full half of other animation movies of today.
I believe this to be the greatest animated achievement of it's time congratulations to all who worked on this film I hope you are proud of your work :) Thank you.

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is an astonishing film that literally swings out of nowhere to become genuinely the best animated film and the best superhero movie of 2018.

This is the first superhero film that takes full advantage of the comic book medium, splashing it proudly onscreen with its gorgeous animation, incredible action sequences, and radical soundtrack. Crafted with genuine and absolute passion by its creators, it honors not only the talent and heart of its titular character himself, but (unlike any superhero film before) also celebrates the wider lore and mythology of the comics themselves.

Spider-Verse is the rare superhero film that truly and authentically explores the heart and soul of who Spider-Man. By expanding the titular superhero character to a diverse new roster, it posits the rare moral message that perhaps, Spider-Man can be anyone.

While not an absolutely perfect film (the pacing can be a little bit rushed and some side characters are unavoidably somewhat sidelined), the amount this movie does right is incredulously monumental. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is a landmark film, a milestone in the superhero genre, and rightfully stands as one of the greatest superhero films ever made.

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is a 2018 Sony Spider-Man film directed by Peter Ramsey, Bob Persichetti and Rodney Rothman. The film stars Shameik Moore as Miles Morales, Jake Johnson as Spider-Man and Hailee Steinfeld as Spider-Woman.

The story I found to be very gripping and unique, from the various plot lines to the very well flowing narrative. 

The voice acting was also very strong, especially Shameik Moore as Miles Morales, I found that he gave a really fitting and stylised performance.
 
The characters for the most part were well written and very entertaining, but I did find some characters like Spider-Ham and Peni Parker to be very underwhelming and just there to get a cheap laugh.

The animation was also really vibrant and stylistic, from the extremely quick character movements to the beautiful and unique comic book style.

The action in the film was detailed, entertaining, intense and very fast paced, especially the two final action sequences.

The soundtrack in my opinion was steady, but at times it did feel a little overbearing and a bit obnoxious. 

The comedy was good and witty, but now and again there'd be a joke that did fall a little flat.

The film did also have some very strong atmosphere, especially in a twist reveal at the end of the second act.

The film was also very intriguing and enjoyable, and I hope to watch it again soon.

Over all I give it a
8/10 - would recommend

A bit Overrated, if you ask me . Little bit disappointed honestly. If there was anyone who would like this film no matter what it would of been me , at yet i didn't like it that much. I really makes me sad to do this . This film showed promise from the first teaser . As I'm doing art for my gcse's the art style blew me away . I even tried to replicate it but it in an art project but it didn't work. Then I found out miller and lord who directed the lego movie were directing it which got me more intrigued . I liked lego movie as a kid , I knew they would bring a certain humor to the film . Then sunflower came out which I even liked even though I don't really like music of that style. And then I found out nic cage was spider noir which was pretty cool (I'm not a fan of nic cage he's just the only cast member I recognized). Then the reviews came out . 100% by critics. If it got 100% it must be good . Everything seemed to be going for it . The visuals the comedy the music the good reviews . So I decided to go watch the film . There was actually a lot of people I knew from school mainly from 6 form in the theatre with me when I watched it . Usually when I watch a film it takes time for to have a final opinion on a film . There are lots of films I like initially but then I realize aren't that good , but in this case I was a bit underwhelmed already when the credits began to roll . To put this film simply I would say the only standout good thing about this film are things I thought would be good but thats it . The visuals and comedy we're both really good but everything else didn't impress me to much. The story was meh the acting was meh the villain was actually kinda bad. not the worst by any means but kinda bland , which I wasn't expecting. The only thing to kingpin is his bare bone motivation and thats basically it . He could of not of been there and there would be bearly any difference to the film . (spoilers) it's true he kills Chris pine spider man but he's only on screen for like a minute so his death personally didn't hit much (spoilers over)  also that brings up another point the emotional moments were weak for me  as they usually have little reason for you to be sad about them . (Spoilers again ) when the uncle dies it isn't sad as he literal is there for two consecutive scenes just to be forgotten and then brought back just to be killed of . When the others are like to miles " your not good enough " or something ( I really can't remember what happened in that scene i found it forgettable) to miles it didn't hit me because first thecharacters didn't  convince me in what they are saying (It isn't the acting is bad it's the dialogue ) second it comes seemingly  out of nowhere and I don't remember miles being that noticeable sad afterwards  . My main problem though was the spider people. To put it briefly they were just about fleshed out enough to have low key dimensions (no pun intended) which is nice but could of been better if there was more time , and that goes for spider Gwen as well . She just had a more formal introduction compared to the others, which I wasn't expecting as she was built up as a big character. Also spideham , I was expecting a average character but he just got on my nerves ; he was like The jar jar of this movie . The interaction between miles and peter is nice though but the problem is there's not enough of it. Now just to clarify these are nit picks of the film . They don't bring the film down for me . The point of me bring this up is to show that I believe this film is good but by no means amazing (again no pun intended). Again just to mention good visuals and comedy . The reason why I wrote this review is because I've been seeing a lot of reviews hailing it as one of the best animations of the year , which is far from the truth atleast for me . I think I'm probably just missing something everyone else is seeing in this film . Also I want a sequel which shows I don't dislike it . I'm probably just over analyzing .

The hype is real.  So you think you know Spider-Man.  If you watch movies, he's Peter Parker with the same old backstory, but some of the minor details get changed along the way, depending on what version you're watching.  But what if there were multiple dimensions where the entity that is Spider-Man is different in every one of them?  This is about Miles Morales (Shameik Moore) getting bit by a spider, assuming the powers and the role, all the while navigating an interdimensional drift that converges on this one character.  Sounds complicated, right?  Well, this is all put together by people who clearly know what they are doing, because it all makes perfect sense when you watch it.  I have heard nothing but the highest of high praise for this, so I got damn excited for it.  This kind of floored me, because as a superhero movie, it is next to flawless.  Now even with all the positive reviews, the best omen I got from this was when I learned that Phil Lord has a writing credit on this.  From 21 and 22 Jump Street to Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs, I was already well aware that he is capable of densely packing as much entertainment into a feature as possible without sacrificing flow and character development.  One of the biggest reasons why this is so fresh is that they are not telling the same story again.  You can't go five years without the character being rebooted or reimagined, and at this point, the origin story has been done to death.  They sidestep that not only with something creative and recurring, but they manage to bring new origin stories that haven't been given this big of a platform before.  I am hesitant to say too much, because there are just that many great surprises to it, and it is a pleasure to see where they take this story that doesn't have to abide by rules of canon or sometimes even physics.  Into the Spider-Verse is laugh out loud funny, but you also feel the stakes when the action peaks as well.  The artwork and animation is gorgeous, and they manage to shape and mold different styles that all come together into one package.  It's aesthetically pleasing and the story is extremely well thought out.  A telltale sign on how much I am enjoying a movie is how few notes I take while watching, and I took about half the amount that I normally do; I was scared I would miss something, and I really was that into the movie.  I don't even have any real complaints about this, and as soon as it was over, I wanted to go and watch it again (update: I have seen it twice now and it is still great).  This is one of the best movies of the year.

"Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse" 

With how oversaturated the super-hero genre has gotten, with the "Infinity Wars" and "Justice Leagues" it is easy to miss a smaller scale film such as this; I assure you, however, that this is the one you DO NOT want to miss. At this point in time, I have had 5 viewings of "Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse" 5(going on 6) and I'm left in awe each and every time I sit in my recliner.

The plot in this film is so fresh and exceptionally well done: using a new Spider-Man learning how to be a hero from an older Spider-Man who has forgotten how to be one? They nailed it. Filled with so much heart and human emotion, "Into The Spider-Verse" is a film that does so many different things and succeeds in every single one both thematically and in it's ambitious narrative.

The script is also handled spectacularly while being extremely well written. Dialogue is real and believable; never in this film did I feel like "oh real people don't talk like this." Everything is natural and flows, even all the superhero jargon sounds less expository as in other films. Exceptionally well done and paced.

"Into The Spider-Verse" is a MARVEL in modern animation,from cell shading, to 3D models retouched with 2D animated features, blending the two styles seamlessly and also paying homage to traditional animation by animating characters 2 frames at a time, but kicking it into 1 frame to smooth out the more dynamic movements just to hyper-emphasize the fluidity of the characters. Utilizing chromatic aberration to "faux pull focus" while refrencing golden and silver age comic book printing errors. The film is a joy to look at. Each frame is handled with heart and it shows on screen.  Visually spectacular. 

Spider-Man has always been a character made from strife. The theme of life taking more than it gives has always been Peter Parker's shtick, and never has it been clear here. The theme in this movie is failure, and more importantly, getting up afterwards. In life, things will knock you down, but you always get up. We are all filled with so much untapped potential, and at the end of the day, there isn't the Green Goblin or Kingpin standing in the way of us, but ourselves. Thats been the theme of Spider-Man since his conception, so to have a film so expertly and lovingly give this to us in the form of "Into The Spider-Verse" is something that I could not give more praise to. Best Spider-Man film. One of the best in the genre. Best movie of 2018 for me. Take care yall. Much love as usual. May add to or edit this in the future.

This movie is a must see. Not only is the abundance of spider superheroes a thrill to watch for Spider-Man fans, but the soundtrack, visuals, and story arc are all high quality.
The first thought that came to mind when I saw the movie trailer was "Wow this is going to be a great movie." I was genuinely excited, and the movie did not disappoint. The visuals immediately grabbed my attention. Due to the animation of the movie Marvel was able to create stunning effects. In addition the use of vibrant colors left me feeling happy as I left the movie theatre. Whether it was Miles and Peter swinging in the forest or Miles scaling buildings the smoothness of movement was amazing. The animation is some of best I have ever seen.
Next is the soundtrack. The music definitely appeals to a certain audience, a younger audience. This being due to many rappers and pop artists being featured. While older audiences may enjoy these music forms they're without a doubt more popular among younger people. I enjoyed the soundtrack immensely, and although the soundtrack is often overlooked it is vital to a movie. 
Finally there is the story arc. This movie is clearly meant to be a coming of age story. Miles must overcome his fears and step up to the plate. But thats where the similarities with other super hero movies end. Miles is a Afro-Latino kid from Brooklyn. He is not a white male like many other superheroes. Furthermore he has not faced tragedy, at least not in the beginning of the movie. This is a far cry from what the original Spider-Man faced. And finally he is not a social pariah as many superheroes are. He is in fact quite well liked. Miles is a normal kid dealing with super powers. And thats part of what makes this movie so appealing to so many people. They could place themselves in his shoes because his life is so normal. Then there is the fact that Miles is a minority. He is one of the few minority superheroes to make it to the big screen. And that might be the greatest thing about him. It allows young minority kids looking for a role model to
have one. All in all this might be my favorite Spider-Man movie yet.

TheReelness.com: New York teenager Miles Morales is bitten by a radioactive spider, developing mysterious superpowers that transform him into Spider-Man. Soon after, he realizes that the evil villain Kingpin has opened portals into other universes and pulled other versions of Spider-Man into his world. Sony Pictures Animations leaves nothing on the table in this heavily-produced animated film. It has creative and innovative animation, clever dialogue and a cavalcade of celebrity voiceovers – among them, Hailee Steinfeld, Kathryn Hahn, Nicholas Cage, Lily Tomlin, Chris Pine and Mahershala Ali. And while the film does have some cute moments as well as a portrait of the Spider-Verse that will delight hardcore comic book nerds, for everyone else, the frenetic blur of action feels like an attempt to distract moviegoers from an exceptionally average, unremarkable and overrated film. Ever since I was a kid I've been a fan of Spider-Man, specifically starting with Peter Parker in the Raimi trilogy. Animated? Eh. A huge twist on the original Marvel Universe? Jesus Christ... This movie had is all going against it from my point of view. When it comes to movies, I prefer something that I can understand before seeing it, more following a pre-formed outline than figuring it out as it goes. This movie seemed the opposite. But boy, oh boy, did I enjoy it. The seamless manner in which they were able to introduce so much information, but have it make instant sense to the audience, was excellent. I was initially worried about the potential lack of character development of the Spidermen/women/pigs, and while there is only so much you cando with characters introduced beyond the halfway-mark onf the movie, the development of Peter B. Parker and Spiderwoman were excellent, Peter Porker and Spiderman Noir still having substantive roles in the movie. If I was to be very critical, the anime-inspired Spidergirl was a bit lost. The other characters were useful (loved the bit with the uncle), and there just seemed to be a level of plot-action-character cohesion that DC and some Marvel Franchises *Cough* Thor *Cough* haven't been able to master. Not to mention the beautiful animation. It didn't feel childish as I had originally feared: it felt like art.
The animation is excellent, the storyline enthralling, and movie thoroughly enjoyable. I'd definitely pay for another overpriced movie ticket to see it again.

This film singlehandedly reflects the excellence of Sam Raimi and Tobey Maguire’s origin story trilogy, erases whatever that Alex Garfield mess was and Salutes the Legacy of the late great Stan Lee. Find everyone you know young and old and enjoy exceptional voice actors in and exceptionally well written fantastically animated treat that will dazzle your eyes and touch your heart in just the way we thirst for ways to unify in today’s unnecessarily divided world. 🕸GOD SPEED♥️STAN LEE🕸

A truly great animated movie, with a great introduction to Miles morales in modern media. The film itself is a little slow starting setting things up but is nearly non stop the second act onwards with enthralling action sequences and animation. The story is very good and the villian has understandable and emotional motivations, however, with a roster of 6 spider people, they dont really have time to flesh out all of them, with Noir, pig and the asian spider people feeling less fleshed out than Miles, Gwen and Petre, the others only getting a short backstory mostly played out as a joke anyway. As well as this, the only other issue i have is kind of a *spoiler*. When it is nearing the end of the movie and Miles is ready to become his earths Spider-man, we hear previous voices that are meant to be insperational to Miles, but most of these voices are lines we heard literally 2 or 5 minutes before the scene.

"Spider-Man into the Spider-Verse" has set the bar high. With originality that breaks free from the all-to-familiar mundane plot lines, long time fans itching for the portrayal of Miles on the big screen will not be disappointed. 

The humor captures the lovable wit of our favorite Spider-Men while also incorporating the heavier themes straight from the comics. You will watch as the heroes and heroines flip and swing through the city, but you will also see, firsthand, their characters develop, a critical part of storytelling that is often washed over in movies these days. This movie tackles loss, identity, betrayal, family, trust, and self-worth. And yes, there is also kick-butt action. 

The brilliant writing, refreshing narrative, and gripping soundtrack make it more than a mere superhero film. In terms of visuals alone the movie is worth seeing. The animation remarkably depicts a comic-like feel, with sliding panels and thought bubbles creating an immersive experience. Morales soars to heights unseen in live action films. 

Everyone will leave the theater pleased. Wether it's the characters, writing, animation, soundtrack, or plot, there is an aspect of this movie to appeal for all. Adults will love the action, kids will love their superheroes, teenagers will witness their coming-of-age struggles in Miles, and Spider-Man fans will, of course, watch favorite characters fight the epic King Pin. Sweet homages throughout, a cameo from Stan Lee, and a tribute to him in the end will leave all crying and laughing. Team Maguire, team Garfield, and team Holland can reunite over their love for Spider-Verse.

This movie brings the Spider-Verse to life. I highly encourage everyone to give it a chance. 
And remember to stay to the very end ;)

In a year full of wonderful animated films, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse stands out.
This movie tells a story of becoming Spider-Man from a unique angle and clarifies from the get-go that is is not a Peter Parker story; this is a Spider-man story. For the first time on the big screen, Miles Morales is featured along with other rich and fun characters.
Blooming in colour, the visuals resemble a moving comic-book and are truly astonishing. Complemented by creative and comical directing, this film seems as if it was born in a child's imagination! 
One of the strengths of this picture is that ignores the recipes of the previous live-action Spider-man franchises(both Sam Raimi's and Marc Webb's) of an origin story+the main plot. Marvel's Spider-man: Homecoming did likewise by ignoring the origin and diving straight into the world. Alternatively, Sony's animated take on the Web-head embraced the arrival of a new protagonist to re-tell the origin story giving itself as much time as it needs. Rather than giving us a quick "With great power comes great responsibility" and letting it be, we are taken into Miles' Morales journey and experience the triumphs and tragedies of becoming a hero.
There is not a part that doesn't belong in the movie, the only notable problem is that the villain is under-developed. The writers gave him a very cliché motive and expect us to empathize without fleshing out. On the other hand, it is pretty clear that the film does not intend to develop the villain but rather the abundance of protagonists.
To conclude, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is a thrilling experience no matter if you are 5 or 75. Go watch it on the big screen while you can!

This movie leaps straight out of a comic book, watching it brings back the nostalgia of reading comic books. The splashes of colors in the movie bring lots of life to the viewer's eyes. This movie brings real aspects of life and real situations n life, and deals with them greatly.

When I saw the teaser trailer I thought "oh great, another animated show." Then i learned that it was a movie and thought "FINALLY! Miles Morales in my favorite story line on the big screen. But still not a movie theatre movie." I saw the first trailer and got super hyped because it looked awesome. I really wanted to go but thought I probably wouldn't have time. I then had the chance to see it and did. IT WAS AMAZING. It blew past my expectations redefining what a good Marvel and Spider Man movie could be. It was sad but happy, funny but serious, and the storytelling was great. It hits on all points perfectly and Miles's character development is smooth and also perfect. The twists are unexpected and ending hits on everything emotional, funny, action packed, and overall satisfying. This is by far the best movie of the year.

This movie is probably the greatest animated movie many of us have seen in a very long time. While it does not take place in the now cramped MCU universe, it's plot is wonderfully crafted around the idea of multiple heroes as well as the inclusion of multiple universes, the latter being an idea many movies have built a story around, but this time around, it feels wonderfully fresh with a spider-twist. The animation, of course, is the other major selling point - it looks and acts like a comic book, and appears to be the first movie of it's kind in that regard. It includes many snide references to it's original medium, and you can tell the animators had a great deal of fun making every scene. 

The characters, both heroes and villains, feel fresh, unique, and often relatable. In this movie, you don't feel like sighing at yet another Spider-Man origin story - you get fun, emotionally deep, and diverse characters out of the old material. Old Spider-Man villains return, but their designs and implementation into the story are refreshed and clever. All characters are challenged some emotionally, yet the plot doesn't feel overstuffed and you begin to care about all the heroes and their collective plight. 

While it does feel like an experiment in film making, I feel that many agree this was a step in the right direction for not only reinvigorating a tired brand, but creating more great films for their own regard, not just because they're a part of a bigger universe.

Any superhero movie has many ways to fall flat on its face -like, a way too convoluted plot, too many heroes, too many villains or a bland two dimensional one-, Into The Spider-verse takes all of this possibilities and makes a huge gamble on the off chance that the six different spider-people won't get anyone dizzy, that the villains won't feel two dimensional, that the end of many universes scenario won't be the cherry on top of a messy a cake. But, despite of having  so many things that could go horribly wrong, Into The Spider-verse makes everything work, and with an amazing and unique style.

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is a colorfully animated, dazzlingly inventive film delivering a charismatic lead performance by Shameik Moore, while Bob Persichetti, Peter Ramsey, and Rodney Rothman direct a film that seldom adheres to formula.
Exceptional movie in every aspect.

As a fan of all things Spider-Man, this film hits all notes of silver age spider man to modern day spider-man. The story introduces Miles and a relatable New York teen, his development through the film into spider man feels deserved, this accompanied with the chemistry he has with the supporting cast makes this film just feel like straight out fun. Each variation of spider person is excuted perfectly and handled with care and humour. They used a clever story telling device to give the origin story of each spider person in a way that feels fresh and unique, even though they revisit this device a couple of times, it never feels bogged down. Each character feels like they go through the journey, such as Miles's mentor Peter B. Parker learning that he made a mistake and develops this father son/mentor bond with Miles. Gwen and Mile's relationship works well as a friendship and didn't need to be seen through as a romantic aspect. 
The animation is this film is top notch. each character having their unique animation style and colour palette works well in this stylised world.

I was waiting for this for so long and how this movie exceeded my expectations. There was so many ascpectd that made this movie unique, great and simply enjoyable with some some amazing characters art style and hilarious laughs; anyway enough with that lets just get started with 
The Good:
One thing this movie did greatly was the art style it was so fresh seeing this on the big screen with some phenomenal action sequences  which complimented the art style .when I was in the cinema there was some times when I was sat there in ore over the sheer brilliance of it.
Another point to make is the charecters; for me anyway the characters were phenomenally well written with all delivering big time on laughs and truest heart felt moments for example Peter B. Parker in this movie is in a completely different state as what most people are used to which I 5hought was great and we seen him go on this journey of essential recovery throughout the movie where on the other hand Spider. Ham delivered on a great comical level which I though was well timed and pleasant. However there was one character which I thought wasn't the best. 
Finally how could we not talk about the protagonist and the story. For me Miles Morales is the perfect Spider-Man seeing his development on the screen as he denies the initial call to adventure and see him become the new Spider-Man and also with the story and message delivering that had never been done before that anyone can be Spider-Man which is just beautiful. 
In conclusion I could be here all day talking about the good bu now I must move onto...
The Mixed:
There is only a few mixed really; for example the only character that I dint like was Pe I Parker not that that really effects the overall narrative just thought there was something missing when her robot gets destroyed but I have seen a few people who really liked her bu that's just my opinion. 
Also  I thought that the reveal of the Prowler was predictable for me I could kind of see it coming from a mile away but then when he died it caught me of guard and it was very mixed for me as it gave miles but I thought that there could've been so much more potential in the future. So now movin onto...
The Bad:
There's only one thing bad about this and it was the posture of king ping. He was meant to be the main villain he just looked dodgy with how big he was it didn't come of as scary it was just disturbing which is a shame because his character was on point.
Conclusion;
There is so much more I could've talked about this movie like the villain and the family life for miles. But it was a simply enjoyable experience for all the family. Finally this is the first movie since Guardians of the Galaxy that has left me wanting more
Final Score: 9.8

Innovazione sotto ogni aspetto, tutto ciò che vorresti da un film del 2018 è racchiuso in questo piccolo capolavoro d'animazione. Incredibile come riescano a tirare fuori una storia su Spider-Man così nuova e originale, una trama di cui io e tanti altri non avevano neanche sentito parlare. Oltre alla fantastica storia basata su un fumetto che pensavo fosse sconosciuto, il film offre animazioni moderne e nuove, una tecnica di cui ancora non conosco le meccaniche che con meno immagini al secondo garantisce movimenti di camera praticamente senza controllo. Questo serve a creare scene d'azione semplicemente fantastiche, emozionanti e coinvolgenti ai massimi livelli. Il tutto, oltre ad essere diretto con uno stile giovane, con musiche moderne e coraggiose, presenta anche un impatto cromatico fuori dal comune, una vera a propria gioia per gli occhi. La storia offre anche quel giusto livello di emozione e umorismo che necessita, senza esagerare o andare fuori tema. E' un film d'animazione che osa tantissimo, che viene ricompensato dal suo coraggio: il risultato è un grandissimo film, che supera in tutto ciò che si è visto quest'anno e diventa automaticamente il miglior film d'animazione dell'anno.

It is really hard to know whether or not my wanting to put a five-star is because of the hype or if my wanting to not put one is because of the hype. I'm not really sure. Either way, hilarious movie. The art style was beautiful and right from the start it had me hooked. As a comics fanboy, this was the sequel that the Sam Raimi films deserved. This is a thousand times better than Andrew Garfield or Tom Holland ever have been in the role. I loved that there was no #thuglife or gangster worship crap to mar the tapestry. In fact, I loved the fact that the main hero's dad is a cop and a moral one. Too many films now put the cops as the bad guys and it isn't right. One of the first films in a while that didn't disturb any political melodrama while preaching very good values. To become who we truly can be takes faith and courage, and the courage to step into parenthood is worth having and putting into action. I loved all the nods and the tributes to a glorious franchise and it's creator, while being able to put a new Spider-Man in the spotlight. Heck, the color scheme might be part of why I love Miles' suit so much, it reminds me of Batman Beyond a lot. Very enjoyable film that I can't wait to own.

Spider-Man: Into the Spider Verse  
Initial Reaction:  How do they get out of the Spider Verse?

Main Characters â" the spider um people.
	Miles Morales, Peter B. Parker, Gwen Stacy, Peni Parker, Spider Ham, Spider Man Noir: The Spider people voiced by Shameik Moore, Jake Johnson, Hailee Steinfield, Kimiko Glenn, John Mulaney and Nicolas Cage.

Plot Summary
	This story takes place in Milesâ(TM) universe.  Just like all the other spider people, he gets bitten by a strange spider and gets the powers of Spiderman.
	Also, the main bad guy, Kingpin, is working with inter-dimensional equipment.  The first test goes badly and several Spider-people from other dimensions gets dragged into Milesâ(TM) dimension.  They will have to work together in order to stop Kingpin, and get a way home.

SCORING
Main Characters
	I like these spider people a lot.  They work well together and each of them has a great personality and quirks.  The best parts of the film are when they are working/not working together.  SCORE: 10

Supporting Characters
	Kingpin makes for a good villain because weâ(TM)re told of why he does what he does.  And the other non superheroes add something special to the mix, namely Aunt May who has a big secret to show the Spider people.  SCORE: 9

Plot
	I enjoyed the trip that the film took me through.  At moments, it was funny and at others it was gripping drama.  But it all works in the end.  SCORE: 9

Originality
	I know, I know.  Iâ(TM)ve heard the origin story a few too many times, and this film makes reference to it one too many times.  But the main characters really add a nice spin to what could be a stale story.  SCOR: 8

Violence Factor
	Not for the youngest â" some people actually die in this film â" albeit not in a graphic way.  Still, the deaths are a vital part of the story.
	But I donâ(TM)t like the fact that either the characters are perfectly healthy or theyâ(TM)re dead.  Nobody gets injured in these films.  SCORE: 8

Other Moral Issues
	This film shows how a group of strangers can get together to make a great team.  It also shows the power of family and the belief one has in oneself.  SCORE: 10

Final Score (out of 60): 50		% Score: 83.33%
	Yes, itâ(TM)s another Spiderman â" or another superhero film.  But I see is as a challenge to make the other action films better.

This was an incredibly successful attempt at not only putting together what is probably the most visually comic accurate film, but also a heartfelt story that can truly connect with everyone mainly due to the fact that the story takes so much time to actually let us become invested in these characters, especially Miles Morales. The movie is also surprisingly very funny and never forced its way in to shift the tones either. Kingpin as the villain was definitely not the highlight of this film and probably couldâ(TM)ve been written to appeal more as the villain to Miles as opposed to just a bad guy. Other than that, Spider-Man: Into the Spiderverse is one of the biggest surprises of 2018 and an absolute delight for comic book fans and average filmgoers alike.

That wasn't a movie, it was a love letter-to the comics, graphic design, New York, hip-hop culture, and most of all, Spider-Man. I was lucky enough to have seen a preview snippet at Adobe Max, but it did not prepare me for the audio-visual immersion of one of my favorite animated film of the year. From the blasting of Biggie Smalls, the hiss of the spray paint cans, use of half-tone and over print design effects, for the first time in my life,  even having consumed countless hours of Marvel animation and films, this is the first time I felt the soul of the comics and Stan Lee's love of New York City were truly brought to life.  There were so many moments that felt so right, but none more than Stan's scene. It was more than a cameo. It was his send-off. Thank you, Stan, for creating the hero for all us nerdy outcasts and to the animators and director for "taking a leap of faith" and surpassing what is expected of animation and film for that matter. Keep taking risks.

I'm honestly astonished how much I liked this, because before I couldn't be bothered with yet another incarnation of Spider-Man.

Despite a cliched narrative towards the end with "everyone doubts the main hero and he needs to prove himself", type of trope, and inappropriate song choices during dramatic moments - yet that didn't bog down the experience for me.

Still, I wished this movie came out during my childhood when Spider-Man was my bible, as I would've died and gone to heaven from the feeling of glee.

I think the message that anyone can be Spider-Man, no matter your race, gender and sexuality is powerful and empowering.

You cannot fault Sony for their determination to milk every last drop out of a franchise that has already seen 3 reboots and counting. So not content with spinning off morally ambiguous villains, here we have a (cynical, much?) attempt to bring about yet another incarnation of the beloved character but this time in animated form. Focusing on the more ethnic and lesser adapted Miles Morales, a half African-American, half Hispanic Spider-Man from the comic books as the main character is a wise choice. With Phil Lord, who cooked up the innovative and meta-funny The Lego Movie before, on screenplay duty, he takes the things that would normally work against the film and utilizes them to the script's advantage, as he finds hilarious and clever ways to play with the idea of different Spider-Man/Gwen/Ham from different dimensions and inverts the tediousness of the 'origin story' into an actually funny postmodern joke. Rendered in a unique and exciting style using seizure-inducing colour palettes that visualizes what a 10-year-old on a sugar high would look like, this is a film that somehow manages to feel fresh and enjoyable despite its formulaic elements as the film charts Morales' search for his own Spider-Man identity amongst the many different counterparts that has broken through as a result of Kingpin's MacGuffin. The script has its funny moments, but its structure is simple enough not to confuse the kids nor tax the adults' minds and the finale sequence has the look and sophistication of a Saturday morning cartoon series, but with better graphics. So, well done, Sony, for breathing new life into a seemingly used-up franchise and find yet another cash cow within while doing it with such grace and style.

One of the year's best in terms of animations, and film as a whole. 

Phil Lord and Christopher Miller, the creative minds behind The Lego Movie and 21 Jump Street, bring their unique talents to a fresh vision of a different Spider-Man Universe, with a groundbreaking visual style that's the first of its kind. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse introduces Brooklyn teen Miles Morales, and the limitless possibilities of the Spider-Verse, where more than one can wear the mask.

Man, when I first saw the trailers for this film (by the way, how often do I say that in my reviews?), it looked fucking awesome (also, can I curse on a PG movie rating?). Also, who could've guessed that we'd be in the mood for ANOTHER Spider-Man movie? Well, we get a lot of films we don't ask for - thankfully this one was awesome. 

Let's start with the animation because that was absolutely gorgeous. This film is filled with spectacular, beautiful looking CGI and visuals. The colors, the design, the look, everything was so gorgeous. The animators implemented a style choice that made it look more like a retro style of animation. This is undeniably one of the most gorgeous animations of the year, with so many beautiful, memorable shots and sequences throughout. 

You know what was really good about this film? - the writing. The writing, the execution, the directing, everything was on point. There was a consistent tone and style throughout, even with multiple directors. The film was fun, emotional, and relatable. The characters were all so unique and all so interesting. I didn't know anything about Miles Morales prior to this film, so it was really interesting to learn about him, along with all the other characters. 

What made this film so compelling was because of its themes and its relatability. It's a story about a young boy who's suddenly handed an immense amount of responsibility and his response to that. This film is kind of like the fun, comic book movie mixed with serious and genuine elements. It's an all around strong film with so many different things going for it. Even though we've kind of seen this story before, it's still just as effective, if not more. 

In the end, "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" is one of my favorites of the year. It's fun, funny, exciting, adventurous, and a breath of fresh air in the superhero genre.

A year ago when the first trailer came out for this, I thought it looked awful. It looked bland and dumb and just a movie for diversity in movies (which isn't bad) but that shoved it down your throat without a good story or acting. I thought that Black Panther would do the same thing, and I was mostly right (it was enjoyable at times and the acting was great, but the CGI was terrible and they did shove it down your throat). However, this film exceeded my expectations, it's easily one of the best spiderman movies ever! There were many pros; it was a great story with some emotional and heartfelt moments and great twists, like *****SPOILER***** Miles Morales uncle being The Prowler, one of the supporting villains, the original Peter Parkers death, and Doc Ock. The Doc Ock thing I didn't see coming but at the same time sorta did, because I seen in the cast list that Doc Ock was voiced by a woman, and I was hesitant to except it unless it made the story better, and it definitely did, the twist with her was awesome and I loved it because of how well done it was. The score was amazing and the new original songs like Sunflower and What's Up Danger have been stuck in my head for a long while now, in fact, as I'm writing this review I'm listening the latter song. The villains, as I said earlier, were all great - Kingpin has been on a role this year as one of the best villains to ever villain, first being awesome in Daredevil and now this. His backstory is tragic and you can understand why he's doing what he is doing without necessarily agreeing with him, similar to Thanos from Avengers: Infinity War. Prowler was actually one of the most threatening villains I've seen, as the sound effects for his menacing roar were well done, and the twist with him was great as well. Scorpion was okay, however, he didn't really do much. The heroes were great as well - Miles Morales was awesome and I love how fleshed out his backstory was and he was funny and memorable, as was Jake Johnsons Peter Parker. Spidergwen was also awesome, and has a two great introductions. Spiderman Noir and Spiderham were great as well, but very sadly underused (I was really hyped for John Mulaney to be playing Spiderham, so I was a bit disappointed). Peni Parker, however, I'm not a big fan of. She was of the only parts of the movie I didn't like. The pacing was mostly good, but the final fight scene was a bit short, however, it was one of the best chekhov's gun moments I've ever seen (*hand lands on shoulder*... "Hey") and it was great fight scene as well, as were the other ones throughout the movie. The animation was really well done, and was one of the things I had really been against after seeing the first teaser, but seeing the finished product it was so awesome to look at, it was like it was jumping straight out of the comics. The greatest scene has to be when Miles takes his 'leap of faith,' one of the best movie scenes ever, I got goosebumps while I was watching. There were some cons, however. Like I said, I think the ending was a little rushed, and I also didn't like Peni Parker. I think Spiderman Noir and Spiderham should have had more screen time. I also didn't really like how kingpin was animated, he was too much of a square. In the end, this was one of the greatest spiderman movies ever that offers alot more to add to the spider-man mythos. Ranks second under Spiderman: Homecoming. Solid 8/10 - A /90%.

Phil Lord and Christopher Miller are known for their penchant for irreverent comedy; 21 Jump Street and The Lego Movie immediately pop to mind with a grin. Here the talented pair, along with Avi Arad and Peter Ramsey, turn their hand to a beloved Marvel item who is no stranger to a reboot; Spider-Man. But, this time we're not being subjected to yet another Uncle Ben death scene; Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse tells the origin story of another Spidey, plucky teen, Miles Morales (an energetic Shameik Moore) as he grapples with the infamous Kingpin (Liev Schreiber), helped by a number of inter-dimensional "Spider-people"... including a washed-up, cynical Peter Parker (voiced with a nonchalant drawl by Jake Johnson). We watch as Miles grapples with finding his feet after an unfortunate interaction with a radioactive arachnid, in a hearty and humorous adventure, that feels distinctly Lord and Miller.
Into the Spider-Verse is a noticeably different adaptation of the friendly neighbourhood superhero; from the outset, the film cheekily satirises the incessant rebooting of its character (a flashback to a certain Spider-Man 3 moment gives perhaps the biggest laugh). Plenty of fun is poked out of comic-book movie tropes too; this doesn't change the fact however that, plot-wise, Into the Spider-Verse has little to offer in terms of originality, its narrative as predictable as a Saturday morning TV cartoon. 
The film almost makes this redundant, however, through a stylish and confident execution, that feels fresh. Lord and Rodney Rothman's script is full of wry humour, quick-witted, yet full of heart and honesty. Miles Morales is also a more fleshed out lead than we are used to from Marvel (despite a slightly easy resolution to his arc) and his band of misfits, whilst largely one-note, are fun enough to carry the film with ease. Brian Tyree Henry and Mahershala Ali are unfeigned as Miles' father and uncle respectively and Jake Johnson is simply brilliant in an incarnation of Peter Parker hitherto undreamt of. An antagonist in the form of Kingpin is more disappointing, a forced motivation leaving him uninteresting and decidedly by-the-numbers. The movie leaves us little time to think on its faults though; it takes a relentless, yet natural, pace through riveting action sequences and comedic montages, with the ease of a web swing.
Into the Spider-Verse's greatest strength, however, is its design. The animation is unique and aesthetic, delightfully reminiscent of an old-school comic strip. The film feels like a very real homage to its source material, the comic in comic book movie always coming first. Into the Spider-Verse won't be remembered for breaking ground in plot and character, but its design alone is enough to make you want to go back for more.
Phil Lord and Christopher Miller have assembled a fun and frenetic film which, whilst standard on paper, is executed with artistry and flair. An incarnation of the world's favourite superhero surely to be remembered.

The film is OK, but it's highly overrated. It has some moments but they get lost in the mess of the "Spider-Verse" plot. Where do I begin? The film is too loud, too busy, too flashy and there are too many "Spider-People" that it doesn't know what to do with. It also has too many villians, it has a whopping six of them! Did Tombstone even do anything during this movie? Female Doc Ock eats up most of the screen time and she's not that menacing, new or interesting. There should of been more of a focus on the Kingpin and the Prowler. That's where the movie shines. Less is more. Although I wasn't a big fan of the Kingpin's square-like character design.  

The animation looks cool, but after watching it you realize it is very choppy and not that fluid. The flashy animated effects and backgrounds give you a headache.  Overall, "Into the Spider-Verse" feels like it's just a excuse to make anyone or anything "Spider-Man" just so SONY can make endless "Spider related" movies  since they drove the classic Peter Parker story line into the ground with their recent failed live action Spider-Man films. Did we really need to see Spider-Ham in this film? Is there a Spider-Dolphin, Spider-Aunt May, Spider-Mail Box or Spider-Mary Jane movie in the works, Sony? Or can we see a movie about a spider that gets bitten by a radioactive human! There is a thing as "overdoing it" and this movie does it.  Spider-Man is a character, and is not a UNIVERSE!!! And when did Spider-Man have a secret "Bat Cave" with tons of tech and gadgets? Wasn't Peter Parker always broke in the history of the comics? That's right, it doesn't need to make sense, because it's in a "alternate universe" 

 The film kills off some meaningful characters (in a gritty way) which gets me invested about new characters (like Miles and his relationship with his Father)  and it tells a good origin / coming of age story and then somebody gets hit with a cartoon anvil or wooden mallet like in a Road Runner cartoon and it completely takes you out of it.  Not a horrible film but far from being great.

I don't think this is a film I would recommend to someone who knows nothing about Spider-Man because it may be way too overwhelming for someone who knows noting about any of the characters. For me even I was having trouble following everything because I was trying to catch up on characters I was not familiar with. The more you know the more you can appreciate this film. If you like Lego Movie or Lego Batman then you will appreciate this film. Looks very different from any Spider-Man film or Super Hero film I have ever seen before. The animation style had me so fascinated that I missed so much of the hidden Easter eggs like logos altered in the film. I like the dedication at the end for Stan Lee & Steve Ditko I wish that we saw more from Spider Nor, Spider-Pig, and Spider-Penny because those were the characters I knew the least about. I thought it was interesting how this film starts and has the Comic Book approval logo I feel like this whole film is a visual a visual spectacle. I thought it was interesting seeing the differences from other Spider-Men film. It was interesting seeing the differences in the villains or variations on the heroes. It was interesting how One Peter was different from the other in age, hair color, what happened to the different Peter Parkers. I liked the montage and references to other Spider-Men. I like all the references and Easter eggs in this film to previous Spider-Man things as well as variations of Spider-Man. I like how they explained the differences on different Spider-Man. Like Peter having dark hair vs. Bright Blonde hair. I did feel confused at times what was Miles Morales Spider powers consisted of. I thought this film was interesting seeing various art styles come together in one film. I thought it was interesting how comic book bubbles are used in this film. I feel like this film was able to connect this film together better than many films. I wish we saw King Pen's family explained or seen better so we feel more for him loosing or help understand his motivation better. I wish we got a little bit on what is different between Aunt May's and Mary Jane Watson in those other universes. I liked that we got to hear the Sam Rami Uncle Ben voice in this film. This film does a great job getting the family theme and inner faith in self as a theme in this film to tie all these characters together in one film. The villain is fighting for family, There is a family feel that connects all the Spider characters because they each lost a family member and then you have Miles Family emphasized in this film. This film feels like a Avengers film while making Miles Morales the main focus. I wish we got more of the Green Goblin and Scorpion because I was least familiar with those versions of those characters. I liked the look of New York in this film. I liked Spider-Nors interest on A Rubics Cube. It was not till a second going that I recognized that the documentary playing when Miles Moralis walks into class is Dr. Olivia Octavius speaking about other dimensions. I think I like some of the music and other times I am not into it. Like I liked the motif used for the Prowler scenes. Or I liked the music playing after Miles is bitten and he is first experiencing his powers. I found the music was unique in that there was so much diversity in types of styles of music even in the score.

IT'S RAINING SPIDER-MEN - My Review of SPIDER-MAN: INTO THE SPIDER-VERSE (4 Stars)

My distaste for superhero films has been well-documented, so consider my surprise that I actually found myself not only loving one, but remembering what I've seen!  Consider that a major achievement with SPIDER-MAN: INTO THE SPIDER-VERSE, while still filled with all of the Marvel trappings I've grown so bored with, triumphs BECAUSE it's animated.  

Live action comic book movies always feel like a bunch of actors in Halloween costumes standing in front of green screens playing out simple black and white storylines.  With acting as stilted as the old Sword And Sandals Epics of yesteryear, I preferred seeking out the gray areas in other genres more in keeping with my tastes.  With this new film, the genre feels more at home as an animated feature, especially because the animation feels so alive.  Because you can literally do anything, the impossible action feels credible and the approximation to reading a comic gets its just due.  Additionally, unlike its wooden predecessors, the voice acting pops with one memorable turn after another, and it doesn't hurt that diversity rules in a traditionally white story.  

Written by Phil Lord (THE LEGO MOVIE), comedy writer Rodney Rothman and directed by Rothman along with Bob Persichetti and Peter Ramsey, the film snaps and crackle with self-reflective humor reminiscent of DEADPOOL and, no surprise, the LEGO movies, but it finds enormous warmth with Shameik Moore's portrayal of Miles Morales, who, like Peter Parker (voiced here by Chris Pine), gets bitten by a radioactive spider and finds himself with the same superpowers. Faster than you can say "Malkovich, Malkovich", more Spider-folks emerge when an accident threatens the lives of his counterparts from other dimensions.  Those include a pig named Spider-Ham (John Mulaney), Peni Parker, an anime-style girl voiced by Kimiko Glenn, and Spider-Man Noir, a hardboiled detective played by Nicolas Cage.  Each incarnation gets their own filmmaking style, turning the film into a delightful genre blend.  Its overall animation has such a fluidity to it as well as glorious "steadi-cam" shots and thrilling action sequences.  Add a terrific Kathryn Hahn as the delightful lab nerd, Doc Ock, Hailee Steinfeld as a very independent, misanthropic Gwen Stacy, Liev Schreiber as the big bad guy, the winning voice of Brian Tyree Henry as Miles' strict police officer father, Mahershala Ali as Miles' freewheeling Uncle Aaron, Lily Tomlin as the most fierce Aunt May yet and Jake Johnson practically stealing the film as a Peter Parker from another dimension, and you have one of the best voiceover casts I've seen in an animated film.  

Yes, the plot and the giant cast feels overstuffed at times, but it remains a quite charming experience throughout.  Miles' hero's journey includes the usual "get off your ass and do something selfless' tropes, but his nerdy, humble demeanor brings joy to the film in ways that the usual stoic super-whatevers never achieve.  The nonsense surrounding the "collider" and fixing it before everyone dies isn't as interesting as watching Miles try to cozy up to Gwen, who just isn't having it.  Despite this, the chase sequence through the woods outside the lab thrilled me in ways I haven't seen since Luke and Leia went on a speeder chase through the Endor forest. The film also has some surprising reveals and a dynamic and literal page-turning quality to the storytelling.  I was reminded of And Lee's HULK in this regard, but again, the animation sells this quality way better than live action.  

I don't want to overpraise this film, because I'll likely forget most of it anyhow, but I will remember its eye-popping style and attention to character.  It's a meta good time at the movies where for once, the calorie count in your popcorn doesn't exceed the surplus of all the good ones on the screen.

I have not enjoyed myself so much in a theater these last couple years (maybe longer) as I had seeing this film. From minute one, this movie had me grinning from ear-to-ear and it never stopped. First, I have to mention the animated motif/aesthetic the production crew went for here. For the first time, I truly felt like the pages of a comic book were properly "translated" to the silver screen instead of being recreated or adapted into the film medium (as distinguished by the ink dots used to make up larger images being clearly visible); that, along with the sounds effect cues, just make the animated panels pop off the screen in a brilliant way. There is so much detail to make out in each visual, which works both to the film's benefit as well as its detriment (I wish I could have seen what was going on better in some of the more-frenetic, snappy fight scenes). Additionally, it was a nice touch incorporating appropriate styles for the "spider-characters" pulled from their varied universes. I also must give a shout-out to the casting department for pulling fantastic performances out of all of the voice actors. Shamiek Moore IS Miles Morales for me, no matter what; he just embodies the character so well that I wish I could see him take on the role in a live-action movie. I also thought Jake Johnson's version of the sad-sack Peter B. Parker was a fun, hilarious inversion of the conventional Spider-Man we've read about for almost six decades now. Hailee Steinfeld, a performer I have rarely been a fan of, added a spark of life to Spider-Gwen/Gwen Stacy, as well. In spite of wanting more running time from the flick to develop their characters, Nick Cage and John Mulaney provide great supporting parts as Spider-Man Noir and Spider-Ham, respectively. Though he cannot measure up to Dn'Ofrio's Netflix counterpart, Liev Schreiber displays enough dimensions to his Wilson Fisk/Kingpin to make him more than a broad, menacing figure. Other actors I won't name here pitch in awesome additional cameos. For me, the best part of the film, though, is that it never loses sight of its main character and HIS story. I may already be familiar with his background as a reader of Marvel's Ultimate line of comics, but even if I was not well-versed in Miles' life, the film does an admirable job of offering viewers a reason to CARE about this kid; you want to root for him to succeed even before he inherits the powers, grapples with the responsibility, and ultimately becomes a "Spider-Man." Add to all that a heartfelt tribute to the recently-passed co-creators of this world, the late Steve Ditko and Stan Lee, and some inspiring messages for younger audiences and you've got yourself a winner. Despite not caring for most of the hip-hop music (along with my other minor complaints above), this is now my second-favorite "Spider-Man" movie of them all. I encourage every person - big, small, whatever - and their families to head out and watch this movie as soon as possible!

An exhilarating achievement illustrating how adventurous, intertextual, and unique a comic book film actually could be. Visually the most arresting and unconventional animated film in recent memory, the filmmakers put their medium to full use: Utterly abandoned is the realism of the Nolan Batman trilogyï¿ 1/2"in the wake of which has been far too much seriousnessï¿ 1/2"or the popcorn safety of the MCU, instead embracing the radical impossibility of the comic imagination. On the level of its texture embodying all at once, paradoxes and logic be damned, its origin and its adaptation, its comic source and its cinematic expression, the film simultaneously sets the stage for, on the level of the text, a story that embraces originals and successors, plurality and uniqueness at the same timeï¿ 1/2"there is no sole source and no singular end, for the font of heroism is within all of our hearts.

A masterpiece. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse succeeds in everything it attempts. The story is fascinating; by not focusing on Peter Parker as the main character, it manages to explore stories and ideas that never have been explored more. Miles Morales is a very intriguing character. He is very desperate to succeed in life, and yet is afraid to at the same time, as he knows the true consequences of following your dreams and what you must leave behind. He is almost like Peter Parker from the MCU in a way. Additionally, the film fully fleshes our Peter Parker in this movie, and all the struggles he goes through as a superhero, even when he’s living the high life. But the film’s ultimate high point is the animation. Seriously, the animation is enough to see the movie even if you’re not interested in the story. It takes all the elements from a comic book and uses it to its advantage. It’s unlike anything you’ve ever seen before. It is clear that it took a lot of people to make these effects possible, and all the work definitely paid off. Spider-Verse attempts to change both the animated and superhero genres, and succeeds on an extremely high note.

Iï¿ 1/2(TM)m not sure what I can add to what has already been said about this film. I had watched an Angry Joe review before I was even aware of this film and I have to admit that it is everything I had wanted the Toby McGuire Spider-man to be, I had never bothered with the second Andrew Garfield film after seeing the painful amount of plot holes, idiot balls, and the terrible extent they made Garfieldï¿ 1/2(TM)s version of Peter Parker into a Gary-Stu character. I hadnï¿ 1/2(TM)t been a fan of Garfieldï¿ 1/2(TM)s acting, but the script and character they gave him was awful and I donï¿ 1/2(TM)t blame him for the failures of those films. I didnï¿ 1/2(TM)t bother to watch Homecoming, partly because of the sheer saturation of Marvel films, and partly because I just couldnï¿ 1/2(TM)t find it in me to view the character of Peter Parker as interesting anymore.

I loved the 90s Spider-man cartoons. Among US cartoons, it and Batman had been my two favorites, but the McGuire films were chalk full of stupid writing compared to the brilliant, analytical, and empathetic cartoon version of Spider-Man. It wasnï¿ 1/2(TM)t always perfect, of course. However, the writing, plots, scenarios, and characterizations were so far above everything that either the Toby McGuire films and Garfield films always failed to capture. Peter Parker wasnï¿ 1/2(TM)t just some stupid kid going through puberty; he was a brilliant, analytical, and compassionate individual who thought through serious issues, grappled with life-death circumstances on a weekly basis, and showed compassion throughout. Perhaps my love for the 90s cartoons skewed my views, because evidently that wasnï¿ 1/2(TM)t Comic-book Spider-Man. I knew I would never see that brilliant version of Peter Parker again, but to repeatedly see from new cartoon series to films . . . this stale, average, and frankly stupid Spider-Man really killed any love I had for the character and series. Over time, I grew to detest the character of Peter Parker too and got sick of the franchise as a whole. I suppose I became a jaded Spider-Man hater, because the writing of all these stories had been so damn terrible compared to the 90s cartoon.

This film has absolutely changed that for me. Miles Morales feels like a fresh start to a new Spider-Man. The comedy is top-notch, the characters have real depth that is shockingly on par with the 90s cartoons, and everything I missed about Spider-Man has been reshaped and re-imagined with this new Spider-Man and the phenomenal writing of this film. I highly recommend Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse. It captures everything I missed about the 90s Spider-Man, adds genuinely hilarious humor unlike most Hollywood films, it has great music that is executed with wonderfully, it does absolutely stunning work with visuals far above and beyond anything previously done with the Spider-Man franchise and that isnï¿ 1/2(TM)t a hyperbole, and I loved all the characters and their individual stories.

If youï¿ 1/2(TM)re even slightly considering watching Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse, I highly recommend it. I really feel this film outshines everything before it. Gwyn Stacy and Mary Jane are both actually interesting for once, the characters are all exceptionally developed, the origin feels far more fresh than the overused Peter Parker storyline, and Miles is more interesting and brilliant as a lead character than any of the previous Peter Parkers since the 90s Spider-Man cartoon.

I'm splitting this into sections:
Visuals: This was definitely it's strong suit. This movie is just beautiful to look at. It's charming and has so much character. Man, it's hard to believe that this is the same company who made the Emoji Movie. It's crazy. Everything felt so beautiful and I think the visuals are what stuck with me the most. 

STORY: I thought the pacing was a little bad. Too slow at points, mostly with dialogue, or too fast in moments that could be strung out a little more. This caused confusion with what the heck was going on near the end, but hey! It was pretty so honestly I can figure that out later.

Predictability: I came into this movie knowing nothing. It's not what I was expecting, but still good nonetheless. I'm not going to spoil anything, but there were some moments that, yes, were surprising, but the unsatisfying part about is that there was absolutely 0 foreshadowing. I'm sure it's answered in the comics but for the general viewer it was just kind of like: "woah, they're that now... huh." On the other hand, what I thought was the most unpredictable part was how dark it was! I can't exactly spoil anything but man!! It was incredibly dark for what I thought was a PG movie. 

Score: I'm a soundtrack lover. It's my favorite type of music. So naturally, it sticks out when I watch the movie. I haven't listened to it directly yet but from what I picked up in the movie it was brilliant. I would have liked a little more character themes but honestly what I got was so fantastic that I wish I had gotten more. Spider Ham and Prowler had some of the best themes that stuck out to me.

Spider-man: Into the Spider-verse is directed by Peter Ramsey, Robert Persichetti Jr. and Rodney Rothman, screenplay by Phil Lord and Rodney Rothman, and voices-starring by Shameik Moore, Jake Johnson, Hailee Steinfeld and Mahershala Ali.

Story by Phil Lord, and it's about Brooklyn teen Miles Morales, and the limitless possibilities of the Spider-Verse, where more than one can wear the mask.

First time I heard about this movie I wasn't that hype about the idea of the movie or the animation. The trailer wasn't so clear about its animation, or the very bold storyline! When I went to see this movie I was blown away by the striking animation and the bold storytelling.. I think it's a very risky step for Sony to take, to make a very unique, new and comic-alike animation, I mean what if the audience didn't like it? It could have been a big disappointing movie, because it has an amazing story, I think this story is definitely the best story of the whole Spiderman movies, also the animation is amazing, it's flawless! When an animation movie brings the live-action movies down, it means that it's definitely unique and bold!!

The story didn't take so long to get you into the main plot, it went with its surprising "scene" -I'm not gonna spoil anything in this review- and though it made a very good introduction of the characters, so the first act was very good, shocking and humorous too!

The second act still a very funny and thrilling as the first act, introducing the rest of the characters, so it took more time to get us back to the main plot, and I loved it, because some characters wasn't that clear in the first act that I wanted to know more about, and others that I wanted more of their backstories because I liked them! After introducing the "rest of the characters" we get another shocking scene, driving us to another shocking scene.. excuse me if I'm mysterious about some stuff, but I don't want to spoil anything, and still, if you watched the movie, you're gonna understand me very well.

The third act was very predictable though, but still very thrilling because of its amazing animation combined with the amazing action, and emotions... Oh yeah, the third act is completely emotional, and action-full!

There're not any subplots like Fantastic Beasts the Crimes of Grindelwald or something, it's very straight and clear.. very good for kids, and amazing for Spider-man fans and adults as well.

I think that Spider-Man Into the Spider-verse is the Spider-Man that we deserve as fans of Spider-Man and it's definitely the best Spider-Man movie of all the time.! And of course, Spider-Man Into the Spider-verse gets an A+!

Alright, guys.. thank you as always for reading and supporting my work, and if you liked this you can click on my name above and read all of my reviews, lots of movie-reviews are coming ahead.. thanks again!
