Spider-Man: Into the Spiderverse is a satisfying movie to watch. Throughout its running time, there isnï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)t really a time where youï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)re bored or just want to get it over with. This said, there are some remarks.

The comedy in the movie seems balanced, it has its moments of seriousness, which is always well respected in any production. Some parts might have been too imaginative and inhuman (feelings-wise, not talking of Spider-Han; Spider-Ham is awesome), but there isnï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)t too much focus on them and were not at all excessive or inappropriate.

The storyline though nicely depicted with beautiful transition and chemistry between the characters, seems to have moved in fast foward in the last third of the movie. It feels like a small chunk was truncated or a part has been dissected.

Now as a fan the 1990s animated spider-man series, this movie gives me mixed feelings. The style of animation definitely bypasses current days outlines and is quite relatable, but I canï¿ 1/2 1/2(TM)t help but always long for the 1990s spider-man shapes that are simply animated depictions of real life.

All in all, into the spiderverse is well established, well crafted movie that no doubt gives Morales a just introduction to the big screen and gives the spider-man universe a decent gateway to our universe. Well done Sony.

this is another one of my favorite Spider-Man movies
another entry in the SONY Universe finally portrays Miles Morales on the big screen but he's not the only Spider-person out there
the animators mostly stick to the original source material of this young kid's origin being raised in Brooklyn NY; Miles is juggling going to a prestigious new school, living with his father who's a police officer and spending time with his uncle Aaron
Miles ends up getting bit by a radioactive spider gaining all the same traits as the hero we know and love but with added abilities like being able to cloak in invisibility 
the original Spider-Man in his dimension battles Green Goblin working for the Kingpin trying to use his cosmic collider, sadly it ends in tragedy 
now it's up to Miles to keep the promise he made to this version of Peter Parker to keep not only this world safe but multiple ones as well
the Kingpin's device works for the most part but it ends up fracturing reality as we know it bringing in others from other dimensions like Peter B. Parker who's more of a slouch and jaded after having bad experiences as Spidey, a version of Gwen Stacy aka Spider-Gwen who lost her best friend, a black-and-white version called Spider-Man Noir from the 1930's, Peni Parker who's DNA bonds with a robotic spider, and an animal version called Spider-Ham who's more of the goofy, Howard-the-Duck esque jokester
the movie has a lot of charm to it by making so many callbacks to previous media forms of Spider-Man from his comic debut in 1962 to a Christmas album to the Sam Raimi movies to his Aunt May to Mary Jane Watson to Donald Glover to a Spider-lair full of vehicles and various suits but also making a few new changes like a female version of Dock Ock
fantastic voice acting from Hailee Steinfeld to Liev Schrieber to Nicholas Cage, stunning animation making the whole thing feel like an actual comic book moving from page-to-page, a sufficient amount of heart, exciting action, one hell of a twist in the middle, and a ton of humor
it's also got a killer soundtrack 
MIles still has a lot of learn in order to be his best version of himself not copy others, his family doesn't run away from things, the hardest part of the job is knowing you can't save everyone, and figuring out who he wants to be may just be the key to rising to the occasion 
it's also kinda nice to see Stan Lee in one of his last cameos 
the movie has some great messages for everyone not just Spider-Man/comic fans to pick up on; each of us in a way has a power of our own to help the world, anyone can be a superhero in their own way, all it takes is a leap of faith to succeed as well
a few side villains could have been cut and it was disappointing most of the footage from the trailers didnt make the final cut
still, SONY and Marvel seem to be on a the right track and I'm very happy they're still moving forward making more side stories and spinoffs :)

Into the Spider-Verse looks amazing. I've seen combinations of two- and three-dimensional animation before, but not anything like this. The movie is very colorful and makes excellent use of action. The whole thing is supposed to look like a comic book and has some wildly creative ideas, including color slightly popping off the lines and thought captions and bubbles. This movie takes place in an alternate reality from more traditional Spider-Man timelines, giving the creators liberty to come up with some inventive visual twists on classic Spider-Man villains without feeling like real betrayals to the characters.

Now, the movie does have a couple things that I adjusted to but may bug people with more sensitive eyes. As mentioned, the color is off-line and the background in particular can be blurry-looking. The motion frame rate is a little jerky, which I assume is a stylistic choice.

The plot is equally impressive. The film features Spider-Men from multiple dimensions and multiple other characters yet manages balance and develop them all almost seamlessly. (Wouldn't have minded a little more time on Mile's relationship with his uncle, but that's a minor issue.) The comedy and drama is equally good. The movie has fun, but there are also stakes. There is real loss in this. (Parents who are more selective in what their children watch, may consider this more of a "big boy" film).

The movie stars Spider-Man Miles Morales (voiced by Shameik Moore), who started off in Marvel's Ultimate comic line. He became popular enough that when the Ultimate universe was shut down, because Ultimate Spider-Man was the only real big seller, he was transferred to the main Marvel line. Hardcore Peter Parker fans may be upset that he isn't the star, but they did such a great job with Miles' character that I don't think you'll mind. He is likable and has personal issues like Peter, but in his own unique way. He forms a mentor relationship with a down-on-his-luck and world-weary Peter Parker (New GIrl's Jake Johnson), and the two of them have great chemistry and basically make the movie.

This is one of those truly innovative steps in moviemaking and a sincere homage to comic books.

To take a burned-out genre with an overdone character and make something truly unique that not only stands on its own but elevates a medium in a way I've never seen is an impressive feat, and that's exactly what this film does. It feels fresh, it's fun, it's emotional. It draws you into the world and uses animation intelligently in how it tells the story. It's not only my favorite Spider-Man incarnation - it's my favorite animated movie of the year, it's probably my favorite superhero movie of the year, and it might just be my favorite movie of the year. Highly recommend if this type of movie even remotely piques your interests.

This movie treats it's subject material with the proper seriousness, but the underlying, irreverent humor that is the heart of Spider-Man is shot through the entire production.  Basically look at the Wolverine movies for "serious/grimdark" and the Adam West Batman show for the complete opposite end of the spectrum.
Spider-Verse plonks itself down in a nice, comfortable median spot between the two and just works it for all it's worth.

The art style is great for the chosen medium.  VERY immersive, though a few scenes you can tell were prepped for 3D conversion (I see stuff in standard 2D because 3D causes me eye strain and headaches).  But, overall, it worked just fine.

The voice acting in here was so transparent and just fit.  So much so that praising it would require me to point out areas of inconsistency where there really weren't any.

All in all, a marvelously put-together film.

I'll be going to actually see it again.

Fresh. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-verse is admirably familiar and new. The several twists compared to films past make this one a Spider-man for the modern generation.  Miles Morales is important for who he is as a movie lead. The animation is sharp and works particularly well in 3D, reminding me of the best of The Incredibles.  The art here pops, and in the last act there are some particularly notable âheroâ? shots. The voice cast work is strong with Shameik Moore giving us a very sympathetic Miles Morales. Jake Johnson is terrific as a more dad-bod leaning alternate Peter B Parker. Liev Shreiber as Kingpin, Brian Tyree Henry as Milesâ(TM) dad Jefferson, and even Nicholas Cage as Spider-man Noir bring a lot to this interpretation. I gotta admit the anime and Warner-Bros cartoon â~verse jolted me out of plot for a minute, but eventually even they get smoothed back into the mix.  Screenplay author Phil Lord as well as the trio of directors show a love and respect for the source materials. There is the MCU-esque load of humor we have come to expect. Spidey Mileâ(TM)s and Kingpinâ(TM)s ultimate slugfest may not have been all that enlightening or satisfying. If nothing else, it feels good to see the first Stan Lee cameo (of sorts) since his passing.

PROS:
- Points for originality.  The mashups of all mashups!
- comraderie between Parker and Morales was well done, if buried sometimes.  The escape from the Hudson lab was very well done and had me in stitches for most of it.
SO SO:
- Visual style was unique, but distracting.  The ending especially was too much flashy bright lights.  If I was a teenager that read a bunch of comic books, I would be thrilled.  As an adult it just looked off.
- spider-reboot - how many reboots of Spider Man do we really need?
- the movie was entertaining to watch, but felt like it went on too long - especially the ending battle scene.
CONS:
- too much going on at once.  I counted no fewer than 7 spider people, and an array of baddies - whenever there are an array of baddies, that means no baddie is good enough to stand on their own, and that felt true here.  And 'Here is my story...' gets old after a couple of tellings.
- And the theme of 'Anyone could be spider man' seems to me contradictory to the Spider Man (original) world.  What did most people who got power do in the Spider Man world?  Become a baddie.  Here, anyone can get bitten and become Spider Man including Spider Man's girlfriend, an Anime character and a pig.  Not that that isn't funny, but at some point it just gets ridiculous. 
- Of course there is the 'Luke I am your Father' scene with the uncle, but what could have been a major antagonist plot theme became a short 5 minute throwaway scene (in fairness, the Uncle Ben death scene wasn't long either, but there was no big reveal there)
- the new Spider Man has to have black street cred or something.  From being a tagger to wearing untied sneakers, he must certainly resonate with the youth... or something.  At least they had the decency to make Morales upright and not morally conflicted, but it just seemed like pandering.  Although who knows?  Maybe when Lee wrote Spider Man back in the 60s, he was catering to nerds?  But now that he is NOT a nerd, I guess Aunt May has to act as Q?
- Look, if you are going to create a new character, do it.  Spider girl, or spider pig, or black spider or whatever.  To go through the motions of killing off spider man and then taking his place - it felt forced and distasteful.

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse Review: Into the Spider-Verse is a new Sony animated movie about Miles Morales, a Spider-Man, who discovers multiple versions of Spider-Man from different dimensions after an experiment gone wrong. I absolutely love Spider-Man. He is my favorite character of all time so I was super excited for this. I loved Into the Spider-Verse! Everything was definitely thought through very carefully, taking into consideration all the comics and backstories for each character. The story was amazing. It was trippy and just fantastic. It wasn’t really predictable for the most part which is really good. The voice acting was really good. Shameik Moore as Miles was by far the best part. His emotion was really good and you could feel for him like you knew Miles. Jake Johnson as Peter B. Parker was really good. I thought that Spider-Man was funny and just enjoyable. Mahershala Ali as Uncle Aaron was very good. Mahershala is just a really good actor and if was cool to hear him voice acting. Brian Tyree Henry player Jefferson Davis and he was a great voice actor for Miles’s father. All the characters had great development. There were three Spider-Men that came later on that I really liked but didn’t have too much exposition on them, but it made sense for them not to have to much. Throughout the film when we meet all the Spider-Men they do exposition on them and they do it in a comedic way and for those three they didn’t need to go too deep so it worked. Also the villain of the story, King Pin, had a great design and looked like a good villain but he kind of failed a little. I could see his views after his backstory was revealed but I wanted just a little more out of him. This film had some of the best animation I’ve ever seen. They made it like a comic book and it looked beautiful. Also the movie is a bit trippy so some of the scenes were just beautiful looking. I could talk about this movie for a long while but I don’t want to get into spoilers. If you love Marvel and Spider-Man there is no way to be disappointed. I would recommend it for sure. It’ll be nominated for Best Animated Feature for the Oscars (it was nominated for the Golden Globes). It’s now hard to say if this or Incredibles 2 will win. This movie has higher ratings but Incredibles 2 is Disney and they almost always win. Once again see it! I absolutely loved Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse!!! My Grade: A

First of all, I love the animation style in this film. The animation in this film is styled to look like an actual comic book. I think this approach for this kind of film was an excellent choice because we've all seen the usual kind of animation but nothing like this. To tie in with the animation I need to talk about the action scenes in this film. These tie in with the animation because of the way the directors styled the action shots is to look like something in a comic panel. Most people don't know who Miles Morales is and after this film, you'll want to learn more about him because of how they made him so relatable in this film. He acts like a typical teen in this situation compared to other versions of Spider-Man. Other versions kind of just acted like they always knew how to use their powers when Miles struggles with his. Miles isn't the only relatable character film all of them are. The creators of this film did a "Marvel"ous job at making each character in this film somebody at least one person in the audience can relate to. All of the voice actors did a great job in their respected roles but it would've been nice to have a returning voice to at least one of the Spider-Man. It would've been cool to hear a returning voice even if it was for a few seconds. I have to talk about the humour in this film. It isn't overpowered in this film and I felt like it had just the right amount of humour that will make everybody laugh. They poke fun of things that wouldn't make sense in a real movie and other Spider-Man movies. Not a single moment in this film felt rushed or slowed down every scene felt the right pace for a movie like this. The cinematography in this movie was spectacular. This is probably because of it looking like a comic book and how the lighting needs to match up with how it would look in an actual book. If you are a comic book junkie you'll love all of the easter eggs in this film. Some of them just comic book readers will get but others a majority of people will understand. The music in this film is fantastic. Every song in this film isn't overused and matches perfectly with the age of the character. Somebody Miles age would be listening to the type of music he listens to. And the music without lyrics helps increase the emotion in the film. Also, there are two end credit scenes that are worth waiting for. In the end, this film is perfect for everybody. I give Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse a 10/10.

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse What starts off as a typical Spider-Man origin story (a surprisingly original one at that) quickly descends into trip down a rabbit hole of pure chaotic madness that results in one of the most spectacular, if not a tad over-ambitious, movies of the year. Incredibles 2 is the best animated movie of the year, there’s no question and no debating that. However, Into the Spider-Verse May just be the best animated film. This movie is truly unlike anything you’ve ever seen before. The only other comic book movies I can think of where they felt like they were ripped straight from the pages are the Sin City and 300 movies. And considering those movies were live action as opposed to animated is high praise for this movie. I tend to throw around the word ‘unique’ when describing any movie, but in this case, I can’t think of a better word to describe this film. It is unique. I had always heard whispers of the character Miles Morales, famous for being a mixed race iteration of the iconic Marvel hero. But it wasn’t until this movie that I realized just how much of an extraordinary character he is. He’s smart, relatable, and even more powerful than Peter Parker in some aspects. He carries this insane movie from start to finish and you’re always rooting for him. I not only expect to see more of Morales in the future, I anticipate it! As I’ve said, the animation in this movie is nothing like you’ve ever seen before. When I heard Sony animation was doing an animated Spider-Man movie my first thought was, “Oh great! Sony’s further capitalizing on its Spider-Man brand by showing Peter Parker dance to James Brown in animated form”. Thankfully that is far from the case here. Though don’t put it past this movie to not include a few self-deprecating sight gags. The animation here is quite similar to stop motion, in the sense that it’s not supposed to feel as clean cut as Pixar and DreamWorks. There are several moments in this movie where it feels like a frame or two has been taken out to further establish the illusion that you’re watching a series of comic book panels come to life. It’s a remarkable aesthetic, though it can at times feel a bit distracting to someone who may not be prepared for what they’re about to get from this movie. There were times where I actually found myself wondering if the theater projectionist had accidentally switched the movie with a 3-D print. There are moments inter-spliced throughout the film where the image looks double with one side red and the other side green. It wasn’t until after I saw the movie that I realized this was intentional. Which is interesting for sure, but if you’re seeing this movie, which I still highly suggest you do, and you have a pair of old red and blue 3-D glasses on hand, I recommend you take them along just in case. This is my only real issue with the movie and it’s part of the reason why the movie feels like it over extends itself to some degree. The visuals and animation in this movie are so colorful and so eye-popping that it’s easy to get lost in the sheer spectacle of it all. There’s a moment about thirty minutes in where there is so much being thrown at you at once that you find yourself wondering if you’re really watching what you think you’re watching. From that moment onward the movie looks and feels like something Lewis Carol would piece together had he been an artist for Marvel comics. It’s no understatement that Sony Animation has had a rough climb up to now. They’ve had a few decent hits (2006’s Open Season) and more than enough epic misfires (last year’s Emoji Movie). Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is without question their best film yet. As a matter of fact, seeing as Disney, Pixar, and DreamWorks dominate the computer animated league, Laika has stop motion, and Studio Ghibli will continue to use classic 2-D, Sony should seriously consider making more movies like Into the Spider-Verse. This kind of stylized, meta-humor filled, animated comic book spectacle is a great niche for the company. And while their live action Spider-Man fare will most likely continue down a more mindless entertainment route like Venom, a movie like Into the Spider-Verse can really establish the company as a tent pole animation studio the same way that Toy Story and Snow White put Pixar and Disney on the map in their respective times. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is a great movie. It’s visually spectacular, absolutely hilarious, quite moving at times, and it acts as a brilliant showcase for Miles Morales as a character and for Sony Animation’s capability as a legit studio in league with Disney and Pixar. My only issues being that the spectacle overwhelms the story and character development at times. But people must have had similar complaints about Toy Story when that movie first premiered. And look where we are now. In time, Into the Spider-Verse will most certainly be regarded as an unprecedented animated classic. A- ****1/4

The minds behind The Lego Movies and the company that made the Emoji Movie are back and gives us a heartfelt animated movie that boasts it's unique and charming animation style and a story that nicely unfolds. Instead of having Peter Parker be the lead, Miles Morales makes his big screen debut which is both funny and emotional and intriguing and investing. Due to the fast paced and well written story, we are transported into his universe that tells a Spider-Man origin story unlike any other. Miles is a very investing character due to his relationships and personality, he contains powers that the other Spider-People do not therefore he is a very tantalizing character for the audience, presenting us with a different kind of hero; this film shows us that a Spider-Man movie can work without Peter Parker in the main role. His origin is actually more relatable and engaging than most superheroes and withstands fantastic character development. That said the other Spider-People are just as fun as Miles, who all have their own special abilities that are exciting and fresh. The standout supporting hero here is Spider-Ham, giving us a more humorous and irreverent character which is always a joy on screen especially when he is oblivious to his surrounding in this new dimension. However, Spider-Noir is a welcome addition to the cast but deserved a more in depth arc. But apart from our heroes there are a lot more juicy things here to easily titillate. The animation is one of them which is extremely fresh and is a unique style that has never been tried before and really shows off the fact that it's essentially a comic book that has come to life. There are bundle loads of Easter Eggs including call backs to the original films (and a recreation of the infamous Emo Dance) and the original 60's books which sometimes help navigate Miles' responsibilities as Spider-Man and what he can do with his newfound capabilities, this concept will please all Spidey fans including myself. Other things worth noting is the voice work as it is extremely well said and each voice actor suits there character with Shameik Moore providing an exceptionally good vocal performance as Miles, and the humour which is witty and slick and the laugh out loud jokes are frequent and doesn't take away the tonal consistency and there are a few emotional scenes in the film and the dialogue between some characters pulls on the heart-strings as well as some surprising plot twists. Finally, the action sequences soar and bounce off the screen and are intense as well as visually stunning and the costume design is basically awesome. 

This Spider-Flick doesn't go completely unscathed though. Kingpin was a terrible villain with poor motivations and an awful character design, he did turn out as a cliche villain unfortunately. The ending did get a bit too predictable and I would of liked a lot of depth and detail to the story and I would of liked more screen time with the supporting heroes e.g. Spider-Ham, Spider-Noir, Spider-Gwen and Peni Parker. As the film progressed it seemed like it was going faster than it should of been going. But overall, Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse will seem like Christmas for the long-term Spider-Man fans. It tells a perfect Spider-Man story which includes a strong lead hero and an unique style of animation; even though Kingpin was a terrible villain, our terrific heroes make up for it. This new comic book film is essentially the don't miss movie this winter and exceeded my expectations. Sony has finally proven that they are capable of producing a near perfect Spidey feature which is a breath of fresh air, considering the fact that Spider-Man is a character who has been rebooted several times onto the big screen. A spinoff and a sequel are in the works and I'm not going to shy away from the fact that I'm excited for them, especially after the result of this film.

Sony hasn't exactly been kind to the Spider-Man universe and its lore the last couple of years since Sam Raimi (gracefully) decided to call quits on continuing his series of films after Spider-Man 3 was essentially forced to be finished by Sony due to creative disagreements. And since then a failed (and deserved tbh) rebooted series, iffy and bad spin-off to a well utilized villain, and refusing to give just in general the rights back to the character to Marvel haven't necessarily been in favour to the studio (not even counting what happened with Ghostbusters and their comedy films.) So suffice to say I wasn't, very worried how despite how surprisingly blown away I was by the animation from the marketing material for this film came along I wasn't, still worried as hell (and Sony Animation? You mean the same people of The Emoji Movie? *Shudders* no please god no.) But then the names of Phil Lord and Chris Miller (two duo directors i've heavily respected and enjoyed from The Lego Movie and One High) were attached, with Phil taking screenwriting credit and Chris producing, and suddenly I felt myself get a bit excited given their talent. And once the marketing got me assured that this wasn't being completely tampered by Sony, I kept my excitement and finally got to see the film finally. And seeing it the first time I came out of it feeling " a bit underwhelmed that this didn't grab me as much as I hoped it would", I think after another re-watch I can say while that may ring still, I'm still happy to say that it's still a damn fun ride that does manage to FINALLY add and give Spider-Man fans (myself included) another nice iteration of the universe.

As before with having some personal gripes on how some of the story was handled, I can say now that while being very great to its core, some things that did hold me back from enjoying it fully with small issues ike dialogue often feeling a bit weirdly forced in exposition from time to time, personal preference of some of the rap songs feeling really pointless and forced (still the Sony ones, except Sunflower), and a personal preference worth mentioning for using for the sequel: missing A HUGE chance to give the film some more runtime and pacing (Ala Lego Movie) with the alternative Peter Parker (and Gwen's especially) to help tie into the arc to Miles, and only one major issue with unfortunately a lot of the pacing of  hurting some of the scripts story and clear emotional moments and as a result can make especially Miles story just a tad underwhelming. But other than that, I'm happy to report that the team involved with the Spiderverse material really put a lot of heart and soul with absolutely no-duh beautiful and sometimes jaw-breaking animation that really is a first and rather than feeling pretentious adds so much character to Spidey as a whole it just goes without saying to mention its amazing, a very solid script courtesy of Phil Lord and Rodeny Rothman that shows a lot of just great wit but especially understanding to emotional weight and investment that sure has its hiccups due to its pacing still shines through when it does work, the themes and especially its emotional impact when it's presented in the story feeling genuinely engaging, speaking of which the character work for Miles especially working so well being a re-work of his origin story and emotionally all the way just works so well and I loved every second of it, all of its goofy but yet especially serious tone and even mature character work working so beautifully well, a very surprisingly well oriented score that actually probably gives some of my favourite Spider-Man music since Danny Elfman's, all of its cast really owning their roles very well (especially Shameik Moore's Miles who despite not even being a darn kid like gets the feel of the character so surprisingly well on top of Jake Johnson's typical but still off-beat performance and Hailee Steinfield unrecognizable but great work on Gwen; its clear they put a lot of work and feeling to their characters.)

So goes without saying that Into the Spider-Verse is definitely a great ride, and definitely this time around feeling much more impactful and entertaining with a second watch. And while it may not be something i'll see myself ALL the time going back to due to its very minor but weird inconsistencies, still for what we got it's a great rendition and take on all of Spider-Man that it ain't worth missing out on, so definitely check this out when you can and give it some love (even if it IS Sony) cause it definitely deserves it! Oh and all I can say is if you enjoy a lot of the inside joke memes of Spider-Man, just all I can say is stay till the end credits. I promise you won't be disappointed.

There are so many things I can say about this film. I was completely blown away by the outrageous fun I had during my viewing. Still, there's far more to this movie than a mindless escape. There was the incredibly unique animation style, truly bringing the wonderfully ridiculous nature of comic books to life on the big screen. The complex story was simplified into a comprehendible narrative, told in a remarkably entertaining, amusing, and self-aware fashion.
From there, you had the rich soundtrack perfectly complimenting the style and themes. On top of all this, there was deep character development, palpable emotion, and true, honest life lessons, derived from none other than the late Stan Lee. This is perhaps on par with any other Spider-Man movie ever created, if not even above their caliber. The following quote, included in the credits perfectly sums up the film: "That person who helps others simply because it should or must be done, and because it is the right thing to do, is indeed, without a doubt, a real superhero." - Stan Lee
It always fits, eventually.

I can't begin to describe how much I loved this movie. I came in the theaters with high expectations and came out with every one of them exceeded. It was the most visually stunning film I had ever seen, and the voice-acting, script, and storyline was so perfect. I'm a comic book nerd and I was extremely pleased by how loyal they kept withwith source material, and spent time to develop each of the spider-people without slowing down the pace of the story. I also liked seeing subtle references toward the Spider-Verse comics such as the Web-Warriors Jeep in the Spidey-Lair. 
Though I'm a nerd and enjoyed it, this movie isn't just for nerds, and don't think it's just a soft kid movie. It is extremely dark in some parts, and can work for basically all audiences to enjoy. The dark elements weren't too dark for kids, though, so it's a great film that every kid and adult to enjoy! I can't thank the creators enough for their hard work and how much life they put into these comics. It is definitely my favorite Marvel movie so far, and I don't think it can easily be beat. I'm giving it a  5/5 star rating and I highly recommend seeing this. It is totally worth it!

Growing up, I grew an appreciation for the character of Spider-Man that I've never been able to develop for any other comic book character. It was Sam Raimi's original live-action trilogy that hooked me and had me scrounging for more. Watching countless episodes of every cartoon iteration, and even starting to read a few of the comics, I found myself becoming a huge fan of this generational icon. Once Spider-Man 3 hit theatres, the character had lost all hope on the big screen, until Andrew Garfield took the role from Tobey Maguire, which didn't last too long, and also crashed and burned. Finally, he found his footing in the Marvel Cinematic Universe, played by Tom Holland, but none of that matters when watching Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse. Not only is this the best that this character has been in a while, but I believe there's a real argument to made that this is possibly the greatest feature-length film based on this character, period.

In this film, which is loosely based off of storylines that are very similar to how this movie plays out, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse follows Miles Morales as he's bitten by a radioactive spider and develops the same (and more) powers as his hero, Spider-Man. After an event opens a portal, it's revealed that his universe isn't the only one. There are endless dimensions out there with parallel characters and creatures, all with similar backstories. From Spider-Gwen to Spider-Ham, this film explores the classics as well as the bizarre, which I fear will probably turn off some average moviegoers who haven't experienced these characters yet, but if you can't embrace a film like that, it's probably not for you anyways.

From the very first teaser trailer, I was very intrigued by the look of this film and how different it looked from most animated films out there today. With only a couple of notable films in Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs and Arthur Christmas, Sony Pictures hasn't had the best track record in terms of releasing animated movies theatrically. Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse has given new life to that notion, because this isn't only the best they've ever produced in my opinion, but it's the best animated movie that has come out all year. The unique style leaps off the screen and made me find another layer to love, on top of the fantastic storyline and characters surrounding it.

Yes, the origin story of Peter Parker is the one that everyone knows. That is very much present here again, and nearly every one of these characters share similar backgrounds, but it feels as though the filmmakers expect the audience to be in on the joke of that. This movie is very meta at times, and it works very well if you're invested in the movie as a whole. At the emotional core of this movie is how these characters differ from one another and how certain circumstances can be worse than others. There are some fantastic life lessons to be learned by children here, and for that, I only loved this movie even more.

In the end, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse impressed me on many levels. It gives you the Spider-Man action that you've come to expect from this character, as well as giving new life to it. The character of Miles Morales has just as many layers to his story as the classic Peter Parker one, but the inclusion of each one of the side characters here fleshes him out even more. This is one of the best superhero origin stories I've seen on the big screen in years. Filled with heart, emotion, plenty of action, and eye-candy as far as the eye can see, Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is one of my favourite films of the year.

Absolutely incredible film with an extremely touching story, fantastic characters, a great ï¿ 1/2leave on repeatï¿ 1/2Â? soundtrack, and animation that will blow your mind. I had high hope for the film and left the theater still totally blown away. The perfect pacing makes the entire movie feel almost like an adrenaline shot that keeps you entertained and laughing the entire time. Mixed with heart felt, tear jerking moments, and excellently written character arcs, Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse raises the bar for *all* animated movies and makes others before it seem pale in comparison.

Sony has a track record for some hits and A LOT of misses when it comes to Marvel and Spider-man movies. 

So I was on the fence with Venom and for me it was an Okay type of movie. And I will be honest, I was VERY Biased when it comes to the trailer of this movie; and being that Amy Pascal (2016 Ghostbuster's fame) is the first name you see when the movie starts was very Jarring to me. And after seeing the first two trailers while i enjoyed the visual artwork I guess because Sony has a habit of showing EVERYTHING in their trailers I was apprehensive about this movie; it was after watching, 'Venom' and the end credits and the 15 mins trailer I figured I owe it to myself to keep an open mind and go see this movie even if it was another cash-grab.......

......I have to honestly eat crow. Cause Spider-man: Into the spider verse...is by far and away the BEST visually, original, emotional and fun movie animated movie I've seen in a while since Lego batman and Lego movie and all three are written by Phil Lord. 

The writing is snappy and fun, the movie has a lot of heart. The origin to Miles Morales while a tad different than the comic version (Just a tad); is still enjoyable to watch...and Miles himself is such an endearing character his dynamic to the other Spider-people and his family had me grinning from ear to ear and I was surprised to find out who voiced Spider-Noir as well as Kingpin, etc. 
They don't shy away from telling you what happen to Spider man in Miles's universe and there's a lot of emotional tear jerking moments that while for some other movies it would seem forced but in this it seems to be part of the course. Off the bat you know Miles life is very different from Peter parker's life but the same at the same time. Then there's Peter B. Parker...the 'What happens when Spider man just let himself go" voiced by Jake Johnson the chemistry between Miles and Peter is one of hilarity but also holds the emotional weight when they work together to fix each others lives in more ways than one. And adding on to this is the amazing soundtrack that matches the feel of Brooklyn life and while there's some hits and misses my favorite is, "What's up Danger" as Miles step into his destiny as the new Spider-man it gives me goosebumps when you hear it as he comes to terms being the hero he was meant to be. 

If you're wondering would i get lost in the majority of the story? simple answer is no. Not only they give you each introduction but they do it in a way in which you will fully understand their backgrounds. This is catered for both kids as well as adults (mostly for adults at times) but just as fun for kids too. 

There's a lot I want to say but saying it would spoil the movie and I don't want to do that. Visually this is one of the best looking animated movie that uses the idea of your old school comic book and I would love this movie to win an award for best animation and music. 
the Easter eggs and cameos are both fun and emotional cause when you see a certain cameo it made me tear up a bit (actually a lot) but It was a good way of solidifying his immortality. 
I can honestly say i would love to see this movie again. I would love to get this movie on Digital or 4k when it comes to it; I would love to see a sequel to this movie cause there's so many set ups they can do with this (Superior Spider-man anyone?) and stay for the post credit scene cause it had me in tears (Laughing) at possibilities for other movies. 

It seems Spider-man found its footing. MCU, PS4, and now in Animated form. Can't wait to see what they can do with this.

Bar far, the standout for this film is the animation style. You can really tell that Sony let go of the reins and let Sony Imageworks have fun. It is equal parts pop art, expressionism, street art and comic book style art with a liberal use of Bed Day dots and though bubbles and fantastic details that will be enjoyed by children and adults alike. Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse does everything right. Honestly. It knew exactly what it was and delivered on it. We know Peter Parker, MJ, Aunt May and the rest of the Parker social circle. We don't need that to be beaten into our heads again and it knew that. It connects the dots without showing you the process of running the string. What I love is how much it truly understood what it was. It moved quickly and got us into the action but knew just how much information to give you so you knew what was going on and enough so you can look up more later. The way it brought the Spider-Family together and gave them personality so quickly is really a testament to the art style, film direction and the way it told the store. I actually got choked up in a scene and I just met these characters an hour ago.

I honestly believe this is the first step in what can be a truly robust and fleshed out franchise for Sony. The team they put on this knew just what we needed and it wasn't more high school Peter Parker. We have one and he's doing a great job and his next story is around the corner; so let's highlight a new range of characters in the same universe. Well not actually the same universe; the whole multi-verse thing is at play after all. I want to see more of this and it looks like they know that.

I have a feeling they know how much ass they just kicked and they plan on kicking some more.

Feel free to not read this but non spoiler spark notes of into the spider verse So I was worried about seeing this film as I thought it was going to be a hate all white people black power film as the director said some questionable things However I am very pleased to say this is just an amazing film. It’s actually my favorite Spider-Man film and this is the most comic booky movie I’ve ever seen. Like idk how to describe it without spoiling it but it really does feel super comic book style. I was worried I was going to hate spider Gwen. With her punk hair I thought she was going to be super gay and all EUGH! Men! Respect my vagina! I am beyond relieved that she was an amazing character. She actually was one of my favorite characters in the film I’d say she, Miles, and Peter are easily the most relatable characters and it’s so easy to love them and route for them. I also really loved Nicholas cage as Noir Spider-Man. Honestly this movie is one of the funniest superhero films I’ve ever seen with actual jokes. Not baby humor we see in the MCu. Like actual time and effort was put into these jokes Not OoohooOOooo he fell down! What a silly clown! OooooOO does the baby love that joke??? Oopsie he bumped his head now? Does the baby love that joke?? More like actual real humor. Course this movie is also considerably dark as in it’s a serious gritty film not all comedic. I also could relate with the villain and I thought they did an amazing job with the villain. After black Panther I was worried it’s impossible to have a black comic book movie that isn’t all about black power! Ans spending the entire film hating on white people. I am so so so glad there were no politics in this film. No politics no SJW just an amazing film. This isn’t a black movie. It’s a comic book movie. It’s a Spider-Man movie. It doesn’t matter if Spider-Man happens to be black or white. They are different people. They each identify themselves as their own unique person and they are defined by exactly that. Not their skin color I ended up loving Miles. This movie was sad sweet beautiful emotional. They did a amazing job with this film and I highly recommend it. Oh as a side note it was clearly made for 3D. I may be being very bias supporting this film so much. The colors may hurt your eyes depending on how good your vision is. I didn’t mind it but I also thought about this movie and felt like yeah I can see how this movie could really hurt your eyes depending on your vision After seeing this film I think a few things are clear. As South Park has joked, we can’t just get hung up over a tiny remark someone makes on Twitter. Maybe they aren’t a racist elitist like it seemed they were. My final remark about this film is this. I am now laughing my ass off because if this movie skyrockets as Venom did, that means no more Spider-Man for MCU. You can bet your ass Sony doesn’t like Disney and is looking for any excuse to yank away from Disney. If this movie explodes in sales while Disney is going super SJW with Carol MANvers, you can bet Sony is pulling all its content away from Disney and I can’t wait for the day that Disney loses Spider-Man to the company that made the Emoji Movie! This is easily the best Spider-Man movie I will ever see, not just "have seen". To achieve better would mean to take the sort of risk in live action (the parts that aren't CG animated) that is easily afforded to animation. It's part-origin, part-zillionth-sequel, part-spoof, and all experiment gone wild. It's a superhero movie that knows it's one while still feeling fresh, allowing a singular perspective to guide the story, and it is highly deceptive, frontloading the proceedings with comedy, only to clobber the viewer with naturally occuring drama from seemingly out of nowhere. By creating consistent parallels between the Spider-Heroes, it lays a clear path as to what Miles must ultimately submit to according to Spider-Hero logic: one step forward, too many steps back.

This does come with a caveat however, one I've theorized for quite a long time: while emulating the aspects of a superhero comic book in its mad dash of a runtime, this movie posits an obvious superiority as an adaptation, which serves as a lament toward graphic storytelling in general. Usually in an action comic, actions and dialogue occupy the same space with mere regard to telling the most economic story at the behest of pacing and impact. In many instances, there are entire panels filled with spoken dialogue, inner narration, and exposition blocks, sometimes simultaneously. I can't help but to feel that this clutter is a prime cause as to why superhero comics remain a niche market (although manga tends to have much better regard toward these issues, mainly because most of it is geared to be adapted to anime). This movie knows when to tell and when to show.

I haven't heard rap used this effectively in film since Above the Rim, accenting the variety of the proceedings as part-score. As for the other part-score, Pemberton is more than up for the challenge, between the growling motif for Prowler, the dextrous synchronicity during the Spider-Cave sequence, and many more cues. If he devotes his work solely to animation, he's got an instant fan right here.

I can only hope that Ralph Bakshi gets a gander at the post-credit sequence.

Spider-Man Into The Spider-Verse

Marvel's sci-fi diverse superhero flick is more than a flung news, infinitely stretched over the narrow streets, it is set in a known universe; home, New York. Endorsing its ownself into a comical idea that jumpstarts this cat and mouse chase is less promising and more exciting. The first act involves your usual teenage drama that feels like an indie film, a surprising take by Marvel. But all this trickery is shattered pretty much in its first few minutes, as this visual galore swings you like a toddler and you are beames back into your childhood memories.

This vision of yours is too shattered by the makers by complicating the linear humane tale into a labyrinthe of dual identities that keeps multiplying like an algorithm which keeps you at the brisk of your seat and challenges you to stay with the storytelling. And this is where the makers shine, despite of being gifted a plethora of tracks or ideas and being free of all logistics, they have sticked to an arguably a simpler one that is constructed well enough for the audience to nod along. Similar to any other animated feature, it makes it more juicy due to its tied hands, the conflicts that the lead characters are piled upon is what makes it electrifying.

But this is Lord's world at some point. And his pacing vocab can easily be pointed out in here. Similar to The Lego Movie, there are too many characters to adore on screen and each of them trying to whirl you around with their hilarious innuendos or their own sub-plots or pointing out the obvious on the stage. It is the Lego phase all over again. You are too overwhelmed at times, to enjoy it thoroughly. You are too busy to catch up with what's going on that you do feel left out.

There is a sense of incompetency in the air, ironically due to overstuffed material. And this is something that can itch to few viewers as you feel being cheated. Personally, I enjoy such narration, it challenges me to push my boundaries and snaps at me on every frame for my attention. The action is more "cool" than it is smart, the artists are stealing the awe struck moments as much as they can. And with a new smooth visual effects like such, they do add the literal transcript on screen and the infamous comic sound effects written out aloud in front of you.

The voice cast has done a decent work but there isn't much for them to factor than few show stealing one liners that stay with you, even after the curtains are dropped for long; the Spider-Man Noir learning the colors on cube still cracks me up. But amidst all these glossy distraction there is, the theme, the gist, is still the same old drama, no matter what Peter says in here, I am going to complete the sentence, "With great powers comes great responsibilities." Spider-Man Into The Spider-Verse is a family drama that swings its way out to create that arc into a full circle.

They say they save the best for last. This is certainly the case. To be honest I wasn't really keen on an animated spider-man movie, but wow did this movie blow me away.  

The animations in the movie were nothing I've seen before in cinema, blending comic -book style graphics into modern animation with masterful seemlessness. The movie threads a fine line between being realistic and being outlandish, and  it works. The story does a good job of knowing when to be humorous and fun, while also not taking away from parts where it has to be serious. Come to think of it, the movie kind of resembles Homecoming, where the movie is less about saving the world, but more about spider-man himself. All the characters are also well developed towards the end, which adds to the enjoyment. Fun, emotional and thoroughly enjoyable, Spider-Man: Into The Spider-Verse is all I could've wanted in a movie to close out the year, and is definitely one of the best (if not the best) movies this year.

This film just may be my favorite film of the year right now, no doubt. Everything I wanted and so much more, from the story, the characters, right down to the stellar animation. The animation here is flawless, a comic book brought to life - the thought and speech bubbles, the panel transitions and grainy style at times, perfection. Seriously this story is so full of charm and heart, and the best part is that Miles' journey isn't rushed at all. This isn't a long film, but it still takes its time to give the main characters their narrative arcs. There are some excellent comedic moments, wonderful easter eggs to search for, and of course a heartwarming cameo by Stan Lee.

The entire voice cast is remarkable as well - Shameik Moore, Jake Johnson as Peter, Hailee Steinfeld as Gwen, Mahershala Ali, Liev Schreiber, and so so many more! There are so many surprise voice cameos that I won't spoil here, look them up if you're interested but they are definitely pleasant surprises. I definitely plan on catching this one again, in 3D next time for sure. PLEASE check it out, and stay thru those credits until the very end, for a mindblowing post-credits scene!

SPIDER-MAN: INTO THE SPIDERVERSE.

At just under 2 hours...it's not bad, it has a good flow, but it was...a bit too, um, busy for my taste. The schizophrenic hyper-comic style left me a bit distracted, but I was still able to follow the story, despite it.

The voice cast did a good job, working well off each other, while also providing memorable characters in their own right. The heroes & side cast really breathed life & humanity into a bunch of cartoon characters, got me invested in their stories. The villains...well, the main villains got me to invest, the rest of them...were video game bosses. Not to say they were bad! They just...coulda had more depth maybe?

The animation style, as I said, schizo-hyper-comic. But, as the plot involved the breakdown of the multi-verse, it kinda worked(?).

The music was a mix of classic Spidey, & sorta modern hood. Which, again, kinda worked(?).

Over all, Into the Spiderverse wasn't bad, I mean, I had no problem with an ethnic Spidey, but the whole thing was just too busy, a sensory overload that left me dizzy. 3 stars outta 5, I don't know, maybe I'm too old, I just thought it shoulda slowed down a bit & given us more time to breath.

December 14, 2018

"Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" is a bright, edgy and imaginative adventure-bold, bustling and alive, all in a safe, mainstream-superhero-movie sort of way. From its pulsating first frame, it's easy to tell the film's three directors, Bob Perischetti, Peter Ramsey and Rodney Rothman, have only love and affection for the their titular hero and what he stands for, although they also know he should be capable of evolving, and with this inaugural computer-animated version of the legendary figure, they've taken what will hopefully be the first step toward a Spider-Man movie that's everything "Into the Spider-Verse" is only less safe. For now, though, we can bask in this one's notable risks and many achievements.

The risks I refer to include this being the first Spider-Man movie to feature a non-white and non-male version of the hero, not to mention a non-human. Following "Wonder Woman" and "Black Panther," this may not seem like such a big a deal, but given that Spider-Man is often viewed as the default and most exemplary superhero in popular culture, it makes the idea of them being more diverse all the more common and accepted.

This latest adaptation of Stan Lee and Steve Ditko's beloved Marvel Comics character, which is cheerfully aware of and recognizes all the previous live-action Spidey incarnations that have come before it, kicks off with Spider-Man/Peter Parker (voice of Chris Pine) giving us a quick recap of how he came to be (promptly summarizing the whole "radioactive spider thing") and bringing us up to speed on what he's doing now. At 26, he's married to Mary Jane Watson (Zoe Kravitz); is still saving New York City from utter devastation on a routine basis; has started his own product line; and is still fending off enemies, old and new.

One of his latest haters is a by-the-books, no-nonsense cop named Jefferson Davis (Brian Tyree Henry), who doesn't agree with Spidey's unorthodox crime-fighting methods. The opposite holds true for Jefferson's son, Miles (Shameik Moore), who will be the movie's chief protagonist. Miles secretly admires Spider-Man, having read the comics written about his true-life adventures. Deep down, perhaps Miles senses he and Spider-Man/Peter Parker aren't all that different from each other. After all, both are intellectually gifted yet socially insecure, although to us, Miles may have it even harder than Peter ever did because he's the son of an African-American father and Hispanic mother (Luna Lauren Velez), which, although the movie doesn't explicitly address this trait (or its social ramifications), we appreciate as one of the qualities that makes Miles a more unique character. 

Despite his academic talents, Miles hates the boarding school his parents send him to, which is just outside of his hometown of Brooklyn. He thinks it's elitist and being there makes him feel like he's betraying his own kind. He tries to get himself kicked out by deliberately failing, but his teachers see through him and won't let him.

Like many adolescents, Miles finds solace in making art, particularly spray-painting murals, and he's able to talk about his woes with his Uncle Aaron (Mahershala Ali), who watches over the kid but clearly has a dark side, which is probably why Miles' father and Aaron are estranged brothers. 

One night, Aaron takes Miles into the subway to paint and, wouldn't you know, down comes a radioactive spider (not unlike the one that found Peter) and bites him on the wrist. As the story goes, Miles begins to transform-his body grows; he develops a Spidey sense; and his fingers start to stick to things, including the hair of the girl he likes at school, who calls herself "Gwendola" (Hailee Steinfeld) and has a secret of her own.

The plot thickens once Miles makes contact with the original Spider-Man, who's in a heated battle with the Green Goblin and, shortly thereafter, the crime lord Kingpin (Liev Schreiber), who's built a giant mechanism that, for all intents and purposes, disrupts the time-space continuum and opens a portal to parallel universes (his motivation for constructing such a device is something I'll let you discover). Without giving too much of this increasingly layered plot away, Miles' own dimension suddenly becomes inhabited by five other Spider-People, including an older, out-of-shape and recently divorced Peter "B." Parker (Jake Johnson), who reluctantly becomes Miles' mentor; Spider-Gwen, the aforementioned female version of the hero; Peni Parker (Kimiko Glenn), a Japanese school girl who operates her own spider robot called "SP//dr"; Spider-Man Noir (Nicolas Cage), a dark version of Spider-Man who, with his black trench coat and fedora, resembles Rorschach from "The Watchmen"; and Peter Porker/Spider-Ham (John Mulaney), an anthropomorphic pig. Yes, a pig.

Research tells me each of these alternate versions of Spider-Man actually has his or her roots in various Spider-Man comics and/or video games, which surprised me because I just assumed they were created specifically for this film. Nevertheless, "Into the Spider-Verse" provides them each a worthy backstory and pools them together to thwart Kingpin and his chief engineer/partner-in-crime, Dr. Livia Octavius, a.k.a. Doc Ock (Kathryn Hahn). With so many characters and an impressively intricate plot, the movie is surprisingly coherent and builds into a rich, action-packed adventure with strong moments of character development; witty, self-deprecating humor; and even true, heartfelt emotion. "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" is nothing if not well-rounded.

The film's most striking feature, of course, is its animation, which is virtually boundless and allows the action to move with the kind of fluidity and freedom that only animation can provide. The filmmakers have utilized their resources to a full and mesmerizing degree, filling all corners of the screen with vibrant colors and often dazzling set pieces (as far as computer-animated set pieces go). And despite this being computer animation, the characters possess full weight and dimension, thanks in large part to the fitting and memorable voice casting, particularly Moore as Miles, Henry as Miles' father, and Ali as Uncle Aaron. They prove they don't just enliven live-action characters but have just as much presence as the voices of animated ones.

If I could change anything about "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse," it would be the main conflict, which, after an energetic setup, eventually settles on a mostly traditional superhero plot. You know the drill: the good guys must defeat the bad guys in a limited amount of time; and the main hero must learn to accept the things he cannot change, harness his powers, and rise above his own personal feelings and insecurities to fight for the greater good. This has become the sort of "go-to" Spider-Man story, which was my underlying problem with the otherwise fine "Spider-Man: Homecoming." And while I understand a big-budget animated feature such as this probably needed to tread familiar territory before it can venture too far on its own, I also couldn't help but think that with everything this film has at its disposal, both technically and casting-wise, it had potential to be a near-masterpiece, if only the plot taken more of a gamble and introduced problems to Miles and company that were less predictable. 

Still, I did appreciate the film for at least being aware of its own exhausted devices and tropes and how it even had the nerve to poke fun at some of them, including the famous, "With great power comes great responsibility" line. This attitude made me think that if the film does well enough and there's a sequel, the filmmakers will feel they can break new ground narratively as much as they have visually.

Regardless of my minor reservations about it, "Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse" is a splendid treat, and both ardent and casual fans of Spider-Man should find it thoroughly engaging, humorous and touching. It takes the cinematic incarnation of Spider-Man as we know it and points it in a much-needed newer direction, while at the same time it helps solidify the idea of diversity in mainstream superhero movies as the new norm. Above all, though, it's just enormously entertaining, and despite how prolific superhero movies have become, particularly those about Spider-Man, the filmmakers have not taken for granted the bare essentials it takes to make a good movie-name character, story and heart, all of which "Into the Spider-Verse" shows off to great effect.

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is a phenomenal animated superhero film. The voice acting is great. Shameik Moore was great as the lead. Each Spider-Man stands out in their own way. Nicolas Cage and John Mulaney in particular stood out. The film’s animation style is excellent. It’s unlike anything you’ve seen. It feels like a cinematic comic book. The writing is great. You are invested in Miles Morales’ story and you care. The action is great, and the film doesn’t feel like your typical origin story. Overall, this film was a blast. It’s unique and brilliant. I can’t wait to see more stories in this multiverse.

All of the other MCU films are superhero movies based on comics. This is truly a comic book movie. They even mess with the coloring, making many shots look vaguely unfocused or color shifted. I'm not a comic book guy, so I didn't know the other Spider-characters, but they were a hoot. My wife even laughed when I told her about Spider-Noir Man and the Rubik's cube. The outdoor action sequences are brilliantly inventive. I laughed out loud a few times when Miles was learning his skills, and when he and Peter B Parker were stuck to the elevated train. Inside the particle accelerator however, things got very muddied, so I have to take it down a half star. Otherwise, I loved it.

Some pretty dark elements for a PG movie, but overall a thoroughly exciting and enthralling Spider-Man movie that managed to be completely new and original while combining most elements of the first 5 films and several from comics and other media too.
Prowler is a real show stealer (which comic fans would never have predicted of this C-list villain) whenever he and his effects and music came on, the entire cinema held their breath and Miles Morales got such a strong showing in this, I'd gladly pay to see another Spider-verse starring him on the big screen!
All the villains were REALLY well designed (Dr. Ock is AMAZING...) Kingpin is finally done right! The first outing for Spider-Gwen was sweet and fun too.
Cartoony/corny Spider-Ham, Nic Cage (too famous a voice) and VERY graphic bloody murder were the only low points on an otherwise perfect film in almost every way!
Spider-verse brings joy, action, humor, and more to Spiderman characters and fans everywhere in the universe.

"Another Spider-Man movie," you ask? Get excited as 'Spider-Verse' breathes new life into our familiar friendly neighborhood hero. It is slickly and gorgeously animated in a way I have never seen Western cinema attempt before. This is the closest we will get to a comic book coming to life.

For a movie jam-packed with main characters, they find a fun and extremely efficient way to introduce them all without getting too repetitive or too dumbed-down. Minimal expositional dialogue gives way to creative visual devices and recalls that are implemented so satisfyingly because they treat the audience like the smart people that we are.

If you are looking for humor (meta or slapstick), lessons on power and responsibility, shocking twists (for non-comic book readers), meaningful cameos, tear-jerking emotional scenes, action-packed sequences, then you are ready to swing into this universe. I, for one, am sucked into this Spider-Verse. And I don't want out.

Spider-Man: ITSV is a masterclass of animated storytelling. A simultaneous introduction to the life of Miles Morales and a myriad of other alternate Spider people while also being an emotionally powerful reminder to any jaded fans of the hero just what about Spider-Man makes him so pervasive and special to so many people. Using writing on par with Guardians of the Galaxy in terms of creating such a cohesive, creative, and varied multiverse that while being so unique and different still feels whole and connected, the crew manages to tell a story of so wildly varied characters coming together as a team feel so natural and effortless. The animation is indescribable to me beyond being the most literal realization of the phrase “Every Frame A Painting” that has ever been put to film. ITSV has changed the superhero climate forever, and in my opinion, we are all so much better off as an audience because of it. Stan Lee’s cameo is a devious, somewhat accidental attack on my emotions and no one will ever be prepared for it. 9/10

Wow!  Just, Wow!  This movie is not only going to redefine what an animated movie should look like, it's going to raise the expectation level of what any superhero movie should feel like.  The creators combined traditional animation with pixar-style animation and then went even further and developed a new way of blending colors, text, dialogue and music so the audience feels like they are living inside a comic book.  I actually tried to find a scene or moment where the animators maybe cheaped out or half-assed something and I couldn't.  Every scene, every sequence . . . hell, every frame was stunning.

The protagonist is Miles Morales, an accidental spiderman set in our world and the writers do a great job of really developing him well in a very short time.  An alternate universe Peter Parker also enters our world and his  character harkens back to the Sam Raimi films and genuflects to Raimi's Spiderman 1 and 2 and justifiably jibes Spiderman 3.  There's also Spiderwoman, Film Noir Spiderman, Anime Spidergirl and Spiderpig.  If I had any complaint, it's that these last three characters seem tacked on in anticipation of sequels or extended universe planning.  

Also, this movie had hands-down the best Stan Lee cameo ever.  You may think it's more sentimental because of his passing just recently and that may be a factor but I assure you that's not why it's great.  It's like they finally figured out the best way to portray the great creator in a way fitting to his legacy.

Definitely stick around until the very end of the credits. Yes, I'm pointing at you!

Okay, this year I thought I'd seen it all when it came to good superhero movies. Black Panther, Infinity Wars, and The Incredibles 2. I remember that most  of those had trailers for this movie, and I shrugged and though "Looked cool, but that's probably just cause they wanted a cool trailer". Turns out, this movie lives up to the hype, 100 percent. It is, hands down, my favorite superhero movie of this year. First, the animation is... lush, textured, colorful, striking,, electric, fluid, and a bunch of other synonyms that escape me now. Just... Wow. It's like the  brilliance of the final battle of the Incredibles 2 was distilled and liberally mixed through the whole movie. Second, the story is wonderful, taking an absurd multiverse story and running with it. There were so many ways for this to get muddled, confused, unfocused, but it never did. The characters are perfectly matched with their animations, and I swear that the spider-man voiced Nickolas Cage even had his mannerisms!  The heroes are wonderfully individual, the villains were both threatening and had solid motives, and the side characters are on point as well. Lastly, the writing is excellently paced and well marbled with humor. 
All in all, I can't think of a movie I've enjoyed more recently, and I highly recommend you go see it.

Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is a rare breed in modern cinema, it's fearless. It doesn't feel beholden to expectations of what you think it should or could be. It feels like it was made in a vacuum like the filmmakers had a clear vision for how to make this work and stand out. How to make it not just another Spider-man movie, of which there are (too) many, but to make it its own beast. Much like our main protagonist Miles Morales having to find his own path to becoming Spider-Man, the secret is to do it your own way, add your own style, rhythm, and pace.
Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse has a style, and rhythm all of its own. I have never experienced anything like it. It is truly a comic book come to life. Nothing about it is traditional, the creative decisions are deliberate yet feel spontaneous and only serve to heighten the experience. This movie begs to be seen on the big screen, it's built for it, and if you choose to wait I feel bad for you that you missed out it on the grandest stage.
So, does that mean that Spider-Man: Into the Spider-Verse is all style and no substance? That's the most amazing part, no! Its style is matched completely by its story, heart, and humour. It's a complex story that is never spoon fed to the audience yet you completely get it. This is Miles' story, no doubt, but it has an eclectic group of Spider... people, each with their part to play. For all it's slick visuals and stunning action it takes the time to make you feel, to have you invest yourself completely. And yes, it's funny, genuinely so and for me, it never panders, as animated movies often do, to the little ones. Even though it gets a little dark, it's not disturbing, it's just genuine.
This is the kind of movie that needs a trilogy and/or more. It deserves to be seen and celebrated for the remarkable achievement that it is so that we do get more. More opportunities to push the boundaries and expectations for animated movies and also to see where these characters and the unlimited possibilities of the Spider-Verse can take us.

One of or better yet, the BEST COMIC BOOK MOVIE EVER! Expect a really fun, thrilling, and action-packed adventure with one of our childhood characters in animation we've never seen before. Just the animation alone made this movie and I'm not at all surprised that it won twice in the animated feature field. Proving that the Marvel magic need not be restricted to live-action blockbusters, along comes "Into the Spider-Verse," with its aim to both celebrate and expand upon the Spider-Man mythos. Viewers that have only known Peter Parker to be the on-screen alter-ego of Spider-Man have to be willing to accept Miles Morales as the web-slinger in order for the film to work as intended. This movie hinges on their being able to appreciate and care about Morales, and from the first seconds seeing him in his room, wearing headphones and singing along to a favorite song before school, I did. He more than earns the mantle. The realities of his teenage existence - the awkwardness and the desire for acceptance - connect in a deeply meaningful way, not to mention that those scenes are also used to introduce another of the film's important characters. The mentor / mentee relationship between Miles and Peter Parker is also a pivotal theme in this film, with the latter being depicted in a fashion at odds with previous film incarnations. The arrival of alternate reality Spider-Men, -Women, & -Pigs gives the film its humor, while also underscoring the central conceit. As I was watching this movie, I thought back to the first time I viewed Spirited Away, another superior story fearlessly told through the spectrum of animation, whereby a kid is swept up into an adventure that tests preexisting notions concerning reality and travels into the realm of the fantastical. Miles' emerging discoveries about his powers, the alternate realities where other super-powered individuals reside, and his worthiness to be a hero, and not just any hero, but THE Spider-Man, are all part of the fun. The film also finds clever ways to pay tribute to Spider-Man lore - both the well-known and obscure facets - so those with an attentive eye will appreciate the many Easter eggs appearing throughout its running time. The story is ambitious, the characters fully realized, action-scenes are a thrill to behold, and the animation style provides a bountiful aesthetic to tell this story. I feel very confident asserting that "Into the Spider-Verse" is one of the best films of 2018, even though there are many candidates I still need to view. Whether young or old, the film's lasting message that anyone can be Spider-Man is the kind of encouragement everyone should register and find inspiring. The magic of movies is alive and well as long as films like this continue to be made. "Into the Spider-Verse" isnt just the best Spider-Man film to date, it's also an all-time great animated film. Walking out of the cinema, I already felt eagerness at the notion of my second viewing.

This film left me satisfied in ways I haven't felt in such a long time. Early reviews indicated that this is the best Spider-Man film ever and I wholeheartedly agree. Everything from the beautifully rendered scenes of New York to the super-related and lovable cast to the fast-paced and well-written plot are perfectly executed. It's hard to believe that this is a Sony production BUT we need to remind ourselves that they gave us Spider-Man 2 (which has been unseated as the best SM film ever :P). As a huge (understatement) Spider-Man fan, Miles' big screen debut is also the best incarnation of the character. It's as if writers Phil Lord and Rodney Rothman took everything great about Bendis's work, put this into the movie, and made the character even better. Combined with the perfectly casted Shameik Moore's voice talent, it's impossible to not relate to Miles. Old Peter Parker is great too as the reluctant mentor, but you feel the character's pains and woes and it feels refreshing for a character that's 50+ years old.

Into the Spider-Verse is so good that I feel compelled to bring all my friends, especially those that aren't aware of how good animated or comic book movies can be, to see this movie. I think I'm going to do just that :)

"Into the Spider-Verse" has an irresistible visual style that truly made me feel like I was watching a comic book unfold. The visual aspect of the movie was definitely my favorite. It is one of those movies that I felt the extra cost of watching it in 3D was well worth it. The movie has a good story that's full of good humor, great action, and likable characters. The story has an okay start but takes off in the second half but I would say it moves at a solid pace. It's clear that the minds behind the story are fans of the source material. I personally found this to be one of the stronger animated films that 2018 has to offer and I feel it will do big things for Sony's animation studios. I had a lot of fun watching the movie and as a long time fan of the character of "Spider-Man", I can safely say this was a solid and refreshing take on the character.
